annotations.shortDefinition: A postal address
annotations.definition: There is a variety of postal address formats defined around the world. This format defines a superset that is the basis for all addresses around the world.
annotations.comment: Note: address is for postal addresses, not physical locations.
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to record postal addresses, along with notes about their use.

binding.name: AddressUse
binding.definition: The use of an address

code.definition: A communication address at a home.
An office address. First choice for business related contacts during business hours.
A temporary address. The period can provide more detailed information.
This address is no longer in use (or was never correct, but retained for records).

annotation.shortDefinition: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
annotation.definition: The purpose of this address.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
annotation.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.
annotation.committeeNotes: Is it outside the 80% for this to repeat?

annotation.definition: A full text representation of the address.
annotation.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
annotation.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.
annotation.v2Mapping: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

annotation.shortDefinition: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc
annotation.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction, P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
annotation.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.
annotation.v2Mapping: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

annotation.definition: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.
Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).
A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.
Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
annotation.comment: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when address was/is in use
annotation.definition: Time period when address was/is in use.
annotation.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Age
detail.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM. If value is present, it SHALL be positive.
detail.xpath: (f:code or not(f:value)) and (not(exists(f:system)) or f:system/@value='http://unitsofmeasure.org') and not(contains(f:value/@value, '-'))

annotations.shortDefinition: Content in a format defined elsewhere
annotations.definition: For referring to data content defined in other formats.
annotations.comment: When providing a summary view (for example with Observation.value[x]) Attachment should be represented with a brief display text such as "Attachment".
annotations.requirements: Many models need to include data defined in other specifications that is complex and opaque to the healthcare model. This includes documents, media recordings, structured data, etc.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.definition: The mime type of an attachment

binding.name: Language
binding.definition: A human language

annotation.shortDefinition: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
annotation.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.
annotation.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to know how to interpret the data.
annotation.v2Mapping: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

annotation.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
annotation.requirements: Users need to be able to choose between the languages in a set of attachments.

annotation.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes. In XML, represented using base64.
annotation.comment: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.
annotation.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline.

annotation.shortDefinition: Uri where the data can be found
annotation.definition: An alternative location where the data can be accessed.
annotation.comment: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.
annotation.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference.
annotation.v2Mapping: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

annotation.shortDefinition: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
annotation.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment.
annotation.comment: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.
annotation.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all.

annotation.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.
annotation.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed and so that a signature of the content can implicitly sign the content of an image without having to include the data in the instance or reference the url in the signature.

annotation.shortDefinition: Label to display in place of the data
annotation.definition: A label or set of text to display in place of the data.
annotation.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

annotation.definition: The date that the attachment was first created.
annotation.requirements: This is often tracked as an integrity issue for use of the attachment.

invariant.name: att-1
invariant.human: It the Attachment has data, it SHALL have a contentType

annotations.shortDefinition: Base for elements defined inside a resource
annotations.definition: Base definition for all elements that are defined inside a resource - but not those in a data type.

annotation.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
annotation.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

annotations.shortDefinition: Concept - reference to a terminology or just text
annotations.definition: A concept that may be defined by a formal reference to a terminology or ontology or may be provided by text.
annotations.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.
annotations.requirements: This is a common pattern in healthcare - a concept that may be defined by one or more codes from formal definitions including LOINC and SNOMED CT, and/or defined by the provision of text that captures a human sense of the concept.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code defined by a terminology system
annotation.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
annotation.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information. Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
annotation.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system. Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

annotation.shortDefinition: Plain text representation of the concept
annotation.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
annotation.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
annotation.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.
annotation.v2Mapping: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

invariant.name: ccc-2
invariant.human: Only one coding in a set can be chosen directly by the user

annotations.shortDefinition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system
annotations.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
annotations.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.
annotations.requirements: References to codes are very common in healthcare models.
annotations.v2Mapping: CE/CNE/CWE subset one of the sets of component 1-3 or 4-6

annotation.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
annotation.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...). OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
annotation.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

annotation.shortDefinition: Version of the system - if relevant
annotation.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
annotation.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

annotation.shortDefinition: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
annotation.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
annotation.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

annotation.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know the system.
annotation.v2Mapping: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

annotation.shortDefinition: If this code was chosen directly by the user
annotation.definition: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
annotation.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.
annotation.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact code was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

invariant.name: cod-1
invariant.description: Value set doesn't substitute for system
invariant.human: If a valueSet is provided, a system URI Is required

annotations.shortDefinition: Details of a Technology mediated contact point (phone, fax, email, etc)
annotations.definition: Details for All kinds of technology mediated contact points for a person or organization, including telephone, email, etc.
annotations.requirements: Need to track phone, fax, mobile, sms numbers, email addresses, twitter tags, etc.

binding.name: ContactPointSystem
binding.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point

code.definition: The value is a telephone number used for voice calls. Use of full international numbers starting with + is recommended to enable automatic dialing support but not required.
The value is a fax machine. Use of full international numbers starting with + is recommended to enable automatic dialing support but not required.
The value is an email address.
The value is a url. This is intended for various personal contacts including blogs, Twitter, Facebook, etc. Do not use for email addresses.

binding.name: ContactPointUse
binding.definition: Use of contact point

code.definition: A communication contact point at a home; attempted contacts for business purposes might intrude privacy and chances are one will contact family or other household members instead of the person one wishes to call. Typically used with urgent cases, or if no other contacts are available.
An office contact point. First choice for business related contacts during business hours.
A temporary contact point. The period can provide more detailed information.
This contact point is no longer in use (or was never correct, but retained for records).
A telecommunication device that moves and stays with its owner. May have characteristics of all other use codes, suitable for urgent matters, not the first choice for routine business.

annotation.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
annotation.comment: Additional out of band data such as extensions, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
annotation.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

annotation.shortDefinition: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
annotation.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
annotation.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.
annotation.v2Mapping: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
annotation.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

invariant.name: cpt-2
invariant.human: A system is required if a value is provided.

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Count
detail.human: There SHALL be a code with a value of "1" if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of length. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM. If present, the value SHALL a whole number.
detail.xpath: (f:code or not(f:value)) and (not(exists(f:system)) or (f:system/@value='http://unitsofmeasure.org' and f:code/@value='1' )) and not(contains(f:value/@value, '.'))

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Distance
detail.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of length. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Duration
detail.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time. If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.

annotations.shortDefinition: Base for all elements
annotations.definition: Base definition for all elements in a resource.

annotation.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
annotation.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

annotations.shortDefinition: Definition of an elements in a resource or extension
annotations.definition: Captures constraints on each element within the resource, profile, or extension.

A nested type in ElementDefinition: Indicates that the element is sliced into a set of alternative definitions (there are multiple definitions on a single element in the base resource). The set of slices is any elements that come after this in the element sequence that have the same path, until a shorter path occurs (the shorter path terminates the set).

annotation.shortDefinition: Element values that used to distinguish the slices
annotation.definition: Designates which child elements are used to discriminate between the slices when processing an instance. If one or more discriminators are provided, the value of the child elements in the instance data SHALL completely distinguish which slice the element in the resource matches based on the allowed values for those elements in each of the slices.
annotation.comment: If there is no discriminator, the content is hard to process, so this should be avoided.

annotation.shortDefinition: Text description of how slicing works (or not)
annotation.definition: A human-readable text description of how the slicing works. If there is no discriminator, this is required to be present to provide whatever information is possible about how the slices can be differentiated.
annotation.comment: If it's really not possible to differentiate them, the design should be re-evaluated to make te content usable.

annotation.shortDefinition: If elements must be in same order as slices
annotation.definition: If the matching elements have to occur in the same order as defined in the profile.
annotation.comment: Order should only be required when it is a pressing concern for presentation. Profile authors should consider making the order a feature of the rules about the narrative, not the rules about the data - requiring ordered data makes the profile much less re-usable.

annotation.definition: Whether additional slices are allowed or not. When the slices are ordered, profile authors can also say that additional slices are only allowed at the end.
annotation.comment: Allowing additional elements makes for a much for flexible template - it's open for use in wider contexts, but also means that the content of the resource is not closed, and applications have to decide how to handle content not described by the profile.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ElementDefinition: The data type or resource that the value of this element is permitted to be.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of Data type or Resource
annotation.definition: Name of Data type or Resource that is a(or the) type used for this element.
annotation.comment: If the element is a reference to another resource, this element contains "Reference", and the profile element refers to the profile of the allowed target of the resource, which may be a reference to the general definition of a resource (e.g. http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Patient). There would be one pair of type/code for each allowed target resource type.

annotation.definition: Identifies a profile structure that SHALL hold for resources or datatypes referenced as the type of this element. Can be a local reference - to another structure in this profile, or a reference to a structure in another profile.
annotation.comment: The reference might be a simple name in the form #[name], which is a reference to another named constraint in a resource - where the resource contains more than one constraint, or a URL which is a reference to a resource Profile, with a terminal #[name] which identifies a specific structure entry in the profile.

annotation.definition: If the type is a reference to another resource, how the resource is or can be aggreated - is it a contained resource, or a reference, and if the context is a bundle, is it included in the bundle.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ElementDefinition: Identifies a concept from an external specification that roughly corresponds to this element.

annotation.definition: An internal reference to the definition of a mapping.
Identifies the computable language in which mapping.map is expressed.
annotation.comment: If omitted, then there can be no expectation of computational interpretation of the mapping.

annotation.definition: Expresses what part of the target specification corresponds to this element.
annotation.comment: For most mappings, the syntax is undefined. Syntax will be provided for mappings to the RIM. Multiple mappings may be possible and may include constraints on other resource elements that identify when a particular mapping applies.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ElementDefinition: Binds to a value set if this element is coded (code, Coding, CodeableConcept).

annotation.definition: A descriptive name for this - can be useful for generating implementation artifacts.
annotation.comment: SHALL be unique within the profile. If the same name as an imported profile, will override the imported binding (and SHALL be a proper constraint on the imported binding).

annotation.definition: Indicates the degree of conformance expectations associated with this binding - that is, the degree to which the provided value set must be adhered to in the instances.
annotation.comment: For further discussion, see [[[Using Terminologies]]].

annotation.shortDefinition: Human explanation of the value set
annotation.definition: Describes the intended use of this particular set of codes.
Points to the value set or external definition (e.g. implicit value set) that identifies the set of codes to be used.
annotation.comment: For value sets,the referenceResource, the display can contain the value set description. The reference may be version-specific or not.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ElementDefinition: Formal constraints such as co-occurrence and other constraints that can be computationally evaluated within the context of the instance.

annotation.definition: Allows identification of which elements have their cardinalities impacted by the constraint. Will not be referenced for constraints that do not affect cardinality.
Used to label the constraint in OCL or in short displays incapable of displaying the full human description.
Identifies the impact constraint violation has on the conformance of the instance.
annotation.comment: This allows constraints to be asserted as "shall" (error) and "should" (warning).

annotation.definition: Text that can be used to describe the constraint in messages identifying that the constraint has been violated.
annotation.comment: Should be expressed in business terms as much as possible.

annotation.definition: An XPath expression of constraint that can be executed to see if this constraint is met.
annotation.comment: Elements SHALL use "f" as the namespace prefix for the FHIR namespace, and "x" for the xhtml namespace, and SHALL not use any other prefixes.
annotation.requirements: Used in Schematron tests of the validity of the resource.

binding.name: BindingConformance
binding.definition: Binding conformance for applications

code.definition: Only codes in the specified set are allowed. If the binding is extensible, other codes may be used for concepts not covered by the bound set of codes.

For greater interoperability, implementers are strongly encouraged to use the bound set of codes, however alternate codes may be used in derived profiles and implementations if necessary without being considered non-conformant.

The codes in the set are an example to illustrate the meaning of the field. There is no particular preference for its use nor any assertion that the provided values are sufficient to meet implementation needs.

binding.name: ConstraintSeverity
binding.definition: SHALL applications comply with this constraint?

code.definition: If the constraint is violated, the resource is not conformant.
If the constraint is violated, the resource is conformant, but it is not necessarily following best practice.

binding.name: PropertyRepresentation
binding.definition: How a property is represented on the wire

code.definition: In XML, this property is represented as an attribute not an element.

binding.name: BindingStrength
binding.definition: Indication of the degree of conformance expectations associated with a binding

code.definition: To be conformant, instances of this element SHALL include a code from the specified value set.

To be conformant, instances of this element SHALL include a code from the specified value set if any of the codes within the value set can apply to the concept being communicated. If the valueset does not cover the concept (based on human review), alternate codings (or, data type allowing, text) may be included instead.
Instances are encouraged to draw from the specified codes for interoperability purposes but are not required to do so to be considered conformant.
Instances are not expected or even encouraged to draw from the specified value set. The value set merely provides examples of the types of concepts intended to be included.

binding.name: AggregationMode
binding.definition: How resource references can be aggregated

code.definition: The reference is a local reference to a contained resource.
The reference to a resource that has to be resolved externally to the resource that includes the reference.
The resource the reference points to will be found in the same bundle as the resource that includes the reference.

binding.name: SlicingRules
binding.definition: How slices are interpreted when evaluating an instance

code.definition: No additional content is allowed other than that described by the slices in this profile.
Additional content is allowed anywhere in the list.

Additional content is allowed, but only at the end of the list. Note that using this requires that the slices be ordered, which makes it hard to share uses. This should only be done where absolutely required.

annotation.shortDefinition: The path of the element (see the Detailed Descriptions)
annotation.definition: The path identifies the element and is expressed as a "."-separated list of ancestor elements, beginning with the name of the resource or extension.

annotation.shortDefinition: How this element is represented in instances
annotation.definition: Codes that define how this element is represented in instances, when the deviation varies from the normal case.
annotation.comment: This is rarely used except for special cases where the representation deviates from the normal, which is done only very reluctantly, and can only be done in the base standard (and profiles must reproduce what the base standard does).

annotation.shortDefinition: Name for this particular element definition (reference target)
annotation.definition: The name of this element definition (to refer to it from other element definitions using ElementDefinition.nameReference). This is a unique name referring to a specific set of constraints applied to this element. One use of this is to provide a name to different slices of the same element.
annotation.comment: The name SHALL be unique within the structure within the context of the constrained resource element. (Though to avoid confusion, uniqueness across all elements is recommended.).
annotation.requirements: Allows referencing a defined element. May also be used for code generation purposes.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name for element to display with or prompt for element
annotation.definition: The text to display beside the element indicating its meaning or to use to prompt for the element in a user display or form.
annotation.comment: Question and label serve similar purposes in they both can be used to prompt for capturing a data element. Whether the question form or label form should be used will depend on the type of instrument being used to capture the information.

annotation.definition: A code that provides the meaning for the element according to a particular terminology.
annotation.comment:
The data element definition and other constraints SHALL be a proper constraint on the meaning (as defined in the code system, including relationships) of any code listed here.
Where multiple codes exist in a terminology that could correspond to the data element, the most granular code(s) should be selected, so long as they are not more restrictive than the data element itself.
annotation.requirements: Links the meaning of an element to an external terminology.

annotation.shortDefinition: This element is sliced - slices follow
annotation.definition: Indicates that the element is sliced into a set of alternative definitions (there are multiple definitions on a single element in the base resource). The set of slices is any elements that come after this in the element sequence that have the same path, until a shorter path occurs (the shorter path terminates the set).
A concise definition that is shown in the generated XML format that summarizes profiles (used throughout the specification).
annotation.comment: May change the term to provide language more appropriate to the context of the profile or to reflect slicing.

annotation.shortDefinition: Full formal definition as narrative text
annotation.definition: Provides a complete explanation of the meaning of the data element for human readability. For the case of elements derived from existing elements (e.g. constraints), the definition SHALL be consistent with the base definition, but convey the meaning of the element in the particular context of use of the resource.
annotation.comment: It is easy for a different definition to change the meaning of an element and this can have nasty downstream consequences. Please be careful when providing definitions.
annotation.requirements: To allow a user to state the usage of an element in a particular context.

annotation.shortDefinition: Comments about the use of this element
annotation.definition: Comments about the use of the element, including notes about how to use the data properly, exceptions to proper use, etc.
annotation.comment: If it is possible to capture usage rules using invariants, that mechanism should be used in preference to this element.

annotation.definition: Explains why this element is needed and why it's been constrained as it has.
annotation.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the element (that's done in comments), rather it's for traceability of *why* the element is either needed or why the constraints exist as they do. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this data element.

annotation.definition: Identifies additional names by which this element might also be known.
annotation.requirements: Allows for better easier recognition of the element by multiple communities, including international communities.

annotation.definition: The minimum number of times this element SHALL appear in the instance.
The maximum number of times this element is permitted to appear in the instance.

annotation.shortDefinition: Data type and Profile for this element
annotation.definition: The data type or resource that the value of this element is permitted to be.
annotation.comment: The Type of the element can be left blank, in which case the type is inherited from the resource. The type can only be listed in this field if it is an allowed option in the base resource.

annotation.definition: Identifies the name of a slice defined elsewhere in the profile whose constraints should be applied to the current element.
annotation.comment: If child components of this element are defined, they act as constraints on the referenced slice.

annotation.shortDefinition: Specified value it missing from instance
annotation.definition: The value that should be used if there is no value stated in the instance.
annotation.comment: Default values can only be specified on a resource, data type, or extension definition, and never in a profile that applies to one of these. Specifying a default value means that the property can never been unknown - it must always have a value. Further, the default value can never be changed. For these reasons, default values are (and should be) used extremely sparingly.

annotation.shortDefinition: Implicit meaning when this element is missing
annotation.definition: The Implicit meaning that is to be understood when this element is missing.
annotation.comment: Implicit meanings for missing values can only be specified on a resource, data type, or extension definition, and never in a profile that applies to one of these. An implicit meaning for a missing value can never be changed, and specifying one has the consequence that constraining its use in profiles eliminates use cases as possibilities, not merely moving them out of scope.

annotation.definition: Specifies a value that SHALL be exactly the value for this element in the instance. For purposes of comparison, non-signficant whitespace is ignored, and all values must be an exact match (case and accent sensitive). Missing elements/attributes must also be missing.
annotation.comment: This is not recommended for Coding and CodeableConcept since these often have highly contextual properties such as version or display.

annotation.shortDefinition: Value must have at least these property values
annotation.definition: Specifies a value that the value in the instance SHALL follow - that is, any value in the pattern must be found in the instance. Other additional values may be found too. This is effectively constraint by example. The values of elements present in the pattern must match exactly (case-senstive, accent-sensitive, etc.).
annotation.comment: Mostly used for fixing values of CodeableConcept.

annotation.definition: A sample value for this element demonstrating the type of information that would typically be captured.
annotation.comment:
This will most commonly be present for data where it's not implicitly obvious from either the data type or value set what the values might be. (I.e. Example values for dates or quantities would generally be unnecessary.)
If the example value are fully populated, the publication tool can generate an instance automatically.

annotation.definition: Indicates the maximum length in characters that is permitted to be present in conformant instances and which is expected to be supported by conformant consumers that support the element.
annotation.comment: Receivers are not required to reject instances that exceed the maximum length. The full length could be stored. In some cases, data might be truncated, though truncation should be undertaken with care and an understanding of the consequences of doing so. If not specified, there is no conformance expectation for length support.

annotation.definition: A reference to an invariant that may make additional statements about the cardinality or value in the instance.

annotation.shortDefinition: Condition that must evaluate to true
annotation.definition: Formal constraints such as co-occurrence and other constraints that can be computationally evaluated within the context of the instance.
annotation.comment: Constraints should be declared on the "context" element - the lowest element in the hierarchy that is common to all nodes referenced by the constraint.

annotation.definition: If true, conformant resource authors SHALL be capable of providing a value for the element and resource consumers SHALL be capable of extracting and doing something useful with the data element. If false, the element may be ignored and not supported.
annotation.comment: "Something useful" is context dependent. This flag is never set to true by the FHIR specification itself - it is only set to true in profiles, and when the profile sets it true, it SHALL describe what it means for applications to support the element. In general, the question is what would a reasonable observer expect of a system that explicitly claims to "support" this element?
annotation.requirements: Allows a profile to set expectations for system capabilities beyond merely respecting cardinality constraints.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this modifies the meaning of other elements
annotation.definition: If true, the value of this element affects the interpretation of the element or resource that contains it, and the value of the element cannot be ignored. Typically, this is used for status, negation and qualification codes. The effect of this is that the element cannot be ignored by systems: they SHALL either recognize the element and process it, and/or a pre-determination has been made that it is not relevant to their particular system.
annotation.comment: Only the definition of an element can set IsModifier true - either the specification itself or where an extension is originally defined. Once set to false, it cannot be set to true in derived profiles. An element/extension that has isModifier=true SHOULD also have a minimum cardinality of 1, so that there is no lack of clarity about what to do if it is missing. If it can be missing, the definition SHALL make the meaning of a missing element clear.
annotation.requirements: Allows elements to be introduced into a specification that can't safely be ignored by applications that don't recognize them.

annotation.definition: Whether the element should be included if a client requests a search with the parameter _summary=true.
annotation.comment: Some resources include a set of simple metadata, and some very large data. This element is used to reduce the quantity of data returned in searches. Note that servers may pre-cache summarised resources for optimal performance, so servers may not support per-profile use of the isSummary flag.
annotation.requirements: Allow clients to search through large resources quickly.

annotation.shortDefinition: ValueSet details if this is coded
annotation.definition: Binds to a value set if this element is coded (code, Coding, CodeableConcept).

annotation.shortDefinition: Map element to another set of definitions
annotation.definition: Identifies a concept from an external specification that roughly corresponds to this element.
annotation.comment: Mappings are not necessarily specific enough for safe translation.
annotation.requirements: Provides guidance to implementers familiar with or converting content from other specifications.

invariant.name: eld-13
invariant.human: Types must be unique by the combination of code and profile
invariant.xpath: not(exists(for $type in f:type return $type/preceding-sibling::f:type[f:code/@value=$type/f:code/@value and f:profile/@value = $type/f:profile/@value]))

invariant.name: eld-14
invariant.human: Constraints must be unique by key

invariant.name: eld-11
invariant.human: Binding can only be present for coded elements, string, and uri

invariant.name: eld-8
invariant.human: Pattern and value are mutually exclusive

invariant.name: eld-15
invariant.human: Constraint names must be unique.

invariant.name: eld-16
invariant.human: default value and meaningWhenMissing are mutually exclusive

invariant.name: eld-2
invariant.human: Min <= Max

invariant.name: eld-7
invariant.human: Pattern may only be specified if there is one type

invariant.name: eld-6
invariant.human: Fixed value may only be specified if there is one type

invariant.name: eld-5
invariant.human: Either a namereference or a fixed value (but not both) is permitted

annotations.definition: Optional Extensions Element - found in all resources.
annotations.requirements: The ability to add extensions in a structured way is what keeps FHIR resources simple.

annotation.shortDefinition: identifies the meaning of the extension
annotation.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
annotation.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition should be version specific. This will ideally be the URI for the Resource Profile defining the extension, with the code for the extension after a #.

annotation.definition: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

annotations.shortDefinition: Name of a human - parts and usage
annotations.definition: A human's name with the ability to identify parts and usage.
annotations.comment: Names may be changed, or repudiated, or people may have different names in different contexts. Names may be divided into parts of different type that have variable significance depending on context, though the division into parts does not always matter. With personal names, the different parts may or may not be imbued with some implicit meaning; various cultures associate different importance with the name parts and the degree to which systems must care about name parts around the world varies widely.
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to record names, along with notes about their use.

binding.name: NameUse
binding.definition: The use of a human name

code.definition: Known as/conventional/the one you normally use.
The formal name as registered in an official (government) registry, but which name might not be commonly used. May be called "legal name".
A temporary name. Name.period can provide more detailed information. This may also be used for temporary names assigned at birth or in emergency situations.
A name that is used to address the person in an informal manner, but is not part of their formal or usual name.
Anonymous assigned name, alias, or pseudonym (used to protect a person's identity for privacy reasons).
This name is no longer in use (or was never correct, but retained for records).

A name used prior to marriage. Marriage naming customs vary greatly around the world. This name use is for use by applications that collect and store "maiden" names. Though the concept of maiden name is often gender specific, the use of this term is not gender specific. The use of this term does not imply any particular history for a person's name, nor should the maiden name be determined algorithmically.

annotation.shortDefinition: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
annotation.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
annotation.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.
annotation.v2Mapping: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

annotation.shortDefinition: Text representation of the full name
annotation.definition: A full text representation of the name.
annotation.comment: Can provide both a text representation and structured parts.
annotation.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

annotation.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
annotation.comment: For family name, hyphenated names such as "Smith-Jones" are a single name, but names with spaces such as "Smith Jones" are broken into multiple parts.

annotation.shortDefinition: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
annotation.definition: Given name.
annotation.comment: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name. Not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.

annotation.shortDefinition: Parts that come before the name
annotation.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.

annotation.shortDefinition: Parts that come after the name
annotation.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when name was/is in use
annotation.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
annotation.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

annotations.shortDefinition: An identifier intended for computation
annotations.definition: A technical identifier - identifies some entity uniquely and unambiguously.
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to identify things with confidence and be sure that the identification is not subject to misinterpretation.
annotations.rimMapping: II - see see identifier pattern at http://wiki.hl7.org/index.php?title=Common_Design_Patterns#Identifier_Pattern for relevant discussion. The Identifier class is a little looser than the v3 type II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs. Also maps to Role[classCode=IDENT]
annotations.v2Mapping: CX / EI (occasionally, more often EI maps to a resource id or a URL)

binding.name: IdentifierUse
binding.definition: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known

code.definition: the identifier recommended for display and use in real-world interactions.
the identifier considered to be most trusted for the identification of this item.
A temporary identifier.
An identifier that was assigned in secondary use - it serves to identify the object in a relative context, but cannot be consistently assigned to the same object again in a different context.

annotation.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
annotation.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

annotation.definition: A text string for the identifier that can be displayed to a human so they can recognize the identifier.
annotation.requirements: Allows humans to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

annotation.definition: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
annotation.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers. To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular sequence or set of unique identifiers.

annotation.definition: The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
annotation.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.
annotation.rimMapping: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when id is/was valid for use
annotation.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

annotation.shortDefinition: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
annotation.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
annotation.comment: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner.
annotation.rimMapping: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field. Also Role.scoper

annotations.shortDefinition: Metadata about a resource
annotations.definition: The metadata about a resource. This is content in the resource that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

annotation.definition: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
annotation.comment: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

annotation.shortDefinition: When the resource version last changed
annotation.definition: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
annotation.comment: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

annotation.shortDefinition: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
annotation.definition: A list of profiles [[[StructureDefinition]]]s that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to [[[StructureDefinition.url]]].
annotation.comment:
It is up to the server and/or other infrastructure of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over time.
The list of profile URLs is a set.

annotation.shortDefinition: Security Labels applied to this resource
annotation.definition: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
annotation.comment:
The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource
The list of security labels is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

annotation.definition: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
annotation.comment:
The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.
The list of tags is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Money
detail.human: There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of currency. If system is present, it SHALL be ISO 4217 (system = "urn:std:iso:4217" - currency).

annotations.shortDefinition: A human-readable formatted text, including images
annotations.definition: A human-readable formatted text, including images.

binding.name: NarrativeStatus
binding.definition: The status of a resource narrative

code.definition: The contents of the narrative are entirely generated from the structured data in the resource.
The contents of the narrative are entirely generated from the structured data in the resource and some of the content is generated from extensions.
The contents of the narrative contain additional information not found in the structured data.
the contents of the narrative are some equivalent of "No human-readable text provided for this resource".

annotation.definition: The status of the narrative - whether it's entirely generated (from just the defined data or the extensions too), or whether a human authored it and it may contain additional data.
The actual narrative content, a stripped down version of XHTML.
annotation.comment: The contents of the html element are an XHTML fragment containing only the basic html formatting elements described in chapters 7-11 and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained stylesheets. The XHTML content may not contain a head, a body, external stylesheet references, scripts, forms, base/link/xlink, frames, iframes and objects.

annotations.shortDefinition: Time range defined by start and end date/time
annotations.definition: A time period defined by a start and end date and optionally time.
annotations.comment: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If a duration might be required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.
annotations.rimMapping: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

annotation.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
annotation.comment: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

annotation.shortDefinition: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
annotation.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
annotation.comment: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

invariant.name: per-1
invariant.human: If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

annotations.shortDefinition: A measured or measurable amount
annotations.definition: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
annotations.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.
annotations.requirements: Need to able to capture all sorts of measured values, even if the measured value are not precisely quantified. Values include exact measures such as 3.51g, customary units such as 3 tablets, and currencies such as $100.32USD.
annotations.rimMapping: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

binding.name: QuantityComparator
binding.definition: How the Quantity should be understood and represented

code.definition: The actual value is less than the given value.
The actual value is less than or equal to the given value.
The actual value is greater than or equal to the given value.
The actual value is greater than the given value.

annotation.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
annotation.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
annotation.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.
annotation.rimMapping: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

annotation.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues. E.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value.
annotation.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.

annotation.definition: A human-readable form of the units.
annotation.requirements: There are many representations for units and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

annotation.shortDefinition: System that defines coded unit form
annotation.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
annotation.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

annotation.definition: A computer processable form of the units in some unit representation system.
annotation.comment:
The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.
The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
annotation.requirements: Need a computable form of the units that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

invariant.name: qty-3
invariant.human: If a code for the units is present, the system SHALL also be present

annotations.shortDefinition: Set of values bounded by low and high
annotations.definition: A set of ordered Quantities defined by a low and high limit.
annotations.comment: The stated low and high value are assumed to have arbitrarily high precision when it comes to determining which values are in the range. I.e. 1.99 is not in the range 2 -> 3.
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to specify ranges of values.
annotations.v2Mapping: NR and also possibly SN (but see also quantity)

annotation.definition: The low limit. The boundary is inclusive.
annotation.comment: If the low element is missing, the low boundary is not known.

annotation.definition: The high limit. The boundary is inclusive.
annotation.comment: If the high element is missing, the high boundary is not known.

invariant.name: rng-2
invariant.human: If present, low SHALL have a lower value than high

invariant.name: rng-3
invariant.human: Quantity values cannot have a comparator when used in a Range

annotations.shortDefinition: A ratio of two Quantity values - a numerator and a denominator
annotations.definition: A relationship of two Quantity values - expressed as a numerator and a denominator.
annotations.requirements: Need to able to capture ratios for some measurements (titers) and some rates (costs).

annotation.definition: The value of the numerator.
The value of the denominator.

invariant.name: rat-1
invariant.human: numerator and denominator SHALL both be present, or both be absent. If both are absent, there SHALL be some extension present

annotations.shortDefinition: A reference from one resource to another
annotations.definition: A reference from one resource to another.
annotations.rimMapping: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

annotation.shortDefinition: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
annotation.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
annotation.comment:
Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.
Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

annotation.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
annotation.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource. The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

invariant.name: ref-1
invariant.human: SHALL have a local reference if the resource is provided inline

annotations.shortDefinition: A series of measurements taken by a device
annotations.definition: A series of measurements taken by a device, with upper and lower limits. There may be more than one dimension in the data.
annotations.comment: The data is not interpretable without at least origin, period, and dimensions, but these are optional to allow a separation between the template of measurement and the actual measurement, such as between DeviceCapabilities and DeviceLog. When providing a summary view (for example with Observation.value[x]) SampledData should be represented with a brief display text such as "Sampled Data".
annotations.requirements: There is a need for a concise way to handle the data produced by devices that sample a physical state at a high frequency.

annotation.definition: The base quantity that a measured value of zero represents. In addition, this provides the units of the entire measurement series.
The length of time between sampling times, measured in milliseconds.
annotation.comment: This is usually a whole number.

annotation.shortDefinition: Multiply data by this before adding to origin
annotation.definition: A correction factor that is applied to the sampled data points before they are added to the origin.
The lower limit of detection of the measured points. This is needed if any of the data points have the value "L" (lower than detection limit).
The upper limit of detection of the measured points. This is needed if any of the data points have the value "U" (higher than detection limit).

annotation.shortDefinition: Number of sample points at each time point
annotation.definition: The number of sample points at each time point. If this value is greater than one, then the dimensions will be interlaced - all the sample points for a point in time will be recorded at once.
annotation.comment: If there is more than one dimension, the code for the type of data will define the meaning of the dimensions (typically ECG data).

annotation.definition: A series of data points which are decimal values separated by a single space (character u20). The special values "E" (error), "L" (below detection limit) and "U" (above detection limit) can also be used in place of a decimal value.

annotations.shortDefinition: An XML digital Signature
annotations.definition: An XML digital signature along with supporting context.
annotations.comment: The elements of the Signature Resource are for ease of access of these elements. The non-repudiation proof comes from the XML-Signature validation, which includes validation of the referenced objects (e.g., Resources) (a.k.a., Content) in the XML-Signature Detached form.
annotations.requirements: There are a number of places where content must be signed in healthcare.

binding.name: SignatureType
binding.definition: An indication of the reason that an entity signed the object

annotation.shortDefinition: Indication of the reason the entity signed the object(s)
annotation.definition: An indication of the reason that the entity signed this document. This may be explicitly included as part of the signature information and can be used when determining accountability for various actions concerning the document.
annotation.comment: Examples include attesting to: authorship, correct transcription, and witness of specific event. Also known as a “Commitment Type Indication”.

annotation.definition: When the digital signature was signed.
annotation.comment: This should agree with the information in the signature.

annotation.definition: A reference to an application-usable description of the person that signed the certificate (e.g. the signature used their private key).
annotation.comment: This should agree with the information in the signature.

annotation.definition: The base64 encoding of the XML-Signature.
annotation.comment: Where the signed content is a FHIR Resource(s), the signature is of the XML form of the Resource(s) using XML-Signature (XMLDIG) "Detached Signature" form.

annotations.shortDefinition: A timing schedule that specifies an event that may occur multiple times
annotations.definition: Specifies an event that may occur multiple times. Timing schedules are used to record when things are expected or requested to occur. The most common usage is in dosage instructions for medications. They are also used when planning care of various kinds.
annotations.comment: A timing schedule can be either a list of events - intervals on which the event occurs, or a single event with repeating criteria or just repeating criteria with no actual event. When both event and a repeating specification are provided, the list of events should be understood as an interpretation of the information in the repeat structure.
annotations.requirements: Need to able to track proposed timing schedules. There are several different ways to do this: one or more specified times, a simple rules like three times a day, or before/after meals.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Timing: A set of rules that describe when the event should occur.

annotation.definition: Outer bounds for start and/or end limits of the timing schedule.
A total count of the desired number of repetitions.
annotation.comment: If you have both bounds and count, then this should be understand as within the bounds period, until count times happens.
annotation.requirements: Repetitions may be limited by end time or total occurrences.

annotation.definition: How long this thing happens for when it happens.
annotation.comment: For some events the duration is part of the definition of the event (e.g. IV infusions). For others, it's part of the timing specification (e.g. exercise).
annotation.requirements: Some activities are not instantaneous and need to be maintained for a period of time.

annotation.shortDefinition: s | min | h | d | wk | mo | a - unit of time (UCUM)
annotation.definition: The units of time for the duration, in UCUM units.

annotation.shortDefinition: Event occurs frequency times per duration
annotation.definition: The number of times to repeat the action within the specified period / period range (i.e. both period and periodMax provided).

annotation.shortDefinition: Event occurs frequency times per duration
annotation.definition: If present, indicates that the frequency is a range - so repeat between [frequency] and [frequencyMax] times within the period or period range.

annotation.shortDefinition: Event occurs frequency times per period
annotation.definition: Indicates the duration of time over which repetitions are to occur. E.g. to express "3 times per day", 3 would be the frequency and "1 day" would be the period.
If present, indicates that the period is a range from [period] to [periodMax], allowing expressing concepts such as "do this once every 3-5 days.

annotation.shortDefinition: s | min | h | d | wk | mo | a - unit of time (UCUM)
annotation.definition: The units of time for the period in UCUM units.

annotation.shortDefinition: Regular life events the event is tied to
annotation.definition: A real world event that the occurrence of the event should be tied to.
annotation.requirements: Timings are frequently determined by occurrences such as waking, eating and sleep.

binding.name: UnitsOfTime
binding.definition: A unit of time (units from UCUM)

binding.name: EventTiming
binding.definition: Real world event that the schedule relates to

code.definition: event occurs [duration] before the hour of sleep (or trying to).
event occurs [duration] after waking.
event occurs at a meal (from the Latin cibus).
event occurs at breakfast (from the Latin cibus matutinus).
event occurs at lunch (from the Latin cibus diurnus).
event occurs at dinner (from the Latin ante cibus vespertinus).
event occurs [duration] before a meal (from the Latin ante cibus).
event occurs [duration] before breakfast (from the Latin ante cibus matutinus).
event occurs [duration] before lunch (from the Latin ante cibus diurnus).
event occurs [duration] before dinner (from the Latin ante cibus vespertinus).
event occurs [duration] after a meal (from the Latin post cibus).
event occurs [duration] after breakfast (from the Latin post cibus matutinus).
event occurs [duration] after lunch (from the Latin post cibus diurnus).
event occurs [duration] after dinner (from the Latin post cibus vespertinus).

annotation.definition: Identifies specific times when the event occurs.
annotation.requirements: In an MAR, for instance, you need to take a general specification, and turn it into a precise specification.

annotation.shortDefinition: When the event is to occur
annotation.definition: A set of rules that describe when the event should occur.
annotation.requirements: Many timing schedules are determined by regular repetitions.

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive base64Binary
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive base64Binary

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive boolean
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive boolean

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive code
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive code

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive date
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive date

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive dateTime
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive dateTime

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive decimal
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive decimal

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive id
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive id

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive instant
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive instant

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive integer
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive integer

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive oid
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive oid

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive string
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive string

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive time
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive time

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive uri
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive uri

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive uuid
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive uuid

annotations.shortDefinition: Typed element containing the primitive xhtml
annotations.definition: Typed element containing the primitive xhtml

annotations.shortDefinition: A resource with narrative, extensions, and contained resources
annotations.definition: A resource that includes narrative, extensions, and contained resources.

annotation.shortDefinition: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
annotation.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
annotation.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

annotation.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
annotation.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

annotation.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
annotation.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

annotation.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
annotation.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

invariant.name: dom-4
invariant.description: No versionId and lastUpdated in contained resources
invariant.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL not have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated

invariant.name: dom-3
invariant.description: No contained resources that are not referenced from elsewhere
invariant.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource

invariant.name: dom-2
invariant.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL not contain nested Resources

invariant.name: dom-1
invariant.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL not contain any narrative

annotations.shortDefinition: Operation Request or Response
annotations.definition: This special resource type is used to represent [operation](operations.html] request and response. It has no other use, and there is no RESTful end=point associated with it.
annotations.comment: The parameters that may be used are defined by the OperationDefinition resource.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Parameters: A parameter passed to or received from the operation.

annotation.definition: The name of the parameter (reference to the operation definition).

annotation.shortDefinition: If parameter is a data type
annotation.definition: If the parameter is a data type.

annotation.shortDefinition: If parameter is a whole resource
annotation.definition: If the parameter is a whole resource.

annotation.shortDefinition: Named part of a parameter (e.g. Tuple)
annotation.definition: A named part of a parameter. In many implementation context, a set of named parts is known as a "Tuple".
annotation.comment: Only one level of tuples is allowed.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Parameters: A named part of a parameter. In many implementation context, a set of named parts is known as a "Tuple".

annotation.definition: The name of the parameter (reference to the operation definition).
The value of the parameter.
annotation.comment: If there is no value, simply omit the parameter.

annotation.shortDefinition: If part is a whole resource
annotation.definition: If the parameter is a whole resource.
A parameter passed to or received from the operation.

annotations.shortDefinition: Base Resource
annotations.definition: Base Resource for everything.

annotation.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
annotation.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

annotation.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

annotation.shortDefinition: A set of rules under which this content was created
annotation.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
annotation.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

annotation.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
annotation.comment:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource
Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically.
