If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

annotations.shortDefinition: Key information to flag to healthcare providers
annotations.definition: Prospective warnings of potential issues when providing care to the patient.

binding.name: AlertStatus
binding.definition: Indicates whether this alert is active and needs to be displayed to a user, or whether it is no longer needed or entered in error

code.definition: A current alert that should be displayed to a user. A system may use the category to determine which roles should view the alert.
The alert does not need to be displayed any more.
The alert was added in error, and should no longer be displayed.

annotation.definition: Identifier assigned to the alert for external use (outside the FHIR environment).
Allows an alert to be divided into different categories like clinical, administrative etc.
Supports basic workflow.
The person who this alert concerns.
The person or device that created the alert.

annotation.shortDefinition: Partially deaf, Requires easy open caps, No permanent address, etc.
annotation.definition: The coded value or textual component of the alert to display to the user.

search.name: author
search.description: Alert creator

search.name: patient
search.description: The identity of a subject to list alerts for

search.name: subject
search.description: The identity of a subject to list alerts for

annotations.shortDefinition: Allergy or Intolerance (generally: Risk Of Adverse reaction to a substance)
annotations.definition: Risk of harmful or undesirable, physiological response which is unique to an individual and associated with exposure to a substance.
annotations.comment: Substances include, but are not limited to: a therapeutic substance administered correctly at an appropriate dosage for the individual; food; material derived from plants or animals; or venom from insect stings.
annotations.requirements: To record a clinical assessment of a propensity, or potential risk to an individual, of an adverse reaction upon future exposure to the specified substance, or class of substance.

annotations.definition: A nested type in AllergyIntolerance: Details about each Adverse Reaction Event linked to exposure to the identified Substance.

annotation.shortDefinition: Specific substance considered to be responsible for event
annotation.definition: Identification of the specific substance considered to be responsible for the Adverse Reaction event. Note: the substance for a specific reaction may be different to the substance identified as the cause of the risk, but must be consistent with it. For instance, it may be a more specific substance (e.g. a brand medication) or a composite substance that includes the identified substance. It must be clinically safe to only process the AllergyIntolerance.substance and ignore the AllergyIntolerance.event.substance.
annotation.comment: Coding of the Specific Substance with a terminology capable of triggering decision support should be used wherever possible. The Substance field allows for the use of a specific substance or a group or class of substances, for example "Penicillins". The specific Substance field could be used for Amoxycillin. Duplication is acceptable when a specific substance has been recorded in the 'Substance' field.

annotation.shortDefinition: unlikely | likely | confirmed - clinical certainty about the specific substance
annotation.definition: Statement about the degree of clinical certainty that the Specific Substance was the cause of the Manifestation in this reaction event.

annotation.shortDefinition: Clinical symptoms/signs associated with the Event
annotation.definition: Clinical symptoms and/or signs that are observed or associated with the Adverse Reaction Event.
annotation.comment: Manifestation can be expressed as a single word, phrase or brief description. For example: nausea, rash or no reaction. It is preferable that Manifestation should be coded with a terminology, where possible. The values entered here may be used to display on an application screen as part of a list of adverse reactions, as recommended in the UK NHS CUI guidelines. Terminologies commonly used include, but are not limited to, SNOMED-CT or ICD10.

annotation.shortDefinition: Description of the event as a whole
annotation.definition: Text description about the Reaction as a whole, including details of the manifestation if required.
Record of the date and/or time of the onset of the Reaction.
The amount of time that the Adverse Reaction persisted.

annotation.shortDefinition: mild | moderate | severe (of event as a whole)
annotation.definition: Clinical assessment of the severity of the reaction event as a whole, potentially considering multiple different manifestations.
annotation.comment: It is acknowledged that this assessment is very subjective. There may be some some specific practice domains where objective scales have been applied. Objective scales can be included in this model as extensions.

annotation.shortDefinition: How the subject was exposed to the substance
annotation.definition: Identification of the route by which the subject was exposed to the substance.
annotation.comment: Coding of the Route of Exposure with a terminology should be used wherever possible.

annotation.shortDefinition: Text about event not captured in other fields
annotation.definition: Additional text about the Adverse Reaction event not captured in other fields.

binding.name: AllergyIntoleranceType
binding.definition: Identification of the underlying physiological mechanism for a Reaction Risk

code.definition: Immune mediated reaction, including allergic reactions and hypersensitivities.

A non-immune mediated reaction, which can include pseudoallergic reactions, side effects, intolerances, drug toxicities (eg to Gentamicin), drug-drug interactions, food-drug interactions, and drug-disease interactions.

binding.name: AllergyIntoleranceCertainty
binding.definition: Statement about the degree of clinical certainty that a Specific Substance was the cause of the Manifestation in an reaction event

code.definition: There is a low level of clinical certainty that the reaction was caused by the identified Substance.
There is a high level of clinical certainty that the reaction was caused by the identified Substance.
There is a very high level of clinical certainty that the reaction was due to the identified Substance, which may include clinical evidence by testing or rechallenge.

binding.name: AllergyIntoleranceSeverity
binding.definition: Clinical assessment of the severity of a reaction event as a whole, potentially considering multiple different manifestations

code.definition: Causes mild physiological effects.
Causes moderate physiological effects.
Causes severe physiological effects.

binding.name: Manifestation
binding.definition: Clinical symptoms and/or signs that are observed or associated with an Adverse Reaction Event

binding.name: AllergyIntoleranceCriticality
binding.definition: Estimate of the potential clinical harm, or seriousness, of a reaction to an identified Substance

code.definition: The potential clinical impact of a future reaction is estimated as low risk: exposure to substance is unlikely to result in a life threatening or organ system threatening outcome. Future exposure to the Substance is considered a relative contra-indication.

The potential clinical impact of a future reaction is estimated as high risk: exposure to substance may result in a life threatening or organ system threatening outcome. Future exposure to the Substance may be considered an absolute contra-indication.
Unable to assess the potential clinical impact with the information available.

binding.name: AllergyIntoleranceCategory
binding.definition: Category of an identified Substance

code.definition: Any substance consumed to provide nutritional support for the body.
Substances administered to achieve a physiological effect.
Substances that are encountered in the environment.

binding.name: AllergyIntoleranceStatus
binding.definition: Assertion about certainty associated with a propensity, or potential risk, of a reaction to the identified Substance

code.definition: A low level of certainty about the propensity for a reaction to the identified Substance.
A high level of certainty about the propensity for a reaction to the identified Substance, which may include clinical evidence by testing or rechallenge.
A reaction to the identified Substance has been clinically reassessed by testing or rechallenge and considered to be resolved.
A propensity for a reaction to the identified Substance has been disproven with a high level of clinical certainty, which may include testing or rechallenge, and is refuted.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this allergy/intolerance concern that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
Date when the sensitivity was recorded.
Indicates who has responsibility for the record.
The patient who has the allergy or intolerance.

annotation.shortDefinition: Source of the information about the allergy
annotation.definition: The source of the information about the allergy that is recorded.
annotation.comment: The recorder takes repsonsibility for the content, but can reference the source from where they got it.

annotation.shortDefinition: Substance, (or class) considered to be responsible for risk
annotation.definition: Identification of a substance, or a class of substances, that is considered to be responsible for the Adverse reaction risk.
annotation.comment: It is strongly recommended that Substance be coded with a terminology, where possible. For example, some terminologies used include RxNorm, Snomed CT, DM+D, NDFRT, ICD-9, IDC-10, UNI, ATC and CPT. Plain text should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

annotation.definition: Assertion about certainty associated with the propensity, or potential risk, of a reaction to the identified Substance.
annotation.comment: Decision support would typically raise alerts for 'Unconfirmed', 'Confirmed', and 'Resolved' and ignore a 'Refuted' reaction. In particular, 'Refuted' may be useful for reconciliation of the Adverse Reaction List. Some implementations may choose to make this field mandatory.

annotation.shortDefinition: low | high | unassessible - Estimated potential clinical harm
annotation.definition: Estimate of the potential clinical harm, or seriousness, of the reaction to the identified Substance.
annotation.comment: The default criticality value for any propensity to an Adverse Reaction should be 'Low Risk', indicating at the very least a relative contraindication to deliberate or voluntary exposure to the Substance. 'High Risk' is flagged if the clinician has identified a propensity for a more serious or potentially life-threatening reaction, such as anaphylaxis, and implies an absolute contraindication to deliberate or voluntary exposure to the substance. If this element is missing, the criticality is unknown (though it may be known elsewhere).

annotation.definition: Identification of the underlying physiological mechanism for the Reaction Risk.
annotation.comment: Immune-mediated responses have been traditionally regarded as an indicator for escalation of significant future risk. Contemporary knowledge suggests that some reactions previously thought to be immune and non-immune and still carry life threatening risk. It is acknowledged that many clinicians may not be in a position to distinguish the mechanism of a particular reaction. This data element is included nevertheless because many legacy systems have captured this attribute. Immunological testing may provide supporting evidence for the basis and causative substance , but no tests are 100% sensitive or specific for a sensitivity.

annotation.shortDefinition: food | medication | environment - Category of Substance
annotation.definition: Category of the identified Substance.
annotation.comment: This data element has been included because it is currently being captured in some clinical systems. This data can be derived from the Substance where coding systems are used, and is effectively redundant in that situation.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date(/time) of last known occurence of a reaction
annotation.definition: Represents the date and/or time of the last known occurence of a reaction event.
annotation.comment: This date may be replicated by one of the Onset of Reaction dates. Where a textual representation of the date of last occurence is required e.g 'In Childhood, '10 years ago' the Comment element should be used.

annotation.shortDefinition: Additional text not captured in other fields
annotation.definition: Additional narrative about the propensity for the Adverse Reaction, not captured in other fields.
annotation.comment: For example: including reason for flagging a Seriousness of 'High Risk'; and instructions related to future exposure or administration of the Substance, such as administration within an Intensive Care Unit or under corticosteroid cover.

annotation.shortDefinition: Adverse Reaction Events linked to exposure to substance
annotation.definition: Details about each Adverse Reaction Event linked to exposure to the identified Substance.

example.name: Medication Allergy
example.description: A typical Medication allergy from a clinical system

annotations.shortDefinition: A booking of a healthcare event among patient(s), practitioner(s), related person(s) and/or device(s) for a specific date/time. This may result in one or more Encounter(s)
annotations.definition: A booking of a healthcare event among patient(s), practitioner(s), related person(s) and/or device(s) for a specific date/time. This may result in one or more Encounter(s).
A nested type in Appointment: List of participants involved in the appointment.

annotation.shortDefinition: Role of participant in the appointment
annotation.definition: Role of participant in the appointment.

annotation.shortDefinition: A Person, Location/HealthcareService or Device that is participating in the appointment
annotation.definition: A Person, Location/HealthcareService or Device that is participating in the appointment.
annotation.v2Mapping: PID-3-Patient ID List | AIL-3 | AIG-3 | AIP-3

annotation.definition: Is this participant required to be present at the meeting. This covers a use-case where 2 doctors need to meet to discuss the results for a specific patient, and the patient is not required to be present.
Participation status of the Patient.

binding.name: ApptReason
binding.definition: The Reason for the appointment to take place

binding.name: AppointmentStatus
binding.definition: The free/busy status of an appointment

code.definition: Some or all of the participant(s) have not finalized their acceptance of the appointment request.
All participant(s) have been considered and the appointment is confirmed to go ahead at the date/times specified.
Some of the patients have arrived.
This appointment has completed and may have resulted in an encounter.
The appointment has been cancelled.
Some or all of the participant(s) have not/did not appear for the appointment (usually the patient).

binding.name: ParticipantRequired
binding.definition: Is the Participant required to attend the appointment

code.definition: The participant is required to attend the appointment.
The participant may optionally attend the appointment.

The participant is excluded from the appointment, and may not be informed of the appointment taking place. (appointment is about them, not for them - such as 2 doctors discussing results about a patient's test).

binding.name: ActStatus
binding.definition: The status of the appointment

binding.name: ParticipationStatus
binding.definition: The Participation status of an appointment

code.definition: The participant has accepted the appointment.
The participant has declined the appointment and will not participate in the appointment.

The participant has tentatively accepted the appointment. This could be automatically created by a system and requires further processing before it can be accepted. There is no commitment that attendance will occur.
The participant needs to indicate if they accept the appointment by changing this status to one of the other statuses.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this appointment concern that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).

annotation.shortDefinition: pending | booked | arrived | fulfilled | cancelled | noshow
annotation.definition: The overall status of the Appointment. Each of the participants has their own participation status which indicates their involvement in the process, however this status indicates the shared status.
annotation.comment: If the Appointment's status is "cancelled" then all participants are expected to have their calendars released for the appointment period, and as such any Slot's that were marked as BUSY can be re-set to FREE.

annotation.shortDefinition: The type of appointment that is being booked
annotation.definition: The type of appointment that is being booked (This may also be associated with participants for location, and/or a HealthcareService).

annotation.shortDefinition: The reason that this appointment is being scheduled, this is more clinical than administrative
annotation.definition: The reason that this appointment is being scheduled, this is more clinical than administrative.

annotation.shortDefinition: The priority of the appointment. Can be used to make informed decisions if needing to re-prioritize appointments. (The iCal Standard specifies 0 as undefined, 1 as highest, 9 as lowest priority)
annotation.definition: The priority of the appointment. Can be used to make informed decisions if needing to re-prioritize appointments. (The iCal Standard specifies 0 as undefined, 1 as highest, 9 as lowest priority).

annotation.shortDefinition: The brief description of the appointment as would be shown on a subject line in a meeting request, or appointment list. Detailed or expanded information should be put in the comment field
annotation.definition: The brief description of the appointment as would be shown on a subject line in a meeting request, or appointment list. Detailed or expanded information should be put in the comment field.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date/Time that the appointment is to take place
annotation.definition: Date/Time that the appointment is to take place.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date/Time that the appointment is to conclude
annotation.definition: Date/Time that the appointment is to conclude.

annotation.shortDefinition: The slot that this appointment is filling. If provided then the schedule will not be provided as slots are not recursive, and the start/end values MUST be the same as from the slot
annotation.definition: The slot that this appointment is filling. If provided then the schedule will not be provided as slots are not recursive, and the start/end values MUST be the same as from the slot.
Additional comments about the appointment.
annotation.comment: Additional text to aid in facilitating the appointment. For instance, a comment might be, “patient should proceed immediately to infusion room upon arrival”.

annotation.shortDefinition: An Order that lead to the creation of this appointment
annotation.definition: An Order that lead to the creation of this appointment.
annotation.committeeNotes: The Supply Order from the V3 DMIM was discussed and decided outside 80%, permit via extensions where required.

annotation.shortDefinition: List of participants involved in the appointment
annotation.definition: List of participants involved in the appointment.

example.name: Example2docs
example.description: Appointment between 2 doctors to discuss MRI results

search.name: partstatus
search.description: The Participation status of the subject, or other participant on the appointment. Can be used to locate participants that have not responded to meeting requests.

search.name: patient
search.description: One of the individuals of the appointment is this patient

search.name: practitioner
search.description: One of the individuals of the appointment is this practitioner

search.name: location
search.description: This location is listed in the participants of the appointment

search.name: status
search.description: The overall status of the appointment

search.name: actor
search.description: Any one of the individuals participating in the appointment

search.name: date
search.description: Appointment date/time.

annotations.shortDefinition: A reply to an appointment request for a patient and/or practitioner(s), such as a confirmation or rejection
annotations.definition: A reply to an appointment request for a patient and/or practitioner(s), such as a confirmation or rejection.

binding.name: ParticipantStatus
binding.definition: The Participation status of an appointment

code.definition: The appointment participant has accepted that they can attend the appointment at the time specified in the AppointmentResponse.
The appointment participant has declined the appointment.
The appointment participant has tentatively accepted the appointment.
The participant has in-process the appointment.
The participant has completed the appointment.
This is the intitial status of an appointment participant until a participant has replied. It implies that there is no commitment for the appointment.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this appointment response concern that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate.

annotation.shortDefinition: Parent appointment that this response is replying to
annotation.definition: Parent appointment that this response is replying to.

annotation.shortDefinition: Role of participant in the appointment
annotation.definition: Role of participant in the appointment.

annotation.shortDefinition: A Person, Location/HealthcareService or Device that is participating in the appointment
annotation.definition: A Person, Location/HealthcareService or Device that is participating in the appointment.

annotation.shortDefinition: accepted | declined | tentative | in-process | completed | needs-action
annotation.definition: Participation status of the Participant. When the status is declined or tentative if the start/end times are different to the appointment, then these times should be interpreted as a requested time change. When the status is accepted, the times can either be the time of the appointment (as a confirmation of the time) or can be empty.
This comment is particularly important when the responder is declining, tentative or requesting another time to indicate the reasons why.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date/Time that the appointment is to take place, or requested new start time
annotation.definition: This may be either the same as the appointment request to confirm the details of the appointment, or alternately a new time to request a re-negotiation of the start time.
annotation.committeeNotes: Should we include the existing times, or rely on resource histories. Decision to wait for implementer feedback to see if these are used.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date/Time that the appointment is to conclude, or requested new end time
annotation.definition: This may be either the same as the appointment request to confirm the details of the appointment, or alternately a new time to request a re-negotiation of the end time.
annotation.committeeNotes: Should we include the existing times, or rely on resource histories. Decision to wait for implementer feedback to see if these are used.

search.name: partstatus
search.description: The participants acceptance status for this appointment

search.name: patient
search.description: This Response is for this Patient

search.name: practitioner
search.description: This Response is for this Practitioner

search.name: location
search.description: This Response is for this Location

search.name: actor
search.description: The Person, Location/HealthcareService or Device that this appointment response replies for

search.name: appointment
search.description: The appointment that the response is attached to

annotations.shortDefinition: Event record kept for security purposes
annotations.definition: A record of an event made for purposes of maintaining a security log. Typical uses include detection of intrusion attempts and monitoring for inappropriate usage.
annotations.comment: Based on ATNA (RFC 3881).

annotations.definition: A nested type in AuditEvent: Logical network location for application activity, if the activity has a network location.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifier for the network access point of the user device
annotation.definition: An identifier for the network access point of the user device for the audit event.
annotation.comment: This could be a device id, IP address or some other identifier associated with a device.
annotation.requirements: This datum identifies the user's network access point, which may be distinct from the server that performed the action. It is an optional value that may be used to group events recorded on separate servers for analysis of a specific network access point's data access across all servers.

annotation.shortDefinition: The type of network access point
annotation.definition: An identifier for the type of network access point that originated the audit event.
annotation.requirements: This datum identifies the type of network access point identifier of the user device for the audit event. It is an optional value that may be used to group events recorded on separate servers for analysis of access according to a network access point's type.

annotations.definition: A nested type in AuditEvent: Additional Information about the Object.

annotation.definition: Name of the property.
Property value.

annotations.definition: A nested type in AuditEvent: Specific instances of data or objects that have been accessed.

annotation.definition: Identifies a specific instance of the participant object. The reference should always be version specific.
annotation.comment: Identifier details depends on object type.

annotation.definition: Identifies a specific instance of the participant object. The reference should always be version specific.
Object type being audited.
annotation.comment: This value is distinct from the user's role or any user relationship to the participant object.
annotation.requirements: To describe the object being acted upon. In addition to queries on the subject of the action in an auditable event, it is also important to be able to query on the object type for the action.

annotation.definition: Code representing the functional application role of Participant Object being audited.
annotation.comment: See RFC 3881 for rules concerning matches between role and type.
annotation.requirements: For some detailed audit analysis it may be necessary to indicate a more granular type of participant, based on the application role it serves.
annotation.rimMapping: role.code (not sure what this would mean for an Act)

annotation.definition: Identifier for the data life-cycle stage for the participant object.
annotation.comment: This can be used to provide an audit trail for data, over time, as it passes through the system.
annotation.requirements: Institutional policies for privacy and security may optionally fall under different accountability rules based on data life cycle. This provides a differentiating value for those cases.

annotation.definition: Denotes policy-defined sensitivity for the Participant Object ID such as VIP, HIV status, mental health status or similar topics.
annotation.comment: Values from ATNA are institution- and implementation-defined text strings (in sensitivity.text). HL7 defines confidentiality codes for records, documents etc. that can also be used here.
annotation.requirements: This field identifies a specific instance of an object, such as a patient, to detect/track privacy and security issues.

annotation.definition: An instance-specific descriptor of the Participant Object ID audited, such as a person's name.
annotation.comment: This field may be used in a query/report to identify audit events for a specific person, e.g., where multiple synonymous Participant Object IDs (patient number, medical record number, encounter number, etc.) have been used.

annotation.definition: Text that describes the object in more detail.
The actual query for a query-type participant object.
annotation.requirements: For query events it may be necessary to capture the actual query input to the query process in order to identify the specific event. Because of differences among query implementations and data encoding for them, this is a base 64 encoded data blob. It may be subsequently decoded or interpreted by downstream audit analysis processing.

annotation.definition: Additional Information about the Object.

annotations.definition: A nested type in AuditEvent: A person, a hardware device or software process.

annotation.definition: Specification of the role(s) the user plays when performing the event. Usually the codes used in this element are local codes defined by the role-based access control security system used in the local context.
annotation.requirements: This value ties an audited event to a user's role(s). It is an optional value that might be used to group events for analysis by user functional role categories.

annotation.definition: Direct reference to a resource that identifies the participant.
annotation.requirements: This field ties an audit event to a specific resource.

annotation.definition: Unique identifier for the user actively participating in the event.
annotation.comment: a unique value within the Audit Source ID. For node-based authentication -- where only the system hardware or process, but not a human user, is identified -- User ID would be the node name.
annotation.requirements: This field ties an audit event to a specific user.

annotation.definition: Alternative Participant Identifier. For a human, this should be a user identifier text string from authentication system. This identifier would be one known to a common authentication system (e.g., single sign-on), if available.
annotation.requirements: In some situations a human user may authenticate with one identity but, to access a specific application system, may use a synonymous identify. For example, some "single sign on" implementations will do this. The alternative identifier would then be the original identify used for authentication, and the User ID is the one known to and used by the application.

annotation.definition: Human-meaningful name for the user.
annotation.requirements: The User ID and Authorization User ID may be internal or otherwise obscure values. This field assists the auditor in identifying the actual user.

annotation.definition: Indicator that the user is or is not the requestor, or initiator, for the event being audited.
annotation.comment: There can only be one initiator. If the initiator is not clear, then do not choose any one participant as the initiator.
annotation.requirements: This value is used to distinguish between requestor-users and recipient-users. For example, one person may initiate a report-output to be sent to another user.
annotation.rimMapping: If participation.typeCode was author, then true

annotation.definition: Where the event occurred.

The policy or plan that authorized the activity being recorded. Typically, a single activity may have multiple applicable policies, such as patient consent, guarantor funding, etc. The policy would also indicate the security token used.
annotation.comment: For example: Where an OAuth token authorizes, the unique identifier from the OAuth token is placed into the policy element Where a policy engine (e.g. XACML) holds policy logic, the unique policy identifier is placed into the policy element.
annotation.requirements: This value is used retrospectively to determine the authorization policies.

annotation.definition: Type of media involved. Used when the event is about exporting/importing onto media.
annotation.requirements: Usually, this is used instead of specifying a network address. This field is not used for Media Id (i.e. the serial number of a CD).
annotation.todo: Do we need an element for Media Id (as opposed to type).

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical network location for application activity
annotation.definition: Logical network location for application activity, if the activity has a network location.

annotations.definition: A nested type in AuditEvent: Identifies the name, action type, time, and disposition of the audited event.

annotation.definition: Identifier for a family of the event.
annotation.comment: e.g., a menu item, program, rule, policy, function code, application name or URL. It identifies the performed function.
annotation.requirements: This identifies the performed function. For "Execute" Event Action Code audit records, this identifies the application function performed.
annotation.rimMapping: .code (type, subtype and action are pre-coordinated or sent as translations)

annotation.shortDefinition: More specific type/id for the event
annotation.definition: Identifier for the category of event.
annotation.requirements: This field enables queries of messages by implementation-defined event categories.
annotation.rimMapping: .code (type, subtype and action are pre-coordinated or sent as translations)

annotation.shortDefinition: Type of action performed during the event
annotation.definition: Indicator for type of action performed during the event that generated the audit.
annotation.requirements: This broadly indicates what kind of action was done on the Participant Object.
annotation.rimMapping: .code (type, subtype and action are pre-coordinated or sent as translations)

annotation.shortDefinition: Time when the event occurred on source
annotation.definition: The time when the event occurred on the source.
annotation.comment: In a distributed system, some sort of common time base, e.g., an NTP [RFC1305] server, is a good implementation tactic.
annotation.requirements: This ties an event to a specific date and time. Security audits typically require a consistent time base, e.g., UTC, to eliminate time-zone issues arising from geographical distribution.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether the event succeeded or failed
annotation.definition: Indicates whether the event succeeded or failed.
annotation.comment: In some cases a "success" may be partial, for example, an incomplete or interrupted transfer of a radiological study. For the purpose of establishing accountability, these distinctions are not relevant.

annotation.definition: A free text description of the outcome of the event.

annotations.definition: A nested type in AuditEvent: Application systems and processes.

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical source location within the enterprise
annotation.definition: Logical source location within the healthcare enterprise network.
annotation.comment: a hospital or other provider location within a multi-entity provider group.
annotation.requirements: This value differentiates among the sites in a multi-site enterprise health information system.

annotation.shortDefinition: The id of source where event originated
annotation.definition: Identifier of the source where the event originated.
annotation.requirements: This field ties the event to a specific source system. It may be used to group events for analysis according to where the event occurred.

annotation.shortDefinition: The type of source where event originated
annotation.definition: Code specifying the type of source where event originated.
annotation.requirements: This field indicates which type of source is identified by the Audit Source ID. It is an optional value that may be used to group events for analysis according to the type of source where the event occurred.

binding.name: AuditEventObjectRole
binding.definition: Code representing the functional application role of Participant Object being audited

code.definition: This object is the patient that is the subject of care related to this event. It is identifiable by patient ID or equivalent. The patient may be either human or animal.

This is a location identified as related to the event. This is usually the location where the event took place. Note that for shipping, the usual events are arrival at a location or departure from a location.

This object is any kind of persistent document created as a result of the event. This could be a paper report, film, electronic report, DICOM Study, etc. Issues related to medical records life cycle management are conveyed elsewhere.
A logical object related to the event. (Deprecated).
This is any configurable file used to control creation of documents. Examples include the objects maintained by the HL7 Master File transactions, Value Sets, etc.
A human participant not otherwise identified by some other category.

Typically a licensed person who is providing or performing care related to the event, generally a physician. The key distinction between doctor and practitioner is with regards to their role, not the licensing. The doctor is the human who actually performed the work. The practitioner is the human or organization that is responsible for the work.
A person or system that is being notified as part of the event. This is relevant in situations where automated systems provide notifications to other parties when an event took place.
Insurance company, or any other organization who accepts responsibility for paying for the healthcare event.
A person or active system object involved in the event with a security role.
A person or system object involved in the event with the authority to modify security roles of other objects.
A passive object, such as a role table, that is relevant to the event.
(deprecated) Relevant to certain RBAC security methodologies.

Any person or organization responsible for providing care. This encompasses all forms of care, licensed or otherwise, and all sorts of teams and care groups. Note, the distinction between practitioners and the doctor that actually provided the care to the patient.
The source or destination for data transfer, when it does not match some other role.
A source or destination for data transfer, that acts as an archive, database, or similar role.
An object that holds schedule information. This could be an appointment book, availability information, etc.
An organization or person that is the recipient of services. This could be an organization that is buying services for a patient, or a person that is buying services for an animal.
An order, task, work item, procedure step, or other description of work to be performed. E.g., a particular instance of an MPPS.
A list of jobs or a system that provides lists of jobs. E.g., an MWL SCP.
An object that specifies or controls the routing or delivery of items. For example, a distribution list is the routing criteria for mail. The items delivered may be documents, jobs, or other objects.
The contents of a query. This is used to capture the contents of any kind of query. For security surveillance purposes knowing the queries being made is very important.

binding.name: AuditEventObjectLifecycle
binding.definition: Identifier for the data life-cycle stage for the participant object

code.definition: Origination / Creation.
Import / Copy from original.
Access / Use.
Aggregation, summarization, derivation.
Export / Copy to target.
Receipt of disclosure.
Logical deletion.
Permanent erasure / Physical destruction.

binding.name: AuditEventAction
binding.definition: Indicator for type of action performed during the event that generated the audit.

code.definition: Create a new database object, such as Placing an Order.
Display or print data, such as a Doctor Census.
Update data, such as Revise Patient Information.
Delete items, such as a doctor master file record.
Perform a system or application function such as log-on, program execution or use of an object's method, or perform a query/search operation.

binding.name: AuditEventObjectType
binding.definition: Code for the participant object type being audited

code.definition: System Object.

binding.name: AuditEventType
binding.definition: Type of event

binding.name: AuditEventSourceType
binding.definition: Code specifying the type of source where event originated

binding.name: AuditEventOutcome
binding.definition: Indicates whether the event succeeded or failed

code.definition: The operation completed successfully (whether with warnings or not).
The action was not successful due to some kind of catered for error (often equivalent to an HTTP 400 response).
The action was not successful due to some kind of unexpected error (often equivalent to an HTTP 500 response).
An error of such magnitude occurred that the system is not longer available for use (i.e. the system died).

binding.name: AuditEventObjectSensitivity
binding.definition: The sensitivity of an object in a audit event resource. May also encompass confidentiality and rudimentary access control

binding.name: AuditEventParticipantNetworkType
binding.definition: The type of network access point that originated the audit event

code.definition: Machine Name, including DNS name.
IP Address.
Telephone Number.
Email address.
URI (User directory, HTTP-PUT, ftp, etc.).

binding.name: DICOMRoleId
binding.definition: Role(s) the user plays (from RBAC)

binding.name: AuditEventSubType
binding.definition: Sub-type of event

annotation.definition: Identifies the name, action type, time, and disposition of the audited event.
annotation.requirements: The event must be identified.

annotation.shortDefinition: A person, a hardware device or software process
annotation.definition: A person, a hardware device or software process.
annotation.comment: There may be more than one user per event, for example, in cases of actions initiated by one user for other users, or in events that involve more than one user, hardware device, or system process. However, only one user may be the initiator/requestor for the event.
annotation.requirements: The event has one or more active participants.

annotation.definition: Application systems and processes.
annotation.comment: Since multi-tier, distributed, or composite applications make source identification ambiguous, this collection of fields may repeat for each application or process actively involved in the event. For example, multiple value-sets can identify participating web servers, application processes, and database server threads in an n-tier distributed application. Passive event participants, e.g., low-level network transports, need not be identified.
annotation.requirements: The event is reported by one source.

annotation.shortDefinition: Specific instances of data or objects that have been accessed
annotation.definition: Specific instances of data or objects that have been accessed.
annotation.comment: required unless the values for Event Identification, Active Participant Identification, and Audit Source Identification are sufficient to document the entire auditable event. Because events may have more than one participant object, this group can be a repeating set of values.
annotation.requirements: The event may have other objects involved.

search.name: site
search.description: Logical source location within the enterprise

search.name: desc
search.description: Instance-specific descriptor for Object

search.name: type
search.description: Type/identifier of event

search.name: date
search.description: Time when the event occurred on source

search.name: reference
search.description: Specific instance of resource (e.g. versioned)

search.name: identity
search.description: Specific instance of object (e.g. versioned)

search.name: patient
search.description: A patient that the .object.reference refers to

search.name: altid
search.description: Alternative User id e.g. authentication

search.name: patientid
search.description: The id of the patient (one of multiple kinds of participations)

search.name: source
search.description: The id of source where event originated

search.name: address
search.description: Identifier for the network access point of the user device

search.name: subtype
search.description: More specific type/id for the event

search.name: name
search.description: Human-meaningful name for the user

search.name: action
search.description: Type of action performed during the event

search.name: participant
search.description: Direct reference to resource

search.name: policy
search.description: Policy that authorized event

search.name: object-type
search.description: Object type being audited

search.name: user
search.description: Unique identifier for the user

annotations.shortDefinition: Resource for non-supported content
annotations.definition: Basic is used for handling concepts not yet defined in FHIR, narrative-only resources that don't map to an existing resource, and custom resources not appropriate for inclusion in the FHIR specification.
annotations.requirements: Need some way to safely (without breaking interoperability) allow implementers to exchange content not supported by the initial set of declared resources.

binding.name: BasicResourceType
binding.description: HL7-maintained set of codes for "Basic" resources
binding.definition: Codes for identifying types of resources not yet defined by FHIR

annotation.definition: Identifier assigned to the resource for business purposes, outside the context of FHIR.
Identifies the 'type' of resource - equivalent to the resource name for other resources.
annotation.comment: Because resource references will only be able to indicate 'Basic', the type of reference will need to be specified in a Profile identified as part of the resource. Refer to the resource notes section for information on appropriate terminologies for this code.
annotation.requirements: Must be able to distinguish different types of "basic" resources.

annotation.definition: Identifies the patient, practitioner, device or any other resource that is the "focus" of this resoruce.
annotation.comment: Optional as not all resources potential resources will have subjects. Resources associated with multiple subjects can handle this via extension.
annotation.requirements: Needed for partitioning the resource by Patient.

annotation.definition: Indicates who was responsible for creating the resource instance.
annotation.requirements: Needed for partitioning the resource.

annotation.definition: Identifies when the resource was first created.
annotation.requirements: Allows ordering resource instances by time.

example.name: Referral
example.description: How 'basic' can be used for future resources - in this case referral

example.name: ClassModel
example.description: How 'Basic' can be used for essoteric resources - in this case, a UML class model

example.name: Narrative Example
example.description: A resource that uses all narrative features for testing rendering applications

search.name: author
search.description: Who created

search.name: patient
search.description: Identifies the

search.name: created
search.description: When created

search.name: subject
search.description: Identifies the

search.name: code
search.description: Kind of Resource

annotations.shortDefinition: Pure binary content defined by sime other format than FHIR
annotations.definition: A binary resource can contain any content, whether text, image, pdf, zip archive, etc.
annotations.comment:
Typically, Binary resources are used for handling content such as:
* CDA Documents (i.e. with XDS) * PDF Documents * Images (the Media resource is preferred for handling images, but not possible when the content is already binary - e.g. XDS).
annotations.requirements: There are situations where it is useful or required to handle pure binary content using the same framework as other resources.

annotation.definition: MimeType of the binary content represented as a standard MimeType (BCP 13).
The actual content, base64 encoded.
annotation.comment: If the content type is itself base64 encoding, then this will be base64 encoded twice - what is created by un-base64ing the content must be the specified content type.

search.name: contenttype
search.description: MimeType of the binary content

annotations.shortDefinition: Specific and identified anatomical location
annotations.definition: Record details about the anatomical location of a specimen or body part, including precise localisation information. This resource may be used when a coded concept does not provide the necessary detail needed for the use case.
A nested type in BodySite: The Specific and identified anatomical location.

annotation.definition: Named anatomical location - ideally would be coded where possible.
Specify lateraility of the anatomical location.
Identify the specific anatomical site out of multiple eg tenth rib; fourth vertebra; second toe.
Line describing the position of a vertical anatomical plane in the body.

annotations.definition: A nested type in BodySite: Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.

annotation.definition: Identified anatomical landmark from which to specify relative anatomical location.
Qualifier to identify which direction the anatomical location is in relation to the identified landmark.
Distance of location from the identified landmark.

binding.name: AnatomicPlane
binding.definition: Concepts describing anatomical plane in the body

binding.name: RelativeLocation
binding.definition: Concepts describing the relative locatiion in relation to an identified anatomical landmark

binding.name: Laterality
binding.definition: Specify lateraility of the anatomical location.

annotation.definition: Identifier for this instance of the anatomical location.
The Specific and identified anatomical location.

Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.
Description of anatomical location.
annotation.comment: This Description could include any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.

annotation.definition: Image or images used to identify a location.

search.name: name
search.description: Named anatomical location

annotations.shortDefinition: Contains a collection of resources
annotations.definition: A container for a collection of resources.
A nested type in Bundle: Additional information about how this entry should be processed as part of a transaction.

annotation.definition: The HTTP verb for this entry in either a update history, or a transaction/ transaction response.
A search URL for this resource that specifies how the resource is matched to an existing resource when processing a transaction (see transaction documentation).
If the ETag values match, return a 304 Not modified status. See the read/vread interaction documentation.
Only perform the operation if the Etag value matches. For more information, see the API section "Managing Resource Contention".
Only perform the operation if the last updated date matches. For more information, see the API section "Managing Resource Contention".
Instruct the server not to perform the create if a specified resource already exists. For further information, see "Conditional Create".

annotations.definition: A nested type in Bundle: Additional information about how this entry should be processed as part of a transaction.

annotation.definition: The status code returned by processing this entry.

annotation.shortDefinition: The location, if the operation returns a location
annotation.definition: The location header created by processing this operation.

annotation.shortDefinition: The etag for the resource (if relevant)
annotation.definition: The etag for the resource, it the operation for the entry produced a versioned resource.
annotation.comment: This has to match the version id in the header if a resource is included.

annotation.definition: The date/time that the resource was modified on the server.
annotation.comment: This has to match the same time in the meta header if a resource is included.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Bundle: Information about the search process that lead to the creation of this entry.

annotation.shortDefinition: match | include - why this is in the result set
annotation.definition: Why this entry is in the result set - whether it's included as a match or because of an _include requirement.
When searching, the server's search ranking score for the entry.
annotation.comment: Servers are not required to return a ranking score. 1 is most relevant, and 0 is least relevant. Often, search results are sorted by score, but the client may specify a different sort order.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Bundle: An entry in a bundle resource - will either contain a resource, or information about a resource (transactions and history only).

annotation.shortDefinition: Base URL, if different to bundle base
annotation.definition: The Base URL for the resource, if different to the base URL specified for the bundle as a whole.
annotation.comment: This allows bundles to be composed of resources from multiple servers (collated search, documents etc).

annotation.definition: A series of links that provide context to this entry.
The Resources for the entry.
Information about the search process that lead to the creation of this entry.
Additional information about how this entry should be processed as part of a transaction.
Additional information about how this entry should be processed as part of a transaction.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Bundle: A series of links that provide context to this bundle.

annotation.definition: A name which details the functional use for this link - see [[http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml]].
The reference details for the link.

binding.name: HTTPVerb
binding.definition: HTTP verbs (in the HTTP command line)

code.definition: HTTP GET.
HTTP POST.
HTTP PUT.
HTTP DELETE.

binding.name: TransactionProcessingMode
binding.definition: Defines how a match URL should be used when processing a transaction

code.definition: If a matching resource is found, then ignore the resource and do not process it as part of the transaction (and return the matching resource information in the transaction response).
If a matching resource is found, then update it with this resource, otherwise create a new one.
If a resource matching the information provided is found, delete it. If no matching resource is found, the transaction fails.

binding.name: SearchEntryMode
binding.definition: Why an entry is in the result set - whether it's included as a match or because of an _include requirement

code.definition: This resource matched the search specification.
This resource is returned because it is referred to from another resource in the search set.

binding.name: BundleType
binding.definition: Indicates the purpose of a bundle- how it was intended to be used

code.definition: The bundle is a document. The first resource is a Composition.
The bundle is a message. The first resource is a MessageHeader.
The bundle is a transaction - intended to be processed by a server as an atomic commit.
The bundle is a transaction response.
The bundle is a list of resources from a _history interaction on a server.
The bundle is a list of resources returned as a result of a search/query interaction, operation, or message.
The bundle is a set of resources collected into a single document for ease of distribution.

binding.name: TransactionOperation
binding.definition: The operation associated with an entry in either a update history, or a transaction/ transaction response

code.definition: No Operation occurred - only valid in a transaction response.

annotation.shortDefinition: document | message | transaction | transaction-response | history | searchset | collection
annotation.definition: Indicates the purpose of this bundle- how it was intended to be used.
annotation.comment: It's possible to use a bundle for other purposes (e.g. a document can be accepted as a transaction). This is primarily defined so that there can be specific rules for some of the bundle types.

annotation.definition: The base URL for the service that provided these resources. All relative URLs are relative to this one (equivalent to xml:base).

annotation.shortDefinition: If search, the total number of matches
annotation.definition: If a set of search matches, this is the total number of matches for the search (as opposed to the number of results in this bundle).
annotation.comment: Only used if the bundle is a search result set.

annotation.definition: A series of links that provide context to this bundle.

annotation.shortDefinition: Entry in the bundle - will have a resource, or information
annotation.definition: An entry in a bundle resource - will either contain a resource, or information about a resource (transactions and history only).
XML Digital Signature - base64 encoded.
annotation.comment: This is base 64 encoded to address issues with json/xml.

invariant.name: bdl-2
invariant.human: entry.search only when a search

invariant.name: bdl-1
invariant.human: total only when a search or history

invariant.name: bdl-3
invariant.human: entry.transaction when (and only when) a transaction

invariant.name: bdl-4
invariant.human: entry.transactionResponse when (and only when) a transaction-response

example.name: search
example.description: An example of a search response

search.name: message
search.description: The first resource in the bundle, if the bundle type is "message" - this is a message header, and this parameter provides access to search its contents

search.name: composition
search.description: The first resource in the bundle, if the bundle type is "document" - this is a composition, and this parameter provides access to searches its contents

search.name: type
search.description: document | message | transaction | transaction-response | history | searchset | collection

annotations.shortDefinition: Healthcare plan for patient
annotations.definition: Describes the intention of how one or more practitioners intend to deliver care for a particular patient for a period of time, possibly limited to care for a specific condition or set of conditions.
annotations.committeeNotes: At present, this resource combines the concepts of CarePlan and CareTeam. Should they be split?

annotations.definition: A nested type in CarePlan: Describes the intended objective(s) of carrying out the Care Plan.

annotation.definition: Human-readable description of a specific desired objective of the care plan.
annotation.requirements: Without a description of what's trying to be achieved, element has no purpose.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether the goal has been reached and is still considered relevant.
annotation.requirements: Allows measuring outcome and also indicates relevance of goal to plan.
annotation.rimMapping: .statusCode in-progress = active (classCode = OBJ) achieved = complete sustaining = active (classCode=OBJC) cancelled = aborted

annotation.definition: Any comments related to the goal.
annotation.comment: May be used for progress notes, concerns or other related information that doesn't actually describe the goal itself.
annotation.requirements: There's a need to capture information about the goal that doesn't actually describe the goal.

annotation.definition: The identified conditions that this goal relates to - the condition that caused it to be created, or that it is intended to address.
annotation.comment: The concerns do not also need to be listed under CarePlan.concern, but may be.
annotation.requirements: Allows specific goals to explicitly linked to conditions - makes the plan more understandable.

annotations.definition: A nested type in CarePlan: Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care envisioned by this plan.

annotation.definition: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care plan. E.g. "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.
annotation.comment: Roles may sometimes be inferred by type of Practitioner. These are relationships that hold only within the context of the care plan. General relationships should be handled as properties of the Patient resource directly.

annotation.definition: The specific person or organization who is participating/expected to participate in the care plan.
annotation.comment: Patient only needs to be listed if they have a role other than "subject of care".
annotation.v2Mapping: REL.5 (or PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {provider participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {non-provider person participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 = (patient non-subject of care) ) / PRT-8-participation organization?)

annotations.definition: A nested type in CarePlan: Identifies a planned action to occur as part of the plan. For example, a medication to be used, lab tests to perform, self-monitoring, education, etc.

annotation.definition: Internal reference that identifies the goals that this activity is intended to contribute towards meeting.
annotation.requirements: So that participants know the link explicitly.

annotation.shortDefinition: not-started | scheduled | in-progress | on-hold | completed | cancelled
annotation.definition: Identifies what progress is being made for the specific activity.
annotation.comment: Some aspects of Status can be inferred based on the resources linked in actionTaken. Note that "status" is only as current as the plan was most recently updated.
annotation.requirements: Indicates progress against the plan, whether the activity is still relevant for the plan.
annotation.rimMapping: .statusCode not-started = new scheduled = not-started (and fulfillment relationship to appointent) in-progress = active on-hold = suspended completed = completed cancelled = aborted

annotation.definition: If true, indicates that the described activity is one that must NOT be engaged in when following the plan.
annotation.requirements: Captures intention to not do something that may have been previously typical.

annotation.definition: Resources that describe follow-on actions resulting from the plan, such as drug prescriptions, encounter records, appointments, etc.
annotation.requirements: Links plan to resulting actions.

annotation.definition: Notes about the execution of the activity.
annotation.comment: Doesn't describe the activity - that goes in details.
annotation.requirements: Can be used to capture information about adherence, progress, concerns, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Activity details defined in specific resource
annotation.definition: The details of the proposed activity represented in a specific resource.
annotation.requirements: Details in a form consistent with other applications and contexts of use.

annotation.definition: A simple summary of details suitable for a general care plan system (e.g. form driven) that doesn't know about specific resources such as procedure etc.
annotation.requirements: Details in a simple form for generic care plan systems.

annotations.definition: A nested type in CarePlan: A simple summary of details suitable for a general care plan system (e.g. form driven) that doesn't know about specific resources such as procedure etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: diet | drug | encounter | observation | procedure | supply | other
annotation.definition: High-level categorization of the type of activity in a care plan.
annotation.requirements: May determine what types of extensions are permitted.
annotation.committeeNotes: Should this be an HL7-defined code? Do we need more (e.g. accommodation).

annotation.definition: Detailed description of the type of activity. E.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.
annotation.comment: Tends to be less relevant for activities involving particular products. Codes should not convey negation - use "prohibited" instead.
annotation.requirements: Allows matching performed to planned as well as validation against protocols.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR-4-universal service ID / RXE-2-Give Code / RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code

annotation.definition: The period, timing or frequency upon which the described activity is to occur.
annotation.requirements: Allows prompting for activities and detection of missed planned activities.

annotation.definition: Identifies the facility where the activity will occur. E.g. home, hospital, specific clinic, etc.
annotation.comment: May reference a specific clinical location or may just identify a type of location.
annotation.requirements: Helps in planning of activity.

annotation.definition: Identifies who's expected to be involved in the activity.
annotation.comment: A performer MAY also be a participant in the care plan.
annotation.requirements: Helps in planning of activity.
annotation.v2Mapping: PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {provider participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {non-provider person participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 = (patient non-subject of care) ) / PRT-8-participation organization

annotation.definition: Identifies the food, drug or other product being consumed or supplied in the activity.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXE-2-Give Code / RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code

annotation.definition: Identifies the quantity expected to be consumed in a given day.
annotation.requirements: Allows rough dose checking.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXO-23-total daily dose / RXE-19-total daily dose / RXD-12-total daily dose

annotation.definition: Identifies the quantity expected to be supplied.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXO-11-requested dispense amount / RXE-10-dispense amount / RXD-4-actual dispense amount / RXG-5-give amount-minumum / RXA-6-administered amount / TQ1-2.1-quantity.quantity *and* RXO-12-requested dispense units / RXE-11-dispense units / RXD-5-actual dispense units / RXG-7-give units / RXA-7-administered units / TQ1-2.2-quantity.units

annotation.definition: This provides a textual description of constraints on the activity occurrence, including relation to other activities. It may also include objectives, pre-conditions and end-conditions. Finally, it may convey specifics about the activity such as body site, method, route, etc.

binding.name: CarePlanStatus
binding.definition: Indicates whether the plan is currently being acted upon, represents future intentions or is now just historical record.

code.definition: The plan is in development or awaiting use but is not yet intended to be acted upon.
The plan is intended to be followed and used as part of patient care.
The plan is no longer in use and is not expected to be followed or used in patient care.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityCategory
binding.definition: High-level categorization of the type of activity in a care plan.

code.definition: Plan for the patient to consume food of a specified nature.
Plan for the patient to consume/receive a drug, vaccine or other product.
Plan to meet or communicate with the patient (in-patient, out-patient, phone call, etc.).
Plan to capture information about a patient (vitals, labs, diagnostic images, etc.).
Plan to modify the patient in some way (surgery, physiotherapy, education, counseling, etc.).
Plan to provide something to the patient (medication, medical supply, etc.).
Some other form of action.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityType
binding.definition: Detailed description of the type of activity. E.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.

binding.name: CarePlanGoalStatus
binding.definition: Indicates whether the goal has been met and is still being targeted

code.definition: The goal is being sought but has not yet been reached. (Also applies if goal was reached in the past but there has been regression and goal is being sought again).
The goal has been met and no further action is needed.
The goal has been met, but ongoing activity is needed to sustain the goal objective.
The goal is no longer being sought.

binding.name: CarePlanParticipantRole
binding.definition: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care plan. E.g. "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityStatus
binding.definition: Indicates where the activity is at in its overall life cycle

code.definition: Activity is planned but no action has yet been taken.
Appointment or other booking has occurred but activity has not yet begun.
Activity has been started but is not yet complete.
Activity was started but has temporarily ceased with an expectation of resumption at a future time.
The activities have been completed (more or less) as planned.
The activities have been ended prior to completion (perhaps even before they were started).

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this care plan that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
annotation.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.

annotation.definition: Identifies the patient/subject whose intended care is described by the plan.
annotation.requirements: Care plans are associated with the patient the plan is for.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether the plan is currently being acted upon, represents future intentions or is now just historical record.
annotation.requirements: Allows clinicians to determine whether the plan is actionable or not.
annotation.rimMapping: .statusCode planned = new active = active completed = completed

annotation.definition: Indicates when the plan did (or is intended to) come into effect and end.
annotation.comment: Any activities scheduled as part of the plan should be constrained to the specified period.
annotation.requirements: Allows tracking what plan(s) are in effect at a particular time.
annotation.v2Mapping: GOL-7-goal established date/time / GOL-8-expected goal achieve date/time

annotation.definition: Identifies the most recent date on which the plan has been revised.
annotation.requirements: Indicates how current the plan is.
annotation.v2Mapping: PTH-6-change pathway life cycle status date/time
annotation.committeeNotes: Do we need this in addition to the resource metadata which tracks last changed?

annotation.definition: Identifies the conditions/problems/concerns/diagnoses/etc. whose management and/or mitigation are handled by this plan.
annotation.requirements: Links plan to the conditions it manages. Also scopes plans - multiple plans may exist addressing different concerns.

annotation.definition: Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care envisioned by this plan.
annotation.requirements: Allows representation of care teams, helps scope care plan. In some cases may be a determiner of access permissions.
annotation.v2Mapping: REL (REL.4 is always the Patient) ( or PRT?)

annotation.definition: Describes the intended objective(s) of carrying out the Care Plan.
annotation.comment: Goal can be achieving a particular change or merely maintaining a current state or even slowing a decline.
annotation.requirements: Provides context for plan. Allows plan effectiveness to be evaluated by clinicians.
annotation.committeeNotes: Should this be expanded into code + value + timeframe?

annotation.shortDefinition: Action to occur as part of plan
annotation.definition: Identifies a planned action to occur as part of the plan. For example, a medication to be used, lab tests to perform, self-monitoring, education, etc.
annotation.requirements: Allows systems to prompt for performance of planned activities, validate plans against best practice.

annotation.definition: General notes about the care plan not covered elsewhere.
annotation.requirements: Used to capture information that applies to the plan as a whole that doesn't fit into discrete elements.

example.name: Integrated
example.description: Simple integrated care plan with multiple goals & conditions (from Mayo)

search.description: Activity details defined in specific resource

search.description: Specified date occurs within period specified by CarePlan.activity.timingSchedule

annotation.comment: Roles may sometimes be inferred by type of Practitioner. These are relationships that hold only within the context of the care plan. General relationships should be handled as properties of the Patient resource directly.

annotation.definition: The specific person or organization who is participating/expected to participate in the care plan.
annotation.comment: Patient only needs to be listed if they have a role other than "subject of care".

annotations.shortDefinition: Claim, Pre-determination or Pre-authorization
annotations.definition: A provider issued list of services and products provided, or to be provided, to a patient which is provided to an insurer for payment recovery.
A nested type in Claim: First tier of goods and services.

annotation.definition: A service line number.

annotation.shortDefinition: Group or type of product or service
annotation.definition: The type of product or service.
The practitioner who is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.
Diagnosis applicable for this service or product line.
If a grouping item then 'GROUP' otherwise it is a node therefore a code to indicate the Professional Service or Product supplied.
The date when the enclosed suite of services were performed or completed.
The number of repetitions of a service or product.

annotation.shortDefinition: Fee, charge or cost per point
annotation.definition: If the item is a node then this is the fee for the product or service, otherwise this is the total of the fees for the children of the group.

A real number that represents a multiplier used in determining the overall value of services delivered and/or goods received. The concept of a Factor allows for a discount or surcharge multiplier to be applied to a monetary amount.
annotation.requirements: If a fee is present the associated product/service code must be present.

annotation.definition: An amount that expresses the weighting (based on difficulty, cost and/or resource intensiveness) associated with the good or service delivered. The concept of Points allows for assignment of point values for services and/or goods, such that a monetary amount can be assigned to each point.
annotation.requirements: If a fee is present the associated product/service code must be present.

annotation.definition: The quantity times the unit price for an addittional service or product or charge. For example, the formula: unit Quantity * unit Price (Cost per Point) * factor Number * points = net Amount. Quantity, factor and points are assumed to be 1 if not supplied.
annotation.requirements: If a fee is present the associated product/service code must be present.

annotation.definition: List of Unique Device Identifiers associated with this line item.
annotation.requirements: The UDI code and issuer if applicable for the supplied product.

annotation.definition: Physical service site on the patient (limb, tooth, etc).
A region or surface of the site, eg. limb region or tooth surface(s).
Item typification or modifiers codes, eg for Oral whether the treatment is cosmetic or associated with TMJ, or an appliance was lost or stolen.
annotation.requirements: May impact on adjudication.

annotation.definition: Second tier of goods and services.
The materials and placement date of prior fixed prosthesis.

Complete (Bill or Claim), Proposed (Pre-Authorization), Exploratory (Pre-determination).
Immediate (STAT), best effort (NORMAL), deferred (DEFER).

In the case of a Pre-Determination/Pre-Authorization the provider may request that funds in the amount of the expected Benefit be reserved ('Patient' or 'Provider') to pay for the Benefits determined on the subsequent claim(s). 'None' explicitly indicates no funds reserving is requested.
