annotations.definition: A nested type in ClaimResponse: The second tier service adjudications for submitted services.

annotation.definition: A service line number.
The adjudications results.
The third tier service adjudications for submitted services.

binding.name: RemittanceOutcome
binding.definition: The outcome of the processing.

code.definition: The processing completed without errors.
The processing identified with errors.

binding.name: AdjudicationError
binding.definition: The error codes for adjudication processing

binding.name: Adjudication
binding.definition: The adjudication codes

binding.name: Forms
binding.definition: The forms codes

binding.name: AdjustmentReason
binding.definition: Adjustment reason codes

binding.name: NoteType
binding.definition: The presentation types of notes

code.definition: Display the note.
Print the note on the form.
Print the note for the operator.

annotation.definition: The Response Business Identifier.
Original request resource referrence.
The version of the style of resource contents. This should be mapped to the allowable profiles for this and supporting resources.
The style (standard) and version of the original material which was converted into this resource.
annotation.requirements: Knowledge of the original version can inform the processing of this instance so that information which is processable by the originating system may be generated.

annotation.definition: The date when the enclosed suite of services were performed or completed.
The Insurer who produced this adjudicated response.
The practitioner who is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.
The organization which is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.
Transaction status: error, complete.
A description of the status of the adjudication.

annotation.shortDefinition: Party to be paid any benefits payable
annotation.definition: Party to be reimbursed: Subscriber, provider, other.
The first tier service adjudications for submitted services.
The first tier service adjudications for payor added services.
Mutually exclusive with Services Provided (Item).

annotation.shortDefinition: Total Cost of service from the Claim
annotation.definition: The total cost of the services reported.
annotation.requirements: This is a check value that the receiver calculates and returns.

annotation.definition: The amount of deductable applied which was not allocated to any particular service line.

annotation.shortDefinition: Total benefit payable for the Claim
annotation.definition: Total amount of benefit payable (Equal to sum of the Benefit amounts from all detail lines and additions less the Unallocated Deductable).
Adjustment to the payment of this transaction which is not related to adjudication of this transaction.
Reason for the payment adjustment.
Estimated payment data.
Payable less any payment adjustment.
Payment identifer.
Status of funds reservation (For provider, for Patient, None).
The form to be used for printing the content.
Note text.
Financial instrument by which payment information for health care.
annotation.requirements: Health care programs and insurers are significant payors of health service costs.

search.name: identifier
search.description: The identity of the insurer

annotations.shortDefinition: A clinical assessment performed when planning treatments and management strategies for a patient
annotations.definition: A record of a clinical assessment performed to determine what problem(s) may affect the patient and before planning the treatments or management strategies that are best to manage a patient's condition. Assessments are often 1:1 with a clinical consultation / encounter, but this varies greatly depending on the clinical workflow. This resource is called "ClinicalImpression" rather than "ClinicalAssessment" to avoid confusion with the recording of assessment tools such as Apgar score.

A nested type in ClinicalImpression: One or more sets of investigations (signs, symptions, etc). The actual grouping of investigations vary greatly depending on the type and context of the assessment. These investigations may include data generated during the assessment process, or data previously generated and recorded that is pertinent to the outcomes.

annotation.definition: A name/code for the group ("set") of investigations. Typically, this will be something like "signs", "symptoms", "clinical", "diagnostic", but the list is not constrained, and others such groups such as (exposure|family|travel|nutitirional) history may be used.
A record of a specific investigation that was undertaken.
annotation.comment: Most investigations are observations of one kind of or another but some other specific types of data collection resources can also be used.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ClinicalImpression: Specific findings or diagnoses that was considered likely or relevant to ongoing treatment.

annotation.shortDefinition: Specific text or code for finding
annotation.definition: Specific text of code for finding or diagnosis.
Which investigations support finding or diagnosis.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ClinicalImpression: Diagnosis considered not possible.

annotation.shortDefinition: Specific text of code for diagnosis
annotation.definition: Specific text of code for diagnosis.
Grounds for elimination.

binding.name: ClinicalFindings
binding.definition: Clinical Findings that may cause an clinical evaluation

binding.name: investigationGroupType
binding.definition: A name/code for a set of investigations

annotation.definition: The patient being asssesed.
The clinician performing the assessment.
The point in time at which the assessment was concluded (not when it was recorded).
annotation.comment: This SHOULD be accurate to at least the minute, though some assessments only have a known date.

annotation.definition: A summary of the context and/or cause of the assessment - why / where was it peformed, and what patient events/sstatus prompted it.

A reference to the last assesment that was conducted bon this patient. Assessments are often/usually ongoing in nature; a care provider (practitioner or team) will make new assessments on an ongoing basis as new data arises or the patient's conditions changes.
annotation.comment: It is always likely that multiple previous assessments exist for a patient. The point of quoting a previous assessment is that this assessment is relative to it (see resolved).

annotation.definition: This a list of the general problems/conditions for a patient.
annotation.comment: e.g. The patient is a pregnant, and cardiac congestive failure, ‎Adenocarcinoma, and is allergic to penicillin.

annotation.shortDefinition: Request or event that necessitated this assessment
annotation.definition: The request or event that necessitated this assessment. This may be a diagnosis, a Care Plan, a Request Referral, or some other resource.

annotation.shortDefinition: One or more sets of investigations (signs, symptions, etc)
annotation.definition: One or more sets of investigations (signs, symptions, etc). The actual grouping of investigations vary greatly depending on the type and context of the assessment. These investigations may include data generated during the assessment process, or data previously generated and recorded that is pertinent to the outcomes.
Reference to a specific published clinical protocol that was followed during this assessment, and/or that provides evidence in support of the diagnosis.
A text summary of the investigations and the diagnosis.

annotation.shortDefinition: Possible or likely findings and diagnoses
annotation.definition: Specific findings or diagnoses that was considered likely or relevant to ongoing treatment.
Diagnoses/conditions resolved since the last assessment.
Diagnosis considered not possible.
Estimate of likely outcome.
Plan of action after assessment.
Actions taken during assessment.

search.name: assessor
search.description: The clinician performing the assessment

search.name: trigger
search.description: Request or event that necessitated this assessment

search.name: patient
search.description: The patient being asssesed

search.name: plan
search.description: Plan of action after assessment

search.name: resolved
search.description: Diagnosies/conditions resolved since previous assessment

search.name: trigger-code
search.description: Request or event that necessitated this assessment

search.name: previous
search.description: Reference to last assessment

search.name: action
search.description: Actions taken during assessment

search.name: finding
search.description: Specific text or code for finding

search.name: investigation
search.description: Record of a specific investigation

search.name: problem
search.description: General assessment of patient state

search.name: date
search.description: When the assessment occurred

search.name: ruledout
search.description: Specific text of code for diagnosis

annotations.shortDefinition: A record of information transmitted from a sender to a receiver
annotations.definition: An occurrence of information being transmitted. E.g., an alert that was sent to a responsible provider, a public health agency was notified about a reportable condition.
A nested type in Communication: Text, attachment(s), or resource(s) to be communicated to the recipient.

annotation.definition: An individual message part for multi-part messages.

binding.name: CommunicationStatus
binding.definition: The status of the communication

code.definition: The communication transmission is ongoing.
The message transmission is complete, i.e., delivered to the recipient's destination.
The communication transmission has been held by originating system/user request.
The receiving system has declined to accept the message.
There was a failure in transmitting the message out.

annotation.definition: Identifiers associated with this Communication that are defined by business processes and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
The type of message such as alert, notification, reminder, instruction, etc.
The entity (e.g., person, organization, clinical information system, or device) which is the source of the communication.
The entity (e.g., person, organization, clinical information system, or device) which is the target of the communication.
Text, attachment(s), or resource(s) to be communicated to the recipient.
The communication medium, e.g., email, fax.
The status of the transmission.
The encounter within which the communication was sent.
The time when this communication was sent.
The time when this communication arrived at the destination.
The reason or justification for the communication.
The patient who is the focus of this communication.

example.name: Alert Message
example.description: An example of an alert message

search.name: sender
search.description: Message sender

search.name: sent
search.description: When sent

search.name: category
search.description: Message category

search.name: patient
search.description: Focus of message

search.name: status
search.description: in-progress | completed | suspended | rejected | failed

search.name: subject
search.description: Focus of message

search.name: received
search.description: When received

search.name: encounter
search.description: Encounter leading to message

search.name: identifier
search.description: Unique identifier

search.name: medium
search.description: Communication medium

search.name: recipient
search.description: Message recipient

annotations.shortDefinition: A request for information to be sent to a receiver
annotations.definition: A request to convey information. E.g., the CDS system proposes that an alert be sent to a responsible provider, the CDS system proposes that the public health agency be notified about a reportable condition.
A nested type in CommunicationRequest: Text, attachment(s), or resource(s) to be communicated to the recipient.

annotation.definition: An individual message part for multi-part messages.

binding.name: CommunicationRequestStatus
binding.definition: The status of the communication

code.definition: The request has been proposed.
The request has been planned.
The request has been placed.
The receiving system has received the request but not yet decided whether it will be performed.
The receiving system has accepted the order, but work has not yet commenced.
The work to fulfill the order is happening.
The work has been complete, the report(s) released, and no further work is planned.
The request has been held by originating system/user request.
The receiving system has declined to fulfill the request.
The communication was attempted, but due to some procedural error, it could not be completed.

annotation.definition: A unique ID of this request for reference purposes. It must be provided if user wants it returned as part of any output, otherwise it will be auto-generated, if needed, by CDS system. Does not need to be the actual ID of the source system.
The type of message such as alert, notification, reminder, instruction, etc.
The entity (e.g., person, organization, clinical information system, or device) which is the source of the communication.
The entity (e.g., person, organization, clinical information system, or device) which is the intended target of the communication.
Text, attachment(s), or resource(s) to be communicated to the recipient.
The communication medium, e.g., email, fax.

The responsible person who authorizes this order, e.g., physician. This may be different than the author of the order statement, e.g., clerk, who may have entered the statement into the order entry application.

annotation.shortDefinition: proposed | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | completed | suspended | rejected | failed
annotation.definition: The status of the proposal or order.
The encounter within which the communication request was created.
The time when this communication is to occur.
The reason or justification for the communication request.
The time when the request was made.
The patient who is the focus of this communication request.
Characterizes how quickly the proposed act must be initiated. Includes concepts such as stat, urgent, routine.

example.description: An example of an alert message

search.description: Message urgency

annotations.shortDefinition: A set of resources composed into a single coherent clinical statement with clinical attestation
annotations.definition: A set of healthcare-related information that is assembled together into a single logical document that provides a single coherent statement of meaning, establishes its own context and that has clinical attestation with regard to who is making the statement.
annotations.comment: While the focus of this specification is on patient-specific clinical statements, this resource can also apply to other healthcare-related statements such as study protocol designs, healthcare invoices and other activities that are not necessarily patient-specific or clinical.
annotations.requirements: To support documents, and also to capture the EN13606 notion of an attested commit to the patient EHR, and to allow a set of disparate resources at the information/engineering level to be gathered into a clinical statement.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Composition: The root of the sections that make up the composition.

annotation.definition: The label for this particular section. This will be part of the rendered content for the document, and is often used to build a table of contents.
annotation.comment: The title identifies the section for a human reader. The title must be consistent with the narrative of the resource that is the target of the section.content reference.
annotation.requirements: Section headings are often standardized for different types of documents. They give guidance to humans on how the document is organized.

annotation.definition: A code identifying the kind of content contained within the section. This must be consistent with the section title.
annotation.comment:
The code identifies the section for an automated processor of the document. This is particularly relevant when using profiles to control the structure of the document.
If the section has content (instead of sub-sections), the section.code does not change the meaning or interpretation of the resource that is the content of the section in the comments for the section.code.
annotation.requirements: Provides computable standardized labels to topics within the document.

annotation.definition: A nested sub-section within this section.
annotation.comment: Nested sections are primarily used to help human readers navigate to particular portions of the document.

annotation.shortDefinition: The Content of the section (narrative + data entries)
annotation.definition: The content (narrative and data entries) associated with the section.
annotation.comment: Because composition represent point-in-time snapshots, resource references should either be to a specific version, or made against resources on the same server with full version tracking, so that the correct versions can easily be assembled.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Composition: The clinical service, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code(s) that apply to the event being documented
annotation.definition: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the typeCode, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
annotation.comment: An event can further specialize the act inherent in the typeCode, such as where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more eventCodes are included, they SHALL NOT conflict with the values inherent in the classCode, practiceSettingCode or typeCode, as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation. This short list of codes is provided to be used as ???key words??? for certain types of queries.

annotation.shortDefinition: The period covered by the documentation
annotation.definition: The period of time covered by the documentation. There is no assertion that the documentation is a complete representation for this period, only that it documents events during this time.

annotation.shortDefinition: Full details for the event(s) the composition consents
annotation.definition: Full details for the event(s) the composition/documentation consents.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Composition: A participant who has attested to the accuracy of the composition/document.

annotation.definition: The type of attestation the authenticator offers.
annotation.comment: Use more than one code where a single attester has more than one mode (professional and legal are often paired).
annotation.requirements: Indicates the level of officialness of the attestation.

annotation.definition: When composition was attested by the party.
annotation.requirements: Identifies when the information in the composition was deemed accurate. (Things may have changed since then.).

annotation.definition: Who attested the composition in the specified way.
annotation.requirements: Identifies who has taken on the responsibility for accuracy of the composition content.
annotation.rimMapping: ./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and isNormalEntity()] or ./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole and not(player)]/scoper[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="ORG" and isNormalEntity()]

binding.name: DocumentConfidentiality
binding.definition: Codes specifying the level of confidentiality of the composition

binding.name: CompositionSectionType
binding.definition: Classification of a section of a composition / document

binding.name: CompositionStatus
binding.definition: The workflow/clinical status of the composition

code.definition: This is a preliminary composition or document (also known as initial or interim). The content may be incomplete or unverified.
This version of the composition is complete and verified by an appropriate person and no further work is planned. Any subsequent updates would be on a new version of the composition.

The composition or document has been modified subsequent to being released as "final", and is complete and verified by an authorized person. The modifications added new information to the composition or document, but did not revise existing content.
The composition or document has been modified subsequent to being released as "final", and is complete and verified by an authorized person.
The composition or document was originally created/issued in error, and this is an amendment that marks that the entire series should not be considered as valid.

binding.name: DocumentType
binding.definition: Type of a composition

binding.name: CompositionAttestationMode
binding.definition: The way in which a person authenticated a composition

code.definition: The person authenticated the content in their personal capacity.
The person authenticated the content in their professional capacity.
The person authenticated the content and accepted legal responsibility for its content.
The organization authenticated the content as consistent with their policies and procedures.

binding.name: DocumentEventType
binding.definition: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts being documented

annotation.definition: Logical Identifier for the composition, assigned when created. This identifier stays constant as the composition is changed over time.
annotation.comment: See discussion in resource definition for how these relate.

annotation.definition: The composition editing time, when the composition was last logically changed by the author.
annotation.comment: The Last Modified Date on the composition may be after the date of the document was attested without being changed.
annotation.requirements: dateTime is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.

annotation.definition: Specifies the particular kind of composition (e.g. History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Progress Note). This usually equates to the purpose of making the composition.
annotation.requirements: Key metadata element describing the composition, used in searching/filtering.

annotation.definition: A categorization for the type of the composition. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the Composition Type.
annotation.requirements: Helps humans to assess whether the composition is of interest when viewing an index of compositions or documents.

annotation.definition: Official human-readable label for the composition.
annotation.comment: If compositions do not have a title, the text or a display name of Composition.type (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note") can be used in its place.

annotation.definition: The workflow/clinical status of this composition. The status is a marker for the clinical standing of the document.
annotation.comment: If a composition is marked as withdrawn, the compositions/documents in the series, or data from the composition or document series, should never be displayed to a user without being clearly marked as untrustworthy. The flag "withdrawn" is why this element is labeled as a modifier of other elements.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to mark interim, amended, or withdrawn compositions or documents.

annotation.definition: The code specifying the level of confidentiality of the Composition.
annotation.comment: The exact use of this element, and enforcement and issues related to highly sensitive documents are out of scope for the base specification, and delegated to implementation profiles (see security section).

annotation.shortDefinition: Who and/or what the composition is about
annotation.definition: Who or what the composition is about. The composition can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (I.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of livestock, or a set of patients that share a common exposure).
annotation.comment: For clinical documents, this is usually the patient.
annotation.requirements: Essential metadata for searching for the composition. Identifies who and/or what the composition/document is about.

annotation.shortDefinition: Who and/or what authored the composition
annotation.definition: Identifies who is responsible for the information in the composition. (Not necessarily who typed it in.).
annotation.requirements: Identifies who is responsible for the content.

annotation.definition: A participant who has attested to the accuracy of the composition/document.
annotation.comment: Only list each attester once.
annotation.requirements: Identifies responsibility for the accuracy of the composition content.

annotation.definition: Identifies the organization or group who is responsible for ongoing maintenance of and access to the composition/document information.
annotation.comment: This is useful when documents are derived from a composition - provides guidance for how to get the latest version of the document. This is optional because knowing this is sometimes not known by the authoring system, and can be inferred by context. However it's important that this information be known when working with a derived document, so providing a custodian is encouraged.
annotation.requirements: Identifies where to go to find the current version, where to report issues, etc.

annotation.definition: The clinical service, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented.
annotation.comment: The event needs to be consistent with the type element, though can provide further information if desired.
annotation.requirements: Provides context for the composition and creates a linkage between a resource describing an event and the composition created describing the event.

annotation.definition: Describes the clinical encounter or type of care this documentation is associated with.
annotation.requirements: Provides context for the composition and supports searching.
annotation.rimMapping: unique(highest(./outboundRelationship[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalActRelationship()], priorityNumber)/target[moodCode="EVN" and classCode=("ENC", "PCPR") and isNormalAct])

annotation.definition: The root of the sections that make up the composition.

search.name: section-code
search.description: Classification of section (recommended)

search.name: status
search.description: preliminary | final | appended | amended | entered-in-error

search.name: subject
search.description: Who and/or what the composition is about

search.name: class
search.description: Categorization of Composition

search.name: encounter
search.description: Context of the conposition

search.name: period
search.description: The period covered by the documentation

search.name: type
search.description: Kind of composition (LOINC if possible)

search.name: date
search.description: Composition editing time

search.name: section
search.description: The Content of the section (narrative + data entries)

search.name: author
search.description: Who and/or what authored the composition

search.name: title
search.description: Human Readable name/title

search.name: patient
search.description: Who and/or what the composition is about

search.name: attester
search.description: Who attested the composition

search.name: confidentiality
search.description: As defined by affinity domain

search.name: context
search.description: Code(s) that apply to the event being documented

search.name: identifier
search.description: Logical identifier of composition (version-independent)

annotations.shortDefinition: A map from one set of concepts to one or more other concepts
annotations.definition: A statement of relationships from one set of concepts to one or more other concepts - either code systems or data elements, or classes in class models.
A nested type in ConceptMap: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of a individual to contact
annotation.definition: The name of an individual to contact regarding the concept map.
annotation.comment: If there is no named individual, the telecom is for the organization as a whole.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contact details for individual or publisher
annotation.definition: Contact details for individual (if a name was provided) or the publisher.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ConceptMap: Mappings for an individual concept in the source to one or more concepts in the target.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code System (if value set crosses code systems)
annotation.definition: An absolute URI that identifies the Code System (if the source is a value value set that crosses more than one code system).
Identity (code or path) or the element/item being mapped.

annotation.shortDefinition: Other elements required for this mapping (from context)
annotation.definition: A set of additional dependencies for this mapping to hold. This mapping is only applicable if the specified element can be resolved, and it has the specified value.
A concept from the target value set that this concept maps to.
annotation.comment: Ideally there would only be one map, with equal or equivalent mapping. But multiple maps are allowed for several narrower options, or to assert that other concepts are unmatched.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ConceptMap: A concept from the target value set that this concept maps to.

annotation.definition: An absolute URI that identifies the code system of the target code (if the target is a value set that cross code systems).
annotation.comment: Should be a version specific reference.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code that identifies the target element
annotation.definition: Identity (code or path) or the element/item that the map refers to.

annotation.shortDefinition: equivalent | equal | wider | subsumes | narrower | specialises | inexact | unmatched | disjoint
annotation.definition: The equivalence between the source and target concepts (counting for the dependencies and products). The equivalence is read from source to target (e.g. the source is 'wider' than the target.
A description of status/issues in mapping that conveys additional information not represented in the structured data.

annotation.shortDefinition: Other concepts that this mapping also produces
annotation.definition: A set of additional outcomes from this mapping to other elements. To properly execute this mapping, the specified element must be mapped to some data element or source that is in context. The mapping may still be useful without a place for the additional data elements, but the equivalence cannot be relied on.

annotations.definition: A nested type in ConceptMap: A set of additional dependencies for this mapping to hold. This mapping is only applicable if the specified element can be resolved, and it has the specified value.

annotation.shortDefinition: Reference to element/field/valueset mapping depends on
annotation.definition: A reference to a specific concept that holds a coded value. This can be an element in a FHIR resource, or a specific reference to a data element in a different specification (e.g. v2) or a general reference to a kind of data field, or a reference to a value set with an appropriately narrow definition.
An absolute URI that identifies the code system of the dependency code (if the source/dependency is a value set that cross code systems).
Identity (code or path) or the element/item that the map depends on / refers to.

binding.name: ConceptMapEquivalence
binding.definition: The degree of equivalence between concepts

code.definition: The definitions of the concepts mean the same thing (including when structural implications of meaning are considered) (i.e. extensionally identical).
The definitions of the concepts are exactly the same (i.e. only grammatical differences) and structural implications of meaning are identifical or irrelevant (i.e. intensionally identical).
The target mapping is wider in meaning than the source concept.
The target mapping subsumes the meaning of the source concept (e.g. the source is-a target).

The target mapping is narrower in meaning that the source concept. The sense in which the mapping is narrower SHALL be described in the comments in this case, and applications should be careful when atempting to use these mappings operationally.
The target mapping specialises the meaning of the source concept (e.g. the target is-a source).

The target mapping overlaps with the source concept, but both source and target cover additional meaning, or the definitions are imprecise and it is uncertain whether they have the same boundaries to their meaning. The sense in which the mapping is narrower SHALL be described in the comments in this case, and applications should be careful when atempting to use these mappings operationally.
There is no match for this concept in the destination concept system.
This is an explicit assertion that there is no mapping between the source and target concept.

annotation.shortDefinition: Globally unique logical id for concept map
annotation.definition: An absolute uri that is used to identify this concept map when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique URI, and an be urn:uuid: or urn:oid:).

annotation.shortDefinition: Additional identifier for the concept map
annotation.definition: Formal identifier that is used to identify this concept map when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
annotation.comment: Typically, this is used for values that can go in a v3 II data type.

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of the concept map
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the concept map when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp.
annotation.comment: There may be multiple resource versions of the concept map that have this same identifier.

annotation.shortDefinition: Informal name for this concept map
annotation.definition: A free text natural language name describing the concept map.
annotation.comment: Not expected to be unique.
annotation.requirements: Support human navigation.

annotation.shortDefinition: Content intends to support these contexts
annotation.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These terms may be used to assist with indexing and searching of concept maps.
annotation.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate concept maps.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)
annotation.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the concept map.
annotation.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
annotation.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the concept map. May also allow for contact.

annotation.definition: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
annotation.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Human language description of the concept map
annotation.definition: A free text natural language description of the use of the concept map - reason for definition, conditions of use, etc.
annotation.comment: The description is not intended to describe the semantics of the concept map. The description should capture its intended use, which is needed for ensuring integrity for its use in models across future changes.
annotation.requirements: Human understandability.

annotation.definition: Explains why this concept map is needed and why it's been constrained as it has.
annotation.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the concept map (that's done in comments), rather it's for traceability of *why* the element is either needed or why the constraints exist as they do. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this data element.

annotation.definition: A copyright statement relating to the concept map and/or its contents.
annotation.comment: Frequently, the copyright differs between the concept map, and codes that are included. The copyright statement should clearly differentiate between these when required.

annotation.definition: The status of the concept map.
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of ConceptMaps that are appropriate for use.
annotation.requirements: Identify when/if the concept map should be used.

annotation.shortDefinition: If for testing purposes, not real usage
annotation.definition: This ConceptMap was authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of ConceptMaps that are appropriate for use.

annotation.definition: The date that the concept map status was last changed.
annotation.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the concept map.
annotation.requirements: Need to know when a concept map was first legal for use or became withdrawn or replaced.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifies the source of the concepts which are being mapped
annotation.definition: The source value set that specifies the concepts that are being mapped.
annotation.comment: Should be a version specific reference. URIs SHOULD be absolute.

annotation.definition: The target value set provides context to the mappings. Note that the mapping is made between concepts, not between value sets, but the value set provides important context about how the concept mapping choices are made.
annotation.comment: Should be a version specific reference. URIs SHOULD be absolute.

annotation.shortDefinition: Mappings for a concept from the source set
annotation.definition: Mappings for an individual concept in the source to one or more concepts in the target.
annotation.comment: Generally, the ideal is that there would only be one mapping for each concept in the source value set, but a given concept may be mapped mutliple times with different comments or dependencies.

search.name: dependson
search.description: Reference to element/field/valueset mapping depends on

search.name: status
search.description: Status of the concept map

search.name: date
search.description: The concept map publication date

search.name: url
search.description: The url of the concept map

search.name: version
search.description: The version identifier of the concept map

search.name: publisher
search.description: Name of the publisher of the concept map

search.name: product
search.description: Reference to element/field/valueset mapping depends on

search.name: system
search.description: The system for any destination concepts mapped by this map

search.name: source
search.description: The system for any concepts mapped by this concept map

search.name: description
search.description: Text search in the description of the concept map

search.name: name
search.description: Name of the concept map

search.name: context
search.description: A use context assigned to the concept map

search.name: target
search.description: Provides context to the mappings

search.name: identifier
search.description: Additional identifier for the concept map

annotations.shortDefinition: Detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses
annotations.definition: Use to record detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses recognized by a clinician. There are many uses including: recording a Diagnosis during an Encounter; populating a problem List or a Summary Statement, such as a Discharge Summary.
annotations.todo:
* Age is questionable, you might well need a range of Age or even (in practice)
a text like "in their teens". => new ballot comment.
* Todo: discuss the applicability of assessing stages
* Change the description: it is circular.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: Supporting Evidence / manifestations that are the basis on which this condition is suspected or confirmed.

annotation.definition: A manifestation or symptom that led to the recording of this condition.
Links to other relevant information, including pathology reports.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events or the substance that caused/triggered this Condition.

annotation.shortDefinition: Relationship target by means of a predefined code
annotation.definition: Code that identifies the target of this relationship. The code takes the place of a detailed instance target.
Target of the relationship.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events or the substance that preceded this Condition.

annotation.shortDefinition: Relationship target by means of a predefined code
annotation.definition: Code that identifies the target of this relationship. The code takes the place of a detailed instance target.
Target of the relationship.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments.

annotation.definition: A simple summary of the stage such as "Stage 3". The determination of the stage is disease-specific.
Reference to a formal record of the evidence on which the staging assessment is based.
annotation.todo: When an assessment resource / framework is developed, this will be changed from Any to something narrower.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Condition: The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself.

annotation.definition: Code that identifies the structural location.
annotation.comment: May include laterality.

annotation.definition: Detailed anatomical location information.

binding.name: ConditionClinicalStatus
binding.definition: The clinical status of the Condition or diagnosis

code.definition: This is a tentative diagnosis - still a candidate that is under consideration.
The patient is being treated on the basis that this is the condition, but it is still not confirmed.
There is sufficient diagnostic and/or clinical evidence to treat this as a confirmed condition.
This condition has been ruled out by diagnostic and clinical evidence.

binding.name: ConditionCategory
binding.definition: A category assigned to the condition. E.g. finding | Condition | diagnosis | concern | condition

binding.name: ConditionKind
binding.definition: Identification of the Condition or diagnosis.

binding.name: ConditionSeverity
binding.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this condition that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
annotation.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.

annotation.definition: Indicates the patient who the condition record is associated with.
Encounter during which the condition was first asserted.
Person who takes responsibility for asserting the existence of the condition as part of the electronic record.
Estimated or actual date the condition/problem/diagnosis was first detected/suspected.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis
annotation.definition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis.
A category assigned to the condition. E.g. complaint | symptom | finding | diagnosis.
annotation.comment: The categorization is often highly contextual and may appear poorly differentiated or not very useful in other contexts.
annotation.v2Mapping: 'problem' if from PRB-3. 'diagnosis' if from DG1 segment in PV1 message

annotation.definition: The clinical status of the condition.
annotation.rimMapping:
.code (pre or post-coordinated in)
Can use valueNegationInd for refuted

annotation.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
annotation.comment: Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
annotation.rimMapping: Can be pre/post-coordinated into value. Or ./inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ].source[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="severity"].value

annotation.shortDefinition: Estimated or actual date, date-time, or age
annotation.definition: Estimated or actual date or date-time the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician.
annotation.comment: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition began to occur.

annotation.definition: The date or estimated date that the condition resolved or went into remission. This is called "abatement" because of the many overloaded connotations associated with "remission" or "resolution" - Conditions are never really resolved, but they can abate.
annotation.comment:
There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated.
If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid.
annotation.rimMapping: .effectiveTime.high or .inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ].source[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="age at remission"].value or .inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ]source[classCode=CONC, moodCode=EVN].status=completed

annotation.definition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments.
Supporting Evidence / manifestations that are the basis on which this condition is suspected or confirmed.
annotation.comment: The evidence may be a simple list of coded symptoms/manifestations, or references to observations or formal assessments, or both.

annotation.definition: The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself.
annotation.comment: May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

annotation.definition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events or the substance that caused/triggered this Condition.
annotation.comment: Although a condition may be caused by a substance, this is not intended to be used to record allergies/adverse reactions to substances.

annotation.definition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events or the substance that preceded this Condition.
Additional information about the Condition. This is a general notes/comments entry for description of the Condition, its diagnosis and prognosis.

example.name: USLab Condition Example1
example.description: USLab Condition Profile Canonical Example: Lead Exposure

example.name: USLab Condition Example2
example.description: USLab Reason for Study Profile Canonical Example: Lead Exposure

search.name: asserter
search.description: Person who asserts this condition

search.name: following-code
search.description: Relationship target by means of a predefined code

search.name: dueto-code
search.description: Relationship target by means of a predefined code

search.name: location
search.description: Location - may include laterality

search.name: subject
search.description: Who has the condition?

search.name: onset
search.description: Date related onsets (dateTime and Period)

search.name: onset-info
search.description: Other onsets (boolean, age, range, string)

search.name: following-item
search.description: Relationship target resource

search.name: severity
search.description: The severity of the condition

search.name: code
search.description: Code for the condition

search.name: encounter
search.description: Encounter when condition first asserted

search.name: date-asserted
search.description: When first detected/suspected/entered

search.name: stage
search.description: Simple summary (disease specific)

search.name: category
search.description: The category of the condition

search.name: patient
search.description: Who has the condition?

search.name: dueto-item
search.description: Relationship target resource

search.name: clinicalstatus
search.description: The clinical status of the condition

annotations.shortDefinition: A conformance statement
annotations.definition: A conformance statement is a set of requirements for a desired implementation or a description of how a target application fulfills those requirements in a particular implementation.
A nested type in Conformance: A definition of the restful capabilities of the solution, if any.

annotation.definition: Identifies whether this portion of the statement is describing ability to initiate or receive restful operations.
Information about the system's restful capabilities that apply across all applications, such as security.
Information about security implementation from an interface perspective - what a client needs to know.

annotation.shortDefinition: Resource served on the REST interface
annotation.definition: A specification of the restful capabilities of the solution for a specific resource type.
annotation.comment: Max of one repetition per resource type.

annotation.definition: A specification of restful operations supported by the system.

annotation.shortDefinition: Definition of an operation or a custom query
annotation.definition: Definition of an operation or a named query and with its parameters and their meaning and type.

A list of absolute URIs that identify profiles that this server implements for accepting documents in the mailbox. If this list is empty, then documents are not accepted. The base specification has the profile identifier "http://hl7.org/fhir/documents/mailbox". Other specifications can declare their own identifier for this purpose.
annotation.comment: If a server accepts messages on the /Mailbox end-point, it declares this in the messaging elements.

annotation.definition: An absolute URI which is a reference to the definition of a compartment hosted by the system.
annotation.comment: At present, the only defined compartments are at [[extras.html]].

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Software that is covered by this conformance statement. It is used when the conformance statement describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

annotation.shortDefinition: A name the software is known by
annotation.definition: Name software is known by.
The version identifier for the software covered by this statement.
annotation.comment: If possible, version should be specified, as statements are likely to be different for different versions of software.

annotation.definition: Date this version of the software released.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: A description of the messaging capabilities of the solution.

annotation.definition: An address to which messages and/or replies are to be sent.
annotation.comment: For solutions that do not use network addresses for routing, it can be just an identifier.

annotation.definition: Length if the receiver's reliable messaging cache in minutes (if a receiver) or how long the cache length on the receiver should be (if a sender).
annotation.comment: If this value is missing then the application does not implement (receiver) or depend on (sender) reliable messaging.

annotation.definition: Documentation about the system's messaging capabilities for this endpoint not otherwise documented by the conformance statement. For example, process for becoming an authorized messaging exchange partner.
A description of the solution's support for an event at this end point.
annotation.comment: The same event may be listed up to two times - once as sender and once as receiver.
annotation.todo: Need to add follow-ups and need to do more to flesh out messaging dynamic model.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: A document definition.

annotation.definition: Mode of this document declaration - whether application is producer or consumer.
A description of how the application supports or uses the specified document profile. For example, when are documents created, what action is taken with consumed documents, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Constraint on a resource used in the document
annotation.definition: A constraint on a resource used in the document.
annotation.comment: The first resource is the document resource.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: A specification of the restful capabilities of the solution for a specific resource type.

annotation.shortDefinition: A resource type that is supported
annotation.definition: A type of resource exposed via the restful interface.
A specification of the profile that describes the solution's support for the resource, including any constraints on cardinality, bindings, lengths or other limitations.
annotation.comment: The profile applies to all resources of this type - i.e. it is the superset of what is supported by the system.

annotation.definition: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.

Thi field is set to true to specify that the system does not support (server) or use (client) versioning for this resource type. If this is not set to true, the server must at least correctly track and populate the versionId meta-property on resources.
annotation.comment: If a server supports versionIds correctly, it should support vread too, but is not required to do so.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether vRead can return past versions
annotation.definition: A flag for whether the server is able to return past versions as part of the vRead operation.
annotation.comment: It is useful to support the vRead operation for current operations, even if past versions aren't available.

annotation.shortDefinition: If update can commit to a new identity
annotation.definition: A flag to indicate that the server allows or needs to allow the client to create new identities on the server (e.g. that is, the client PUTs to a location where there is no existing resource). Allowing this operation means that the server allows the client to create new identities on the server.
annotation.comment: Allowing the clients to create new identities on the server means that the system administrator needs to have confidence that the clients do not create clashing identities between them. Obviously, if there is only one client, this won't happen. While creating identities on the client means that the clients need to be managed, it's much more convenient for many scenarios if such management can be put in place.

annotation.definition: A flag that indicates that the server supports conditional create.
annotation.comment: Conditional Create is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

annotation.definition: A flag that indicates that the server supports conditional update.
annotation.comment: Conditional Update is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

annotation.definition: A flag that indicates that the server supports conditional delete.
annotation.comment: Conditional Delete is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

annotation.definition: A list of _include values supported by the server.
annotation.comment: If this list is empty, the server does not support includes.

annotation.definition: Search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of - either references to ones defined in the specification, or additional ones defined for/by the implementation.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Identifies a specific implementation instance that is described by the conformance statement - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.

annotation.definition: Information about the specific installation that this conformance statement relates to.
An absolute base URL for the implementation. This forms the base for REST interfaces as well as the mailbox and document interfaces.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of a individual to contact
annotation.definition: The name of an individual to contact regarding the conformance.
annotation.comment: If there is no named individual, the telecom is for the organization as a whole.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contact details for individual or publisher
annotation.definition: Contact details for individual (if a name was provided) or the publisher.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: A description of the solution's support for an event at this end point.

annotation.definition: A coded identifier of a supported messaging event.
annotation.todo: May need a profile id as well if profiles can define message events.

annotation.definition: The impact of the content of the message.
The mode of this event declaration - whether application is sender or receiver.
A list of the messaging transport protocol(s) identifiers, supported by this endpoint.
annotation.todo: Loosen this to "extensible" once tooling supports that.

annotation.definition: A resource associated with the event. This is the resource that defines the event.
annotation.comment: This SHALL be provided if the event type supports multiple different resource types.

annotation.definition: Information about the request for this event.
Information about the response for this event.
Guidance on how this event is handled, such as internal system trigger points, business rules, etc.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: A specification of restful operations supported by the system.

annotation.definition: A coded identifier of the operation, supported by the system.
Guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as limitations on the kind of transactions allowed, or information about system wide search is implemented.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.

annotation.shortDefinition: read | vread | update | delete | history-instance | validate | history-type | create | search-type
annotation.definition: Coded identifier of the operation, supported by the system resource.

Guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as 'delete is a logical delete' or 'updates are only allowed with version id' or 'creates permitted from pre-authorized certificates only'.
annotation.requirements: REST allows a degree of variability in the implementation of RESTful solutions that is useful for exchange partners to be aware of.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Information about security implementation from an interface perspective - what a client needs to know.

annotation.definition: Server adds CORS headers when responding to requests - this enables javascript applications to use the server.
annotation.comment: The easiest CORS headers to add are Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * & Access-Control-Request-Method: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. All servers SHOULD support CORS.

annotation.definition: Types of security services are supported/required by the system.

annotation.shortDefinition: General description of how security works
annotation.definition: General description of how security works.
Certificates associated with security profiles.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Certificates associated with security profiles.

annotation.definition: Mime type for certificate.
Actual certificate.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Definition of an operation or a named query and with its parameters and their meaning and type.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name by which the operation/query is invoked
annotation.definition: The name of a query, which is used in the _query parameter when the query is called.
annotation.comment: The name here SHOULD be the same as the name in the definition, unless there is a name clash and the name cannot be used.

annotation.definition: Where the formal definition can be found.
annotation.comment: This can be used to build ah HTML form to invoke the operation, for instance.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of - either references to ones defined in the specification, or additional ones defined for/by the implementation.

annotation.definition: The name of the search parameter used in the interface.
annotation.comment: Parameter names cannot overlap with standard parameter names, and standard parameters cannot be redefined.

annotation.definition: An absolute URI that is a formal reference to where this parameter was first defined, so that a client can be confident of the meaning of the search parameter (a reference to [[[SearchParameter.url]]]).
annotation.comment: This SHOULD be present, and matches SearchParameter.url.

annotation.shortDefinition: number | date | string | token | reference | composite | quantity | uri
annotation.definition: The type of value a search parameter refers to, and how the content is interpreted.
annotation.comment: While this can be looked up from the definition, it is included here as a convenience for systems that auto-generate a query interface based on the server conformance statement. It SHALL be the same as the type in the search parameter definition.

annotation.definition: This allows documentation of any distinct behaviors about how the search parameter is used. For example, text matching algorithms.

annotation.shortDefinition: Types of resource (if a resource reference)
annotation.definition: Types of resource (if a resource is referenced).
annotation.comment: This SHALL be the same as or a proper subset of the resources listed in the search parameter definition.

annotation.definition: Chained names supported.

binding.name: SystemRestfulInteraction
binding.definition: Operations supported by REST at the system level

binding.name: DocumentMode
binding.definition: Whether the application produces or consumes documents

code.definition: The application produces documents of the specified type.
The application consumes documents of the specified type.

binding.name: ResourceVersionPolicy
binding.definition: How the system supports versioning for a resource

code.definition: VersionId meta-property is not suppoerted (server) or used (client).
VersionId meta-property is suppoerted (server) or used (client).
VersionId is must be correct for updates (server) or will be specified (If-match header) for updates (client).

binding.name: RestfulConformanceMode
binding.definition: The mode of a RESTful conformance statement

code.definition: The application acts as a client for this resource.
The application acts as a server for this resource.

binding.name: MessageTransport
binding.definition: The protocol used for message transport

code.definition: The application sends or receives messages using HTTP POST (may be over http or https).
The application sends or receives messages using File Transfer Protocol.
The application sends or receivers messages using HL7's Minimal Lower Level Protocol.

binding.name: TypeRestfulInteraction
binding.definition: Operations supported by REST at the type or instance level

binding.name: ConformanceEventMode
binding.definition: The mode of a message conformance statement

code.definition: The application sends requests and receives responses.
The application receives requests and sends responses.

binding.name: MessageSignificanceCategory
binding.definition: The impact of the content of a message

code.definition: The message represents/requests a change that should not be processed more than once. E.g. Making a booking for an appointment.
The message represents a response to query for current information. Retrospective processing is wrong and/or wasteful.
The content is not necessarily intended to be current, and it can be reprocessed, though there may be version issues created by processing old notifications.

binding.name: SearchParamType
binding.definition: Data types allowed to be used for search parameters

code.definition: Search parameter SHALL be a number (a whole number, or a decimal).
Search parameter is on a date/time. The date format is the standard XML format, though other formats may be supported.
Search parameter is a simple string, like a name part. Search is case-insensitive and accent-insensitive. May match just the start of a string. String parameters may contain spaces.

Search parameter on a coded element or identifier. May be used to search through the text, displayname, code and code/codesystem (for codes) and label, system and key (for identifier). Its value is either a string or a pair of namespace and value, separated by a "|", depending on the modifier used.
A reference to another resource.
A composite search parameter that combines a search on two values together.
A search parameter that searches on a quantity.
A search parameter that searches on a URI (RFC 3986).

binding.name: RestfulSecurityService
binding.definition: Types of security services used with FHIR

code.definition: OAuth (see oauth.net).
OAuth version 2 (see oauth.net).
Microsoft NTLM Authentication.
Basic authentication defined in HTTP specification.
see http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4120.txt.

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical uri to reference this statement
annotation.definition: An absolute uri that is used to identify this conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique URI, and an be urn:uuid: or urn:oid:).

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of the statement
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp.
annotation.comment: There may be multiple different instances of a conformance statement that have the same identifier but different versions.

annotation.shortDefinition: Informal name for this conformance statement
annotation.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the conformance statement.
annotation.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)
annotation.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the conformance.
annotation.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
annotation.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the conformance. May also allow for contact.

annotation.definition: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
annotation.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Human description of the conformance statement
annotation.definition: A free text natural language description of the conformance statement and its use. Typically, this is used when the conformance statement describes a desired rather than an actual solution, for example as a formal expression of requirements as part of an RFP.
annotation.comment: This field cmay include the purpose of this conformance statement, comments about its context etc. This does not need to be populated if the description is adequately implied by the software or implementation details.

annotation.definition: Explains why this conformance statement is needed and why it's been constrained as it has.
annotation.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the conformance statement (that's done in comments), rather it's for traceability of *why* the element is either needed or why the constraints exist as they do. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this data element.

annotation.definition: A copyright statement relating to the conformamce statement and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the details of the system described by the conformance statement.
The status of this conformance statement.
annotation.comment: This is not intended for use with actual conformance statements, but where conformance statements are used to describe possible or desired systems.

annotation.shortDefinition: If for testing purposes, not real usage
annotation.definition: A flag to indicate that this conformance statement is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of conformance statements that are appropriate for use vs. not.

annotation.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the conformance statement was published.

annotation.shortDefinition: Software that is covered by this conformance statement
annotation.definition: Software that is covered by this conformance statement. It is used when the conformance statement describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this describes a specific instance
annotation.definition: Identifies a specific implementation instance that is described by the conformance statement - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.
The version of the FHIR specification on which this conformance statement is based.

annotation.shortDefinition: True if application accepts unknown elements
annotation.definition: A flag that indicates whether the application accepts unknown elements as part of a resource.
annotation.comment: This is not about extensions, but about unknown elements in a resource - these can only arise as later versions of the specification are published, because this is the only place where such elements can be defined. Hence this element is about inter-version compatibility.

annotation.definition: A list of the formats supported by this implementation using their content types.
annotation.comment: "xml" or "json" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here.

annotation.definition: A list of profiles supported by the system. For a server, "supported by the system" means the system hosts/produces a set of resources, conformant to a particular profile, and allows its clients to search using this profile and to find appropriate data. For a client, it means the system will search by this profile and process data according to the guidance implicit in the profile.
annotation.comment:
Supported profiles are different to the profiles that apply to a particular resource in rest.resource.profile. The resource profile is a general statement of what features of the resource are supported overall by the system - the sum total of the facilities it supports. A supported profile is a deeper statement about the functionality of the data and services provided by the server (or used by the client). A typical case is a laboratory system that produces a set of different reports- this is the list of types of data that it publishes. A key aspect of declaring profiles here is the question of how the client converts knowledge that the server publishes this data into working with the data; the client can inspect individual resources to determine whether they conform to a particular profile, but how does it find the ones that does? It does so by searching using the _profile parameter, so any resources listed here must be valid values for the _profile resource (using the identifier in the target profile).
Typical supported profiles cross resource types to describe a network of related resources, so they are listed here rather than by resource. However they do not need to describe more than one resource.

annotation.shortDefinition: If the endpoint is a RESTful one
annotation.definition: A definition of the restful capabilities of the solution, if any.
annotation.comment: Multiple repetitions allow definition of both client and / or server behaviors or possibly behaviors under different configuration settings (for software or requirements statements).

annotation.definition: A description of the messaging capabilities of the solution.
annotation.comment: Multiple repetitions allow the documentation of multiple endpoints per solution.

annotation.definition: A document definition.

invariant.name: cnf-1
invariant.human: A Conformance statement SHALL have at least one of rest, messaging or document

invariant.name: cnf-2
invariant.human: A Conformance statement SHALL have at least one of description, software, or implementation

invariant.name: cnf-4
invariant.human: If there is more than one messaging element, endpoint must be specified for each one

invariant.name: cnf-5
invariant.human: The set of end points listed for messaging must be unique

invariant.name: cnf-7
invariant.human: The set of documents must be unique by the combination of profile & mode

invariant.name: cnf-8
invariant.human: There can only be one REST declaration per mode

search.name: status

annotations.definition: A formal agreement between parties regarding the conduct of business, exchange of information or other matters.
A nested type in Contract: List of Computable Policy Rule Language Representations of this Contract.

annotation.definition: Computable Contract conveyed using a policy rule language (e.g. XACML, DKAL, SecPal).

annotations.definition: A nested type in Contract: List of Contract actors.

annotation.definition: Who or what actors are assigned roles in this Contract.
Role type of actors assigned roles in this Contract.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Contract: Contract Provision Valued Item List.

annotation.definition: Specific type of Contract Provision Valued Item that may be priced.
Identifies a Contract Provision Valued Item instance.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contract Term Valued Item Effective Tiem
annotation.definition: Indicates the time during which this Contract Term ValuedItem information is effective.
Specifies the units by which the Contract Provision Valued Item is measured or counted, and quantifies the countable or measurable Contract Term Valued Item instances.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contract Term Valued Item fee, charge, or cost
annotation.definition: A Contract Provision Valued Item unit valuation measure.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contract Term Valued Item Price Scaling Factor
annotation.definition: A real number that represents a multiplier used in determining the overall value of the Contract Provision Valued Item delivered. The concept of a Factor allows for a discount or surcharge multiplier to be applied to a monetary amount.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contract Term Valued Item Difficulty Scaling Factor
annotation.definition: An amount that expresses the weighting (based on difficulty, cost and/or resource intensiveness) associated with the Contract Provision Valued Item delivered. The concept of Points allows for assignment of point values for a Contract ProvisionValued Item, such that a monetary amount can be assigned to each point.

annotation.shortDefinition: Total Contract Term Valued Item Value
annotation.definition: Expresses the product of the Contract Provision Valued Item unitQuantity and the unitPriceAmt. For example, the formula: unit Quantity * unit Price (Cost per Point) * factor Number * points = net Amount. Quantity, factor and points are assumed to be 1 if not supplied.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Contract: The "patient friendly language" versionof the Contract in whole or in parts. "Patient friendly language" means the representation of the Contract and Contract Provisions in a manner that is readily accessible and understandable by a layperson in accordance with best practices for communication styles that ensure that those agreeing to or signing the Contract understand the roles, actions, obligations, responsibilities, and implication of the agreement.

annotation.shortDefinition: Easily comprehended representation of this Contract
annotation.definition: Human readable rendering of this Contract in a format and representation intended to enhance comprehension and ensure understandability.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Contract: Contract Valued Item List.

annotation.definition: Specific type of Contract Valued Item that may be priced.
Identifies a Contract Valued Item instance.
Indicates the time during which this Contract ValuedItem information is effective.
Specifies the units by which the Contract Valued Item is measured or counted, and quantifies the countable or measurable Contract Valued Item instances.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contract Valued Item fee, charge, or cost
annotation.definition: A Contract Valued Item unit valuation measure.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contract Valued Item Price Scaling Factor
annotation.definition: A real number that represents a multiplier used in determining the overall value of the Contract Valued Item delivered. The concept of a Factor allows for a discount or surcharge multiplier to be applied to a monetary amount.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contract Valued Item Difficulty Scaling Factor
annotation.definition: An amount that expresses the weighting (based on difficulty, cost and/or resource intensiveness) associated with the Contract Valued Item delivered. The concept of Points allows for assignment of point values for a Contract Valued Item, such that a monetary amount can be assigned to each point.

Expresses the product of the Contract Valued Item unitQuantity and the unitPriceAmt. For example, the formula: unit Quantity * unit Price (Cost per Point) * factor Number * points = net Amount. Quantity, factor and points are assumed to be 1 if not supplied.
