annotation.definition: Unique identifier for this Contract.
When this Contract was issued.
Relevant time or time-period when this Contract is applicable.
Who and/or what this Contract is about: typically a Patient, Organization, or valued items such as goods and services.

annotation.shortDefinition: Authority under which this Contract has standing
annotation.definition: A formally or informally recognized grouping of people, principals, organizations, or jurisdictions formed for the purpose of achieving some form of collective action such as the promulgation, administration and enforcement of contracts and policies.

annotation.shortDefinition: Domain in which this Contract applies
annotation.definition: Recognized governance framework or system operating with a circumscribed scope in accordance with specified principles, policies, processes or procedures for managing rights, actions, or behaviors of parties or principals relative to resources.
Type of Contract such as an insurance policy, real estate contract, a will, power of attorny, Privacy or Security policy , trust framework agreement, etc.
More specific type or specialization of an overarching or more general contract such as auto insurance, home owner insurance, prenupial agreement, Advanced-Directive, or privacy consent.
Action stipulated by this Contract.
Reason for action stipulated by this Contract.
List of Contract actors.
Contract Valued Item List.
Party signing this Contract.
One or more Contract Provisions, which may be related and conveyed as a group, and may contain nested groups.

Legally binding Contract: This is the signed and legally recognized representation of the Contract, which is considered the "source of truth" and which would be the basis for legal action related to enforcement of this Contract.

The "patient friendly language" versionof the Contract in whole or in parts. "Patient friendly language" means the representation of the Contract and Contract Provisions in a manner that is readily accessible and understandable by a layperson in accordance with best practices for communication styles that ensure that those agreeing to or signing the Contract understand the roles, actions, obligations, responsibilities, and implication of the agreement.
List of Legal expressions or representations of this Contract.
List of Computable Policy Rule Language Representations of this Contract.

annotations.shortDefinition: Clinical issue with action
annotations.definition: Indicates an actual or potential clinical issue with or between one or more active or proposed clinical actions for a patient. E.g. Drug-drug interaction, Ineffective treatment frequency, Procedure-condition conflict, etc.

A nested type in Contraindication: Indicates an action that has been taken or is committed to to reduce or eliminate the likelihood of the risk identified by the contraindicaiton from manifesting. Can also reflect an observation of known mitigating factors that may reduce/eliminate the need for any action.

annotation.definition: Describes the action that was taken or the observation that was made that reduces/eliminates the risk associated with the identified contraindication.
annotation.comment: The "text" component can be used for detail or when no appropriate code exists.

annotation.definition: Indicates when the mitigating action was documented.
annotation.comment: This may not be the same as when the mitigating step was actually taken.

annotation.definition: Identifies the practitioner who determined the mitigation and takes responsibility for the mitigation step occurring.

binding.name: ContraindicationSeverity
binding.definition: Indicates the potential degree of impact of the identified issue on the patient

binding.name: ContraindicationCategory
binding.definition: Codes identifying the general type of contraindication. E.g. Drug-drug interaction, Timing issue, Duplicate therapy, etc.

binding.name: ContraindicationMitigationAction
binding.definition: Codes describing steps taken to resolve the contraindication or other circumstances that mitigate the risk associated with the contraindication. E.g. 'added concurrent therapy', 'prior therapy documented', etc.

annotation.definition: Indicates the patient whose record the contraindication is associated with.
annotation.requirements: While the subject could be inferred by tracing the subject of the implicated resources, it's useful to have a direct link for query purposes.

annotation.definition: Identifies the general type of issue identified.
Indicates the degree of importance associated with the identified issue based on the potential impact on the patient.
Indicates the resource representing the current activity or proposed activity that.
annotation.comment: There's an implicit constraint on the number of implicated resources based on Contraindication.type. E.g. For drug-drug, there would be more than one. For timing, there would typically only be one.

annotation.definition: A textual explanation of the contraindication.
annotation.comment: Should focus on information not covered elsewhere as discrete data - no need to duplicate the narrative.

annotation.definition: The date or date-time when the contraindication was initially identified.
annotation.requirements: No-one can be responsible for mitigation prior to the issue being identified.

annotation.definition: Identifies the provider or software that identified the.
annotation.todo: Is this 80%?

annotation.definition: Business identifier associated with the contraindication record.
annotation.requirements: Allows linking instances of the same contraindication found on different servers.

annotation.definition: The literature, knowledge-base or similar reference that describes the propensity for the contraindication identified.
annotation.todo: Is this in the 80%?

annotation.definition: Indicates an action that has been taken or is committed to to reduce or eliminate the likelihood of the risk identified by the contraindicaiton from manifesting. Can also reflect an observation of known mitigating factors that may reduce/eliminate the need for any action.
annotation.todo: How much, if any of this is in the 80%?

search.description: Who found issue?

annotations.shortDefinition: Insurance or medical plan
annotations.definition: Financial instrument which may be used to pay for or reimburse for health care products and services.
annotations.requirements: Health care programs and insurers are significant payors of health service costs.

binding.name: CoverageType
binding.definition: The type of insurance: public health, worker compensation; private accident, auto, private health, etc.)

annotation.shortDefinition: An identifier for the plan issuer
annotation.definition: The program or plan underwriter or payor.
annotation.requirements: Need to identify the issuer to target for processing and for coordination of benefit processing.

annotation.definition: Business Identification Number (BIN number) used to identify the routing of eclaims if the insurer themselves don't have a BIN number for all of their business.
Time period during which the coverage is in force. A missing start date indicates the start date isn't known, a missing end date means the coverage is continuing to be in force.
annotation.v2Mapping: IN1-12-plan effective date / IN1-13-plan expiration date

annotation.definition: The type of coverage: social program, medical plan, accident coverage (workers compensation, auto), group health.
annotation.requirements: The order of application of coverages is dependent on the types of coverage.

annotation.definition: The id issued to the subscriber.
The main (and possibly only) identifier for the coverage - often referred to as a Member Id, Subscriber Id, Certificate number or Personal Health Number or Case ID.
annotation.requirements: This value may uniquely identify the coverage or it may be used in conjunction with the additional identifiers below.

annotation.definition: Identifies a style or collective of coverage issues by the underwriter, for example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group. May also be referred to as a Policy or Group ID.
Identifies a style or collective of coverage issues by the underwriter, for example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group. May also be referred to as a Policy or Group ID.

annotation.shortDefinition: An identifier for the subsection of the plan
annotation.definition: Identifies a sub-style or sub-collective of coverage issues by the underwriter, for example may be used to identify a specific employer group within a class of employers. May be referred to as a Section or Division ID.
A unique identifier for a dependent under the coverage.
annotation.requirements: For some coverage a single identifier is issued to the PolicyHolder and dependent number issues to each to each of their dependents to track and manage the plan.
annotation.v2Mapping: - No exact V2.x equivalent concept seems to exist; instance relationship can be inferred if ( ( PID-3-patient ID list ??? IN1-49-insured's ID number ) & ( ?? IN2-72-patient's relationship to insured ) )

annotation.shortDefinition: The plan instance or sequence counter
annotation.definition: An optional counter for a particular instance of the identified coverage which increments upon each renewal.
annotation.requirements: Some coverage, for example social plans, may be offered in short time increments, for example for a week or a month at a time, so while the rest of the plan details and identifiers may remain constant over time, the instance is incremented with each renewal and provided to the covered party on their 'card'.
annotation.v2Mapping: No V2.x equivalent concept seems to exist

annotation.definition: The party who 'owns' the insurance contractual relationship to the policy or to whom the benefit of the policy is due.
annotation.v2Mapping: IN1-16, 18, 19-name of insured, address, date of birth
annotation.todo: D01 through D09.

annotation.definition: The identifier for a community of providers.
The policy(s) which constitute this insurance coverage.
annotation.v2Mapping: IN1-16, 18, 19-name of insured, address, date of birth
annotation.todo: D01 through D09.

annotations.shortDefinition: Resource data element
annotations.definition: The formal description of a single piece of information that can be gathered and reported.
annotations.comment: Often called a clinical template.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DataElement: Identifies a specification (other than a terminology) that the elements that make up the DataElement hav some correspondance with.

annotation.shortDefinition: Internal id when this mapping is used
annotation.definition: An Internal id that is used to identify this mapping set when specific mappings are made on a per-element basis.
annotation.comment: The specification is described once, with general comments, and then specific mappings are made that reference this declaration.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifies what this mapping refers to
annotation.definition: An absolute URI that identifies the specification that this mapping is expressed to.
annotation.comment: A formal identity for the specification being mapped to helps with identifying maps consistently.

annotation.shortDefinition: Names what this mapping refers to
annotation.definition: A name for the specification that is being mapped to.
Comments about this mapping, including version notes, issues, scope limitations, and other important notes for usage.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DataElement: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of a individual to contact
annotation.definition: The name of an individual to contact regarding the data element.
annotation.comment: If there is no named individual, the telecom is for the organization as a whole.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contact details for individual or publisher
annotation.definition: Contact details for individual (if a name was provided) or the publisher.

binding.name: DataElementSpecificity
binding.definition: Indicates the degree of precision of the data element definition

code.definition: The data element is sufficiently well-constrained that multiple pieces of data captured according to the constraints of the data element will be comparable (though in some cases, a degree of automated conversion/normalization may be required).
The data element is fully specified down to a single value set, single unit of measure, single data type, etc. Multiple pieces of data associated with this data element are fully compareable.
The data element allows multiple units of measure having equivalent meaning. E.g. "cc" (cubic centimeter) and "mL".

The data element allows multiple units of measure that are convertable between each other (e.g. Inches and centimeters) and/or allows data to be captured in multiple value sets for which a known mapping exists allowing conversion of meaning.
A convertable data element where unit conversions are different only by a power of 10. E.g. g, mg, kg.
The data element is unconstrained in units, choice of data types and/or choice of vocabulary such that automated comparison of data captured using the data element is not possible.

binding.name: UseContext
binding.definition: Indicates the countries, regions, disciplines and other aspects of use this artifact is targeted for use within

annotation.shortDefinition: Globally unique logical id for data element
annotation.definition: An absolute uri that is used to identify this element when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique URI, and an be urn:uuid: or urn:oid:).

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id to reference this data element
annotation.definition: Formal identifier that is used to identify this data element when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
annotation.comment: Typically, this is used for values that can go in a v3 II data type.

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of the data element
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the data element when it is referenced in a StructureDefinition, Questionnaire or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the definition author manually.
annotation.requirements: There may be multiple resource versions of the data element that have this same identifier. The resource version id will change for technical reasons, whereas the stated version number needs to be under the author's control.

annotation.shortDefinition: Descriptive label for this element definition
annotation.definition: The term used by humans to refer to the data element. Should ideally be unique within the context in which the data element is expected to be used.
annotation.comment: This may be similar to the question used to prompt someone for a data element value, but the purpose is communicating about the data element, not asking the question. (Refer to the 'question' element for the latter.).

annotation.shortDefinition: Content intends to support these contexts
annotation.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These terms may be used to assist with indexing and searching of data element definitions.

annotation.shortDefinition: If for testing purposes, not real usage
annotation.definition: A flag to indicate that this search data elemnt definition is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of search data element definitions that are appropriate for use vs. not.

annotation.definition: The status of the data element.
annotation.requirements: Allows filtering of data elements that are appropriate for use vs. not.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date for this version of the data element
annotation.definition: The date that the status for this business version of the data element became effective. (I.e. Date the draft was created, date element became active or date element became retired).
annotation.comment: This refers to the "business" version - the DataElement.version which changes based on business processes. It does not refer to the date of the RESTful version which is part of the resource metadata.

annotation.definition: A copyright statement relating to the definition of the data element. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the details of the definition of the data element.
annotation.comment: The copyright statement does not apply to values for the data element, only to its definition.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)
annotation.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the data element.
annotation.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
annotation.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the data element. May also allow for contact.

annotation.definition: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
annotation.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: comparable | fully-specified | equivalent | convertable | scaleable | flexible
annotation.definition: Identifies how precise the data element is in its definition.
annotation.requirements: Allows determining whether the degree of comparability of data element instances - less granular data elements result in data that is less comparable (or at least requires more work to compare).
annotation.todo: Should this be an extension?

annotation.definition: Identifies a specification (other than a terminology) that the elements that make up the DataElement hav some correspondance with.
Defines the structure, type, allowed values and other constraining characteristics of the data element.
annotation.comment: For simple data types there will only be one repetion. For complex data types, multiple repetitions will be present defining a nested structure using the "path" element.
annotation.todo: Type should have {http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/elementdefinition-de}.

example.name: Gender
example.description: Patient gender represented as an data element

example.name: SDC-Gender
example.description: Patient gender represented according to SDC rules

example.description: Prothrombin time for lab test master file

search.name: status
search.description: The current status of the data element

search.name: description
search.description: Text search in the description of the data element. This corresponds to the definition of the first DataElement.element.

search.name: name
search.description: Name of the data element

search.name: context
search.description: A use context assigned to the data element

search.name: code
search.description: A code for the data element (server may choose to do subsumption)

search.name: date
search.description: The data element publication date

search.name: identifier
search.description: The identifier of the data element

search.name: url
search.description: The official URL for the data element

search.name: publisher
search.description: Name of the publisher of the data element

search.name: version
search.description: The version identifier of the data element

annotations.shortDefinition: An instance of a manufactured thing that is used in the provision of healthcare
annotations.definition: This resource identifies an instance of a manufactured thing that is used in the provision of healthcare without being substantially changed through that activity. The device may be a machine, an insert, a computer, an application, etc. This includes durable (reusable) medical equipment as well as disposable equipment used for diagnostic, treatment, and research for healthcare and public health.
annotations.requirements: Allows institutions to track their devices.

binding.name: DeviceKind
binding.definition: Defines the nature of the device and the kind of functionality/services/behavior that may be expected from it

annotation.shortDefinition: Instance id from manufacturer, owner, regulatory agencies and others
annotation.definition: Unique instance identifiers assigned to a device by organizations like manufacturers, owners or regulatory agencies. If the identifier identifies the type of device, Device.type should be used. An example is the FDA Mandated Unique Device Identifier (UDI) which identifies an instance of a device uniquely if the serial number is present, . - see http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/UniqueDeviceIdentification/default.htm.
annotation.comment: Often fixed to the device as a barcode and may include names given to the device in local usage. Note that some of the barcodes affixed to the device identify its type, not its instance.

annotation.shortDefinition: What kind of device this is
annotation.definition: Code or identifier to identify a kind of device An example is the FDA Mandated Unique Device Identifier (UDI) which identifies a type of a device when the serial number is absent, otherwise it uniquely identifies the device instance and Device.identifier should be used instead of Device.type. - see http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/UniqueDeviceIdentification/default.htm.
A name of the manufacturer.

annotation.shortDefinition: Model id assigned by the manufacturer
annotation.definition: The "model" - an identifier assigned by the manufacturer to identify the product by its type. This number is shared by the all devices sold as the same type.
The version of the device, if the device has multiple releases under the same model, or if the device is software or carries firmware.
The Date and time when the device was manufactured.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date and time of expiry of this device (if applicable)
annotation.definition: The date and time beyond which this device is no longer valid or should not be used (if applicable).
Lot number assigned by the manufacturer.
annotation.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

annotation.definition: An organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device.
The resource may be found in a literal location (i.e. GPS coordinates), a logical place (i.e. "in/with the patient"), or a coded location.

annotation.shortDefinition: If the resource is affixed to a person
annotation.definition: Patient information, if the resource is affixed to a person.
Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device.
annotation.comment: used for troubleshooting etc.

annotation.definition: A network address on which the device may be contacted directly.
annotation.comment: If the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should be the root URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved.

search.name: organization
search.description: The organization responsible for the device

search.name: model
search.description: The model of the device

search.name: patient
search.description: Patient information, if the resource is affixed to a person

search.name: location
search.description: A location, where the resource is found

search.name: manufacturer
search.description: The manufacturer of the device

search.name: type
search.description: The type of the device

search.name: identifier
search.description: Instance id from manufacturer, owner, regulatory agencies and others

annotations.shortDefinition: An instance of a medical-related component of a medical device
annotations.definition: Describes the characteristics, operational status and capabilities of a medical-related component of a medical device.
A nested type in DeviceComponent: Describes the production specification such as component revision, serial number, etc.

annotation.definition: Describes the specification type, such as, serial number, part number, hardware revision, software revision, etc.

Describes the internal component unique identification. This is a provision for manufacture specific standard components using a private OID. 11073-10101 has a partition for private OID semantic that the manufacture can make use of.

annotation.shortDefinition: A printable string defining the component
annotation.definition: Describes the printable string defining the component.

binding.name: Measmnt-Principle
binding.definition: Different measurement principle supported by the device

code.definition: Measurement principle isn't in the list.
Measurement is done using chemical.
Measurement is done using electrical.
Measurement is done using impedance.
Measurement is done using nuclear.
Measurement is done using optical.
Measurement is done using thermal.
Measurement is done using biological.
Measurement is done using mechanical.
Measurement is done using acoustical.
Measurement is done using manual.

binding.name: ComponentType
binding.definition: Describes the type of the component

annotation.shortDefinition: What kind of component it is
annotation.definition: Describes the specific component type as defined in the object-oriented or metric nomenclature partition.

annotation.shortDefinition: Instance id assigned by the software stack
annotation.definition: Describes the local assigned unique identification by the software. For example: handle ID.
Describes the timestamp for the most recent system change which includes device configuration or setting change.

annotation.shortDefinition: A source device of this component
annotation.definition: Describes the link to the source Device that contains administrative device information such as manufacture, serial number, etc.
Describes the link to the parent resource. For example: Channel is linked to its VMD parent.
Indicates current operational status of the device. For example: On, Off, Standby, etc.
annotation.comment: OperationalStatus for the MDS, VMD, or Channel will be bound to a specific ValueSet that is defined in its profile.

annotation.definition: Describes the parameter group supported by the current device component that is based on some nomenclature, e.g., cardiovascular.

annotation.shortDefinition: other | chemical | electrical | impedance | nuclear | optical | thermal | biological | mechanical | acoustical | manual+
annotation.definition: Describes the physical principle of the measurement. For example: thermal, chemical, acoustical, etc.
Describes the production specification such as component revision, serial number, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Language code for the human-readable text strings produced by the device
annotation.definition: Describes the language code for the human-readable text string produced by the device. This language code will follow the IETF language tag. Example: en-US.

annotations.shortDefinition: Measurement, calculation or setting capability of a medical device
annotations.definition: Describes a measurement, calculation or setting capability of a medical device.
A nested type in DeviceMetric: Describes the calibrations that have been performed or that are required to be performed.

annotation.definition: Describes the type of the calibration method.
Describes the state of the calibration.

annotation.shortDefinition: Describes the time last calibration has been performed
annotation.definition: Describes the time last calibration has been performed.

binding.name: DeviceMetricColor
binding.definition: Describes the typical color of representation

code.definition: Color for representation - black.
Color for representation - red.
Color for representation - green.
Color for representation - yellow.
Color for representation - blue.
Color for representation - magenta.
Color for representation - cyan.
Color for representation - white.

binding.name: DeviceMetricCalibrationState
binding.definition: Describes the state of a metric calibration

code.definition: The metric has not been calibrated.
The metric needs to be calibrated.
The metric has been calibrated.
The state of calibration of this metric is unspecified.

binding.name: DeviceMetricCalibrationType
binding.definition: Describes the type of a metric calibration

binding.name: DeviceMetricCategory
binding.definition: Describes the category of the metric

code.definition: DeviceObservations generated for this DeviceMetric are measured.
DeviceObservations generated for this DeviceMetric is a setting that will influence the behavior of the Device.
DeviceObservations generated for this DeviceMetric are calculated.
The category of this DeviceMetric is unspecified.

binding.name: MetricType
binding.definition: Describes the metric type

binding.name: MetricUnit
binding.definition: Describes the unit of the metric

binding.name: DeviceMetricOperationalStatus
binding.definition: Describes the operational status of the DeviceMetric

code.definition: The DeviceMetric is operating and will generate DeviceObservations.
The DeviceMetric is not operating.
The DeviceMetric is operating, but will not generate any DeviceObservations.

annotation.definition: Describes the type of the metric. For example: Heart Rate, PEEP Setting, etc.

Describes the unique identification of this metric that has been assigned by the device or gateway software. For example: handle ID. It should be noted that in order to make the identifier unique, the system element of the identifier should be set to the unique identifier of the device.
Describes the unit that an observed value determined for this metric will have. For example: Percent, Seconds, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Describes the link to the source Device
annotation.definition: Describes the link to the Device that this DeviceMetric belongs to and that contains administrative device information such as manufacture, serial number, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Describes the link to the parent DeviceComponent
annotation.definition: Describes the link to the DeviceComponent that this DeviceMetric belongs to and that provide information about the location of this DeviceMetric in the containment structure of the parent Device. An example would be a DeviceComponent that represents a Channel. This reference can be used by a client application to distinguish DeviceMetrics that have the same type, but should be interpreted based on their containment location.
Indicates current operational state of the device. For example: On, Off, Standby, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: black | red | green | yellow | blue | magenta | cyan | white
annotation.definition: Describes the typical color of the representation of observations that have been generated for this DeviceMetric.
Indicates the category of the observation generation process. A DeviceMetric can be for example a setting, measurement, or calculation.
Describes the measurement repetition time. This is not necessarily the same as the update period.

annotation.shortDefinition: Describes the calibrations that have been performed or that are required to be performed
annotation.definition: Describes the calibrations that have been performed or that are required to be performed.

annotations.shortDefinition: A request for a patient to use or be given a medical device
annotations.definition: Represents a request for a patient to employ a medical device. The device may be an implantable device, or an external assistive device, such as a walker.

binding.name: DeviceUseRequestStatus
binding.definition: Codes representing the status of the request

code.definition: The request has been proposed.
The request has been planned.
The request has been placed.
The receiving system has received the request but not yet decided whether it will be performed.
The receiving system has accepted the request but work has not yet commenced.
The work to fulfill the order is happening.
The work has been complete, the report(s) released, and no further work is planned.
The request has been held by originating system/user request.
The receiving system has declined to fulfill the request.
The request was attempted, but due to some procedural error, it could not be completed.

binding.name: DeviceUseRequestPriority
binding.definition: Codes representing the priority of the request

code.definition: The request has a normal priority.
The request should be done urgently.
The request is time-critical.
The request should be acted on as soon as possible.

annotation.definition: Indicates the site on the subject's body where the device should be used ( i.e. the target site).
annotation.requirements: Knowing where the device is targeted is important for tracking if multiple sites are possible.

annotation.shortDefinition: proposed | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | completed | suspended | rejected | aborted
annotation.definition: The status of the request.
The details of the device to be used.
An encounter that provides additional context in which this request is made.
Identifiers assigned to this order by the orderer or by the receiver.
Reason or justification for the use of this device.

Details about this request that were not represented at all or sufficiently in one of the attributes provided in a class. These may include for example a comment, an instruction, or a note associated with the statement.
The proposed act must be performed if the indicated conditions occur, e.g.., shortness of breath, SpO2 less than x%.
The time when the request was made.
The time at which the request was made/recorded.
The patient who will use the device.

The timing schedule for the use of the device The Schedule data type allows many different expressions, for example. "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".
Characterizes how quickly the use of device must be initiated. Includes concepts such as stat, urgent, routine.

search.description: Search by subject

search.description: Device requested

annotations.definition: A record of a device being used by a patient where the record is the result of a report from the patient or another clinician.

annotation.definition: Indicates the site on the subject's body where the device was used ( i.e. the target site).
annotation.requirements: Knowing where the device is targeted is important for tracking if multiple sites are possible.

annotation.definition: The time period over which the device was used.
The details of the device used.
An external identifier for this statement such as an IRI.
Reason or justification for the use of the device.

Details about the device statement that were not represented at all or sufficiently in one of the attributes provided in a class. These may include for example a comment, an instruction, or a note associated with the statement.
The time at which the statement was made/recorded.
The patient who used the device.
How often the device was used.

annotations.shortDefinition: A request for a diagnostic service
annotations.definition: A record of a request for a diagnostic investigation service to be performed.

A nested type in DiagnosticOrder: The specific diagnostic investigations that are requested as part of this request. Sometimes, there can only be one item per request, but in most contexts, more than one investigation can be requested.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code to indicate the item (test or panel) being ordered
annotation.definition: A code that identifies a particular diagnostic investigation, or panel of investigations, that have been requested.
annotation.comment: Many laboratory tests and radiology tests embed the specimen/organ system in the test name, for example, serum or serum/plasma glucose, or a chest xray. The specimen may not be recorded separately from the test code.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this item relates to specific specimens
annotation.definition: If the item is related to a specific specimen.
annotation.comment: A single specimen should not appear in both DiagnosticOrder.specimen and DiagnosticOrder.item.specimen.

annotation.definition: Anatomical location where the request test should be performed. This is the target site.

annotation.shortDefinition: proposed | draft | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | review | completed | cancelled | suspended | rejected | failed
annotation.definition: The status of this individual item within the order.
annotation.comment: If the request has multiple items that have their own life cycles, then the items will have their own status while the overall diagnostic order is (usually) "in-progress".
annotation.rimMapping: .statusCode also influenced by whether a ControlAct fulfillment requeste exists, whether a promise exists, status of the review component, whether a fulfilling observation exists, whether a refusal exists

annotation.definition: A summary of the events of interest that have occurred as this item of the request is processed.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DiagnosticOrder: A summary of the events of interest that have occurred as the request is processed. E.g. when the order was made, various processing steps (specimens received), when it was completed.

annotation.shortDefinition: proposed | draft | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | review | completed | cancelled | suspended | rejected | failed
annotation.definition: The status for the event.
annotation.rimMapping: .statusCode also influenced by whether a ControlAct fulfillment requeste exists, whether a promise exists, status of the review component, whether a fulfilling observation exists, whether a refusal exists

annotation.shortDefinition: More information about the event and its context
annotation.definition: Additional information about the event that occurred - e.g. if the status remained unchanged.

annotation.shortDefinition: The date at which the event happened
annotation.definition: The date/time at which the event occurred.
The person who was responsible for performing or recording the action.

binding.name: DiagnosticRequests
binding.definition: Codes for tests/services that can be performed by diagnostic services

binding.name: DiagnosticOrderEventDescription
binding.definition: Additional information about an event that occurred to a diagnostic order - e.g. if the status remained unchanged

binding.name: DiagnosticOrderStatus
binding.definition: The status of a diagnostic order

code.definition: The request has been proposed.
the request is in preliminary form prior to being sent.
The request has been planned.
The request has been placed.
The receiving system has received the order, but not yet decided whether it will be performed.
The receiving system has accepted the order, but work has not yet commenced.
The work to fulfill the order is happening.
The work is complete, and the outcomes are being reviewed for approval.
The work has been complete, the report(s) released, and no further work is planned.
the request has been withdrawn.
The request has been held by originating system/user request.
The receiving system has declined to fulfill the request.
The diagnostic investigation was attempted, but due to some procedural error, it could not be completed.

binding.name: DiagnosticOrderPriority
binding.definition: The clinical priority of a diagnostic order

code.definition: The order has a normal priority.
The order should be urgently.
The order is time-critical.
The order should be acted on as soon as possible.

annotation.shortDefinition: Who and/or what test is about
annotation.definition: Who or what the investigation is to be performed on. This is usually a human patient, but diagnostic tests can also be requested on animals, groups of humans or animals, devices such as dialysis machines, or even locations (typically for environmental scans).
The practitioner that holds legal responsibility for ordering the investigation.
Identifiers assigned to this order by the order or by the receiver.

annotation.shortDefinition: The encounter that this diagnostic order is associated with
annotation.definition: An encounter that provides additional information about the healthcare context in which this request is made.
An explanation or justification for why this diagnostic investigation is being requested.
annotation.comment: This may be used to decide how the diagnostic investigation will be performed, or even if it will be performed at all.

annotation.definition: Additional clinical information about the patient or specimen that may influence test interpretations.
annotation.comment: This information includes diagnosis, clinical findings and other observations. Examples include reporting the amount of inspired carbon dioxide for blood gasses, the point in the menstrual cycle for cervical pap tests, and other conditions that influence test interpretations.

annotation.shortDefinition: If the whole order relates to specific specimens
annotation.definition: One or more specimens that the diagnostic investigation is about.
annotation.comment: Many investigation requests will create a need for specimens, but the request itself is not actually about the specimens. This is provided for when the diagnostic investigation is requested on already existing specimens.

annotation.shortDefinition: proposed | draft | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | review | completed | cancelled | suspended | rejected | failed
annotation.definition: The status of the order.
annotation.comment: Typically the system placing the order sets the status to requested. Thereafter, the order is maintained by the receiver that updates the status as the request is handled.
annotation.rimMapping: .statusCode also influenced by whether a ControlAct fulfillment requeste exists, whether a promise exists, status of the review component, whether a fulfilling observation exists, whether a refusal exists

annotation.definition: The clinical priority associated with this order.
annotation.comment: The Order resource also has a priority. Generally, these should be the same, but they can be different, for instance in the case where the clinician indicates that the order is urgent, but the subsequent workflow process overrule this priority for some reason. The effective default value is "normal".

annotation.shortDefinition: A list of events of interest in the lifecycle
annotation.definition: A summary of the events of interest that have occurred as the request is processed. E.g. when the order was made, various processing steps (specimens received), when it was completed.
annotation.comment: This is not the same as an audit trail - it is a view of the important things that happened in the past. Typically, there would only be one entry for any given status, and systems may not record all the status events.

annotation.definition: The specific diagnostic investigations that are requested as part of this request. Sometimes, there can only be one item per request, but in most contexts, more than one investigation can be requested.
annotation.comment: There would always be at least one item in normal usage, but this is optional so that a workflow can quote order details without having to list the items.

search.name: orderer
search.description: Who ordered the test

search.name: status
search.description: proposed | draft | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | review | completed | cancelled | suspended | rejected | failed

search.name: subject
search.description: Who and/or what test is about

search.description: proposed | draft | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | review | completed | cancelled | suspended | rejected | failed

search.description: proposed | draft | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | review | completed | cancelled | suspended | rejected | failed

search.name: actor
search.description: Who recorded or did this

search.name: code
search.description: Code to indicate the item (test or panel) being ordered

search.name: encounter
search.description: The encounter that this diagnostic order is associated with

search.name: item-past-status
search.description: proposed | draft | planned | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | review | completed | cancelled | suspended | rejected | failed

search.name: patient
search.description: Who and/or what test is about

search.name: bodysite
search.description: Location of requested test (if applicable)

search.name: item-date
search.description: The date at which the event happened

search.name: specimen
search.description: If the whole order relates to specific specimens

search.name: event-status-date
search.description: A combination of past-status and date

search.name: event-date
search.description: The date at which the event happened

search.name: identifier
search.description: Identifiers assigned to this order

search.name: item-status-date
search.description: A combination of item-past-status and item-date

annotations.shortDefinition: A Diagnostic report - a combination of request information, atomic results, images, interpretation, as well as formatted reports
annotations.definition: The findings and interpretation of diagnostic tests performed on patients, groups of patients, devices, and locations, and/or specimens derived from these. The report includes clinical context such as requesting and provider information, and some mix of atomic results, images, textual and coded interpretation, and formatted representation of diagnostic reports.
annotations.comment: This is intended to capture a single report, and is not suitable for use in displaying summary information that covers multiple reports. For example, this resource has not been designed for laboratory cumulative reporting formats nor detailed structured reports for sequencing.
annotations.requirements: To support reporting for any diagnostic report into a clinical data repository.
annotations.committeeNotes: It's not clear how to handle cumulative reports.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DiagnosticReport: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).

annotation.definition: A comment about the image. Typically, this is used to provide an explanation for why the image is included, or to draw the viewer's attention to important features.
annotation.comment: The comment should be displayed with the image. It would be common for the report to include additional discussion of the image contents in other sections such as the conclusion.
annotation.requirements: The provider of the report should make a comment about each image included in the report.

annotation.definition: Reference to the image source.

binding.name: BodySite
binding.definition: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality

binding.name: AdjunctDiagnosis
binding.definition: Diagnoses codes provided as adjuncts to the report

binding.name: DiagnosticReportNames
binding.definition: Codes that describe Diagnostic Reports

binding.name: DiagnosticServiceSection
binding.definition: Codes for diagnostic service sections

binding.name: DiagnosticReportStatus
binding.definition: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole

code.definition: The existence of the report is registered, but there is nothing yet available.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) report: data in the report may be incomplete or unverified.
The report is complete and verified by an authorized person.
The report has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by an authorized person.
The report has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by an authorized person. New content has been added, but existing content hasn't changed.
The report is unavailable because the measurement was not started or not completed (also sometimes called "aborted").
The report has been withdrawn following previous Final release.

annotation.definition: A code or name that describes this diagnostic report.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR-4-Universal Service ID (V2 doesn't provide an easy way to indicate both the ordered test and the performed panel)

annotation.shortDefinition: registered | partial | final | corrected | appended | cancelled | entered-in-error
annotation.definition: The status of the diagnostic report as a whole.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications need to take appropriate action if a report is withdrawn.
annotation.requirements: Diagnostic services routinely issue provisional/incomplete reports, and sometimes withdraw previously released reports.
annotation.rimMapping:
statusCode
Note: final and amended are distinguished by whether observation is the subject of a ControlAct event of type "revise"

annotation.definition: The date and/or time that this version of the report was released from the source diagnostic service.
annotation.comment: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report .
annotation.requirements: Clinicians need to be able to check the date that the report was released.

annotation.shortDefinition: The subject of the report, usually, but not always, the patient
annotation.definition: The subject of the report. Usually, but not always, this is a patient. However diagnostic services also perform analyses on specimens collected from a variety of other sources.
annotation.requirements: SHALL know the subject context.
annotation.v2Mapping: PID-3-Patient ID List (no V2 mapping for Group or Device)

annotation.definition: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
annotation.comment: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items - it is the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.
annotation.requirements: Need to know whom to contact if there are queries about the results. Also may need to track the source of reports for secondary data analysis.

annotation.shortDefinition: Health care event when test ordered
annotation.definition: The link to the health care event (encounter) when the order was made.

annotation.shortDefinition: Id for external references to this report
annotation.definition: The local ID assigned to the report by the order filler, usually by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider.
annotation.requirements: Need to know what identifier to use when making queries about this report from the source laboratory, and for linking to the report outside FHIR context.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR-51-Observation Group ID (todo: check semantic intent of OBR-51 with OOWG)

annotation.definition: Details concerning a test requested.
annotation.comment: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track completion of requests based on reports issued and also to report what diagnostic tests were requested (not always the same as what is delivered).

annotation.definition: The section of the diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, hematology, MRI.
annotation.requirements: Help clinicians filter/find the reports they are looking for.

annotation.definition: The time or time-period the observed values are related to. This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection(s), but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
annotation.comment: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was performed. If there are specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.
annotation.requirements: Need to know where in the patient history to file/present this report.

annotation.shortDefinition: Specimens this report is based on
annotation.definition: Details about the specimens on which this diagnostic report is based.
annotation.comment: If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data may be redundant. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per Observation or group.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to report information about the collected specimens on which the report is based.

annotation.shortDefinition: Observations - simple, or complex nested groups
annotation.definition: Observations that are part of this diagnostic report. Observations can be simple name/value pairs (e.g. "atomic" results), or they can be grouping observations that include references to other members of the group (e.g. "panels").
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to individual results, or report groups of results, where the result grouping is arbitrary, but meaningful. This structure is recursive - observations can contain observations.

annotation.shortDefinition: Reference to full details of imaging associated with the diagnostic report
annotation.definition: One or more links to full details of any imaging performed during the diagnostic investigation. Typically, this is imaging performed by DICOM enabled modalities, but this is not required. A fully enabled PACS viewer can use this information to provide views of the source images.
annotation.comment: ImagingStudy and image are somewhat overlapping - typically, an image in the image list will also be found in the imaging study resource. However the imaging study and image lists cater to different types of displays for different types of purposes. Neither, either, or both may be provided.

annotation.shortDefinition: Key images associated with this report
annotation.definition: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).
annotation.requirements: Many diagnostic services include images in the report as part of their service.

annotation.definition: Concise and clinically contextualized narrative interpretation of the diagnostic report.
annotation.comment: Typically, a report is either [all data, no narrative (e.g. Core lab)] or [a mix of data with some concluding narrative (e.g. Structured Pathology Report, Bone Density)], or [all narrative (e.g. typical imaging report, histopathology)]. In all of these cases, the narrative goes in "text".
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to provide a conclusion that is not lost amongst the basic result data.

annotation.definition: Codes for the conclusion.
Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
annotation.comment: Application/pdf is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.
annotation.requirements: Gives Laboratory the ability to provide its own fully formatted report for clinical fidelity.

example.name: Assorted Collection
example.description: Various reports gathered from v2 messages

example.name: Report Feed
example.description: Snapshot of a live feed from a laboratory

example.name: Micro Isolate and Sensitivities
example.description: An example of a complex Micro Isolate and Sensitivities

example.name: USLab DiagnosticReport Example1
example.description: USLabReport DiagnosticReport Profile Canonical Example: Childhood Blood Lead Report

search.name: result
search.description: Link to an atomic result (observation resource)

search.name: status
search.description: The status of the report

search.name: subject
search.description: The subject of the report

search.name: issued
search.description: When the report was issued

search.name: diagnosis
search.description: A coded diagnosis on the report

search.name: image
search.description: Reference to the image source

search.name: encounter
search.description: The Encounter when the order was made

search.name: date
search.description: The clinically relevant time of the report

search.name: patient
search.description: The subject of the report if a patient

search.name: request
search.description: What was requested

search.name: specimen
search.description: The specimen details

search.name: name
search.description: The name of the report (e.g. the code for the report as a whole, as opposed to codes for the atomic results, which are the names on the observation resource referred to from the result)

search.name: service
search.description: Which diagnostic discipline/department created the report

search.name: performer
search.description: Who was the source of the report (organization)

search.name: identifier
search.description: An identifier for the report

annotations.shortDefinition: A manifest that defines a set of documents
annotations.definition: A manifest that defines a set of documents.
A nested type in DocumentManifest: Related identifiers or resources associated with the DocumentManifest.

annotation.definition: Related identifier to this DocumentManifest. If both id and ref are present they shall refer to the same thing.
annotation.comment: Order numbers, accession numbers, XDW workflow numbers.

annotation.definition: Related Resource to this DocumentManifest. If both id and ref are present they shall refer to the same thing.
annotation.comment: Order, DiagnosticOrder, Procedure, EligibilityRequest, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Unique Identifier for the set of documents
annotation.definition: A single identifier that uniquely identifies this manifest. Principally used to refer to the manifest in non-FHIR contexts.
annotation.rimMapping: id [need a list semantic to indicate order matters]

annotation.definition: Other identifiers associated with the document manifest, including version independent identifiers.

annotation.shortDefinition: The subject of the set of documents
annotation.definition: Who or what the set of documents is about. The documents can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (i.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure). If the documents cross more than one subject, then more than one subject is allowed here (unusual use case).

annotation.shortDefinition: Intended to get notified about this set of documents
annotation.definition: A patient, practitioner, or organization for which this set of documents is intended.
annotation.comment: How the recipient receives the document set or is notified of it is up to the implementation. This element is just a statement of intent.

annotation.shortDefinition: What kind of document set this is
annotation.definition: Specifies the kind of this set of documents (e.g. Patient Summary, Discharge Summary, Prescription, etc.). The type of a set of documents may be the same as one of the documents in it - especially if there is only one - but it may be wider.

annotation.shortDefinition: Who and/or what authored the document
annotation.definition: Identifies who is responsible for adding the information to the document.
annotation.comment: Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) or who was the source (informant).

annotation.definition: When the document manifest was created for submission to the server (not necessarily the same thing as the actual resource last modified time, since it may be modified, replicated etc).
annotation.comment: Creation time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching. This is the creation time of the document set, not the documents on which it is based.

annotation.definition: Identifies the source system, application, or software that produced the document manifest.
The status of this document manifest.
Human-readable description of the source document. This is sometimes known as the "title".
annotation.comment: What the document is about, rather than a terse summary of the document. It is commonly the case that records do not have a title and are collectively referred to by the display name of Record code (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note").
annotation.requirements: Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contents of this set of documents
annotation.definition: The list of resources that describe the parts of this document reference. Usually, these would be document references, but direct references to binary attachments and images are also allowed.
Related identifiers or resources associated with the DocumentManifest.
annotation.comment: May be identifiers or resources that caused the DocumentManifest to be created.

search.name: status
search.description: current | superceded | entered-in-error

search.name: subject
search.description: The subject of the set of documents

search.name: relatedids
search.description: Related Identifier

search.name: type
search.description: What kind of document set this is

search.name: recipient
search.description: Intended to get notified about this set of documents

search.name: content
search.description: Contents of this set of documents

search.name: author
search.description: Who and/or what authored the document

search.name: patient
search.description: The subject of the set of documents

search.name: source
search.description: The source system/application/software

search.name: created
search.description: When this document manifest created

search.name: description
search.description: Human-readable description (title)

search.name: identifier
search.description: Unique Identifier for the set of documents

search.name: relatedrefs
search.description: Related Resource

annotations.shortDefinition: A reference to a document
annotations.definition: A reference to a document.
annotations.comment: Usually, this is used for documents other than those defined by FHIR.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DocumentReference: The clinical context in which the document was prepared.

annotation.definition: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the typeCode, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
annotation.comment: An event can further specialize the act inherent in the type, such as where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more event codes are included, they shall not conflict with the values inherent in the class or type elements as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation.

annotation.shortDefinition: Time of service that is being documented
annotation.definition: The time period over which the service that is described by the document was provided.

annotation.shortDefinition: Kind of facility where patient was seen
annotation.definition: The kind of facility where the patient was seen.

annotation.shortDefinition: Additional details about where the content was created (e.g. clinical specialty)
annotation.definition: This property may convey specifics about the practice setting where the content was created, often reflecting the clinical specialty.
annotation.comment: The value set for this content has an example binding because it is a value set decided by community policy. Other examples exist for consideration: * HITSP created the table HITSP/C80 Table 2-148 Clinical Specialty Value Set (a value set based upon SNOMED-CT which is referenced by Direct (XDR and XDM for Direct Messaging Specification, Version 1), as well as Nationwide Health Information Network (NHIN). Query for Documents, Web Service Interface Specification, V 3.0, 07/27/2011 * ELGA (Austria) (ELGA CDA Implementie-rungsleitfäden Registrierung von CDA Dokumenten für ELGA mit IHE Cross-Enterprise Document Sharing: XDS Metadaten (XDSDocumentEntry), [1.2.40.0.34.7.6.3] * XDS Connect-a-thon practiceSettingCode.
annotation.requirements: This is an important piece of metadata that providers often rely upon to quickly sort and/or filter out to find specific content.

annotation.definition: The Patient Information as known when the document was published. May be a reference to a version specific, or contained.
Related identifiers or resources associated with the DocumentReference.
annotation.comment: May be identifiers or resources that caused the DocumentReference or referenced Document to be created.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DocumentReference: Relationships that this document has with other document references that already exist.

annotation.definition: The type of relationship that this document has with anther document.
annotation.comment: If this document appends another document, then the document cannot be fully understood without also accessing the referenced document.

annotation.definition: The target document of this relationship.

annotations.definition: A nested type in DocumentReference: Related identifiers or resources associated with the DocumentReference.

annotation.definition: Related identifier to this DocumentReference. If both id and ref are present they shall refer to the same thing.
annotation.comment: Order numbers, accession numbers, XDW workflow numbers.

annotation.definition: Related Resource to this DocumentReference. If both id and ref are present they shall refer to the same thing.
annotation.comment: Order, DiagnosticOrder, Procedure, EligibilityRequest, etc.

binding.name: DocumentC80FacilityType
binding.definition: XDS Facility Type

binding.name: ReferredDocumentStatus
binding.definition: Status of the underlying document

binding.name: DocumentC80PracticeSetting
binding.definition: Additional details about where the content was created (e.g. clinical specialty)

binding.name: DocumentRelationshipType
binding.definition: The type of relationship between documents

code.definition: This document logically replaces or supercedes the target document.
This document was generated by transforming the target document (e.g. format or language conversion).
This document is a signature of the target document.
This document adds additional information to the target document.

binding.name: DocumentIHEFormat
binding.definition: Document Format Codes

binding.name: DocumentC80Type
binding.definition: Precice type of clinical document

binding.name: DocumentC80Class
binding.definition: High-level classification of a clinical document

binding.name: HCS
binding.definition: Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System

binding.name: DocumentReferenceStatus
binding.definition: The status of the document reference

code.definition: This is the current reference for this document.
This reference has been superseded by another reference.
This reference was created in error.

annotation.definition: Document identifier as assigned by the source of the document. This identifier is specific to this version of the document. This unique identifier may be used elsewhere to identify this version of the document.
annotation.comment: CDA Document Id extension and root.
annotation.requirements: The structure and format of this Id shall be consistent with the specification corresponding to the formatCode attribute. (e.g., for a DICOM standard document a 64 character numeric UID, for an HL7 CDA format a serialization of the CDA Document Id extension and root in the form oid^extension, where OID is a 64 digits max, and the Id is a 16 UTF-8 char max. If the OID is coded without the extension then the '^' character shall not be included.).

annotation.definition: Other identifiers associated with the document, including version independent identifiers.

annotation.shortDefinition: Who|what is the subject of the document
annotation.definition: Who or what the document is about. The document can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (I.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure).
annotation.v2Mapping: PID-3-Patient ID List (No standard way to define a Practitioner or Group subject in V2 MDM message)

annotation.definition: The type code specifies the precise type of document from the user perspective. It is recommended that the value Set be drawn from a coding scheme providing a fine level of granularity such as LOINC. (e.g. Patient Summary, Discharge Summary, Prescription, etc.).
annotation.comment: Key metadata element describing the document, used in searching/filtering.

annotation.definition: The class code specifying the high-level use classification of the document type (e.g., Report, Summary, Images, Treatment Plan, Patient Preferences, Workflow).
annotation.comment: Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest when viewing an list of documents.

annotation.definition: An identifier that identifies the the document encoding, structure and template that the document conforms to beyond the base format indicated in the mimeType.
annotation.comment: Helps the processing. Usually is a URN that identifies. For IHE defined Document Content profiles this is a urn issued by IHE.

annotation.shortDefinition: Who and/or what authored the document
annotation.definition: Identifies who is responsible for adding the information to the document.
annotation.comment: Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) it in or who was the source (informant).
annotation.v2Mapping: TXA-9-Originator Code/Name (No standard way to indicate a Device in V2 MDM message)

annotation.definition: Identifies the organization or group who is responsible for ongoing maintenance of and access to the document.
annotation.comment: Identifies the logical organization to go to find the current version, where to report issues, etc. This is different from the physical location of the document, which is the technical location of the document, which host may be delegated to the management of some other organization.

annotation.definition: Which person or organization authenticates that this document is valid.
annotation.comment: Represents a participant within the author institution who has legally authenticated or attested the document. Legal authentication implies that a document has been signed manually or electronically by the legal Authenticator.

annotation.definition: When the document was created.
annotation.comment: Creation time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching. This is the creation time of the document, not the source material on which it is based.

annotation.definition: When the document reference was created.
annotation.comment: Referencing/indexing time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.

annotation.definition: The status of this document reference.
annotation.comment: This is the status of the DocumentReference object, which might be independent from the docStatus.

annotation.definition: The status of the underlying document.
annotation.comment: The document that is pointed to might be in various lifecycle states.

annotation.definition: Relationships that this document has with other document references that already exist.
Human-readable description of the source document. This is sometimes known as the "title".
annotation.comment: What the document is about, rather than a terse summary of the document. It is commonly the case that records do not have a title and are collectively referred to by the display name of Record code (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note").
annotation.requirements: Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest.

annotation.definition: A set of Security-Tag codes specifying the level of privacy/security of the Document.
annotation.comment: The confidentiality codes can carry multiple vocabulary items. HL7 has developed an understanding of security and privacy tags that might be desirable in a Document Sharing environment, called HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System (HCS). The following specification is recommended but not mandated, as the vocabulary bindings are an administrative domain responsibility. The use of this method is up to the policy domain such as the XDS Affinity Domain or other Trust Domain where all parties including sender and recipients are trusted to appropriately tag and enforce. • [1…1] Confidentiality Security Classification Label Field • [0…*] Sensitivity Security Category Label Field • [0…*] Compartment Security Category Label Field • [0…*] Integrity Security Category Label Field • [0…*] Handling Caveat Security Category Field In the HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System In the HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification (HCS) there are code systems specific to Confidentiality, Sensitivity, Integrity, and Handling Caveats. Some values would come from a local vocabulary as they are related to workflow roles and special projects.
annotation.requirements: Use of the Health Care Privacy/Security Classification (HCS) system of security-tag use is recommended.

annotation.definition: The document or url to the document along with critical metadata to prove content has integrity.
The clinical context in which the document was prepared.
annotation.comment: These values are primarily added to help with searching for interesting/relevant documents.

annotation.definition: The status of the participants presence at the specified location during the period specified. If the participant is is no longer at the location, then the period will have an end date/time.

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location
annotation.definition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Encounter: The main practitioner responsible for providing the service.

annotation.definition: Role of participant in encounter.
annotation.comment: The Participant Type indicates how an individual parcitipates in an encounter. It includes non practitioner participants, and for practitioners this is to describe the action type in the context of this encounter (e.g. Admitting Dr, Attending Dr, Translator, Consulting Dr). This is different to the Practitioner Roles which are functional roles, derived from terms of employment, education, licensing, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Period of time during the encounter participant was present
annotation.definition: The period of time that the specified participant was present during the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounters period.

annotation.shortDefinition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
annotation.definition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.

binding.name: EncounterClass
binding.definition: Classification of the encounter

code.definition: An encounter during which the patient is hospitalized and stays overnight.
An encounter during which the patient is not hospitalized overnight.
An encounter where the patient visits the practitioner in his/her office, e.g. a G.P. visit.
An encounter where the patient needs urgent care.
An encounter where the practitioner visits the patient at his/her home.
An encounter taking place outside the regular environment for giving care.
An encounter where the patient needs more prolonged treatment or investigations than outpatients, but who do not need to stay in the hospital overnight.
An encounter that takes place where the patient and practitioner do not physically meet but use electronic means for contact.

Any other encounter type that is not described by one of the other values. Where this is used it is expected that an implementer will include an extension value to define what the actual other type is.

inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +.

annotation.definition: The patient present at the encounter.

The referral request that this encounter is satisfies (incoming referral).

annotation.shortDefinition: List of participants involved in the encounter

annotation.definition: The start and end time of the encounter.

annotation.shortDefinition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted
annotation.definition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted. This excludes the time during leaves of absence.
annotation.comment: May differ from the time the Encounter.period lasted because of leave of absence.
annotation.v2Mapping: (PV1-45 less PV1-44) iff ( (PV1-44 not empty) and (PV1-45 not empty) ); units in minutes

annotation.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
annotation.v2Mapping: EVN-4-event reason code / PV2-3-admit reason (note: PV2-3 is nominally constrained to inpatient admissions; V2.x makes no vocabulary suggestions for PV2-3; would not expect PV2 segment or PV2-3 to be in use in all implementations )

annotation.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, as specified using information from another resource. For admissions, this is the admission diagnosis. The indication will typically be a Condition (with other resources referenced in the evidence.detail), or a Procedure.
annotation.v2Mapping: Resources that would commonly referenced at Encounter.indication would be Condition and/or Procedure. These most closely align with DG1/PRB and PR1 respectively.

annotation.shortDefinition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter
annotation.definition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

annotation.v2Mapping: PV1-10-hospital service / PL.6 Person Location Type & PL.1 Point of Care (note: V2.x definition is "the treatment or type of surgery that the patient is scheduled to receive"; seems slightly out of alignment with the concept name 'hospital service'. Would not trust that implementations apply this semantic by default)

binding.name: EpisodeOfCareStatus

code.definition: This episode of care is planned to start at the date specified in the period.start. During this status an organization may perform assessments to determine if they are eligible to receive services, or be organizing to make resources available to provide care services.
This episode of care is current.
This episode of care is on hold, the organization has limitted responsibility for the patient (such as while on respite).
This episode of care is finished at the organization is not expecting to be providing care to the patient.

The episode of care was withdrawn from service, often selected during the planned stage as the patient may have gone elsewhere, or the circumstances have changed and the organization is unable to provide the care.
The status is outside one of these values, an extension should be used to define what the status reason is.
