search.name: value-string
search.description: The value of the observation, if the value is a string, and also searches in CodeableConcept.text

search.name: status
search.description: The status of the observation

search.name: subject
search.description: The subject that the observation is about

search.name: value-concept
search.description: The value of the observation, if the value is a CodeableConcept

search.name: reliability
search.description: The reliability of the observation

search.name: encounter
search.description: Healthcare event related to the observation

search.name: code
search.description: The code of the observation type

search.name: date
search.description: Obtained date/time. If the obtained element is a period, a date that falls in the period

search.name: related-target
search.description: Observation that is related to this one

search.name: data-absent-reason
search.description: The reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.

search.name: related
search.description: Related Observations - search on related-type and related-target together

search.name: patient
search.description: The subject that the observation is about (if patient)

search.name: specimen
search.description: Specimen used for this observation

search.name: device
search.description: The Device that generated the observation data.

search.name: related-type
search.description: has-component | has-member | derived-from | sequel-to | replaces | qualified-by | interfered-by

search.name: performer
search.description: Who performed the observation

search.name: identifier
search.description: The unique Id for a particular observation

search.name: value-quantity
search.description: The value of the observation, if the value is a Quantity, or a SampledData (just search on the bounds of the values in sampled data)

search.name: code-value-[x]
search.description: Both code and one of the value parameters

search.name: value-date
search.description: The value of the observation, if the value is a Period

annotations.shortDefinition: Definition of an operation or a named query
annotations.definition: A formal computable definition of an operation (on the RESTful interface) or a named query (using the search interaction).
A nested type in OperationDefinition: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of a individual to contact
annotation.definition: The name of an individual to contact regarding the operation definition.
annotation.comment: If there is no named individual, the telecom is for the organization as a whole.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contact details for individual or publisher
annotation.definition: Contact details for individual (if a name was provided) or the publisher.

annotations.definition: A nested type in OperationDefinition: The parts of a Tuple Parameter.

annotation.definition: The name of used to identify the parameter.
annotation.comment: This name must be a token (start with a letter in a..z, and only contain letters, numerals, and underscore.

annotation.definition: The minimum number of times this parameter SHALL appear in the request or response.
The maximum number of times this element is permitted to appear in the request or response.
Describes the meaning or use of this parameter.
The type for this parameter.
A profile the specifies the rules that this parameter must conform to.

annotations.definition: A nested type in OperationDefinition: The parameters for the operation/query.

annotation.definition: The name of used to identify the parameter.
annotation.comment: This name must be a token (start with a letter in a..z, and only contain letters, numerals, and underscore.

annotation.definition: Whether this is an input or an output parameter.
annotation.comment: If a parameter name is used for both an input and an output parameter, the parameter should be defined twice.

annotation.definition: The minimum number of times this parameter SHALL appear in the request or response.
The maximum number of times this element is permitted to appear in the request or response.
Describes the meaning or use of this parameter.
The type for this parameter.
annotation.comment: if there is no stated parameter, then the parameter is a "Tuple" type and must have at least one part defined.

annotation.definition: A profile the specifies the rules that this parameter must conform to.
The parts of a Tuple Parameter.
annotation.comment: Query Definitions only have one output parameter, named "result". This may not be described, but can be to allow a profile to be defined.

binding.name: OperationParameterUse
binding.definition: Whether an operation parameter is an input or an output parameter

code.definition: This is an input parameter.
This is an output parameter.

binding.name: OperationKind
binding.definition: Whether an operation is a normal operation or a query

code.definition: This operation is invoked as an operation.
This operation is a named query, invoked using the search mechanism.

binding.name: OperationParameterType
binding.definition: The type of a parameter

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical url to reference this operation definition
annotation.definition: An absolute url that is used to identify this operation definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique uri).
annotation.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid:.

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of the operation definition
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the profile when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp.
annotation.requirements: There may be multiple resource versions of the profile that have this same identifier. The resource version id will change for technical reasons, whereas the stated version number needs to be under the author's control.

annotation.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the Profile.
annotation.comment: Not expected to be globally unique.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)
annotation.definition: The name of the individual or organization that published the operation definition.
annotation.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
annotation.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the operation definition. May also allow for contact.

annotation.definition: Contacts to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
annotation.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Natural language description of the operation
annotation.definition: A free text natural language description of the profile and its use.
annotation.comment: This field can be used for things such as why the profile was written, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is *not* a rendering of the profile as conveyed in Profile.text. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

annotation.definition: Explains why this operation definition is needed and why it's been constrained as it has.
annotation.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the operation definition (that's done in comments), rather it's for traceability of *why* the element is either needed or why the constraints exist as they do. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this data element.

annotation.definition: The status of the profile.
annotation.requirements: Allows filtering of profiles that are appropriate for use vs. not.

annotation.shortDefinition: If for testing purposes, not real usage
annotation.definition: This profile was authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
annotation.requirements: Allows filtering of profiles that are appropriate for use vs. not.

annotation.shortDefinition: Date for this version of the operation definition
annotation.definition: The date that this version of the profile was published.
Whether this is operation or named query.
annotation.comment: Named queries are invoked differently, and have different capabilities.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name used to invoke the operation
annotation.definition: The name used to invoke the operation.
Additional information about how to use this operation or named query.

annotation.shortDefinition: Marks this as a profile of the base
annotation.definition: Indicates that this operation definition is a constraining profile on the base.
annotation.comment: A constrained profile can make optional parameters required or not used and clarify documentation.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether this operation or named query can be invoked at the system level (e.g. without needing to choose a resource type for the context).

annotation.shortDefinition: Invoke at resource level for these type
annotation.definition: Indicates whether this operation or named query can be invoked at the resource type level for any given resource type level (e.g. without needing to choose a resource type for the context).
Indicates whether this operation can be invoked on a particular instance of one of the given types.
The parameters for the operation/query.
annotation.comment: Query Definitions only have one output parameter, named "result". This may not be described, but can be to allow a profile to be defined.

search.name: status
search.description: draft | active | retired

search.name: code
search.description: Name used to invoke the operation

search.name: date
search.description: Date for this version of the operation definition

search.name: type
search.description: Invoke at resource level for these type

search.name: url
search.description: Logical url to reference this operation definition

search.name: kind
search.description: operation | query

search.name: version
search.description: Logical id for this version of the operation definition

search.name: publisher
search.description: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)

search.name: system
search.description: Invoke at the system level?

search.name: name
search.description: Informal name for this profile

search.name: base
search.description: Marks this as a profile of the base

search.name: instance
search.description: Invoke on an instance?

search.name: profile
search.description: Profile on the type

annotations.shortDefinition: Information about the success/failure of an action
annotations.definition: A collection of error, warning or information messages that result from a system action.
annotations.comment: Can result from the failure of a REST call or be part of the response message returned from a request message. If sent with extensions overriding particular issues, might even appear as part of a request message.
annotations.rimMapping: Grouping is handled through multiple repetitions from whatever context references the outcomes (no specific grouper required)

annotations.definition: A nested type in OperationOutcome: An error, warning or information message that results from a system action.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether the issue indicates a variation from successful processing.
annotation.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not confuse hints and warnings with errors.
annotation.requirements: Indicates how relevant the issue is to the overall success of the action.
annotation.rimMapping: ./typeCode[parent::AcknowledgmentDetail] or unique(./inboundRelationship[parent::Observation and typeCode='SUBJ' and isNormalActRelationship()]/source[classCode="OBS" and moodCode="EVN" and implies(code, ActCode#SEV and isNormalAct())/value[xsi:type="CD"]

annotation.definition: Describes the type of the issue.
annotation.requirements: Expresses the issue in a human and computer-friendly way, allowing the requesting system to behave differently based on the type of issue. The system that creates an OperationOutcome SHALL choose the most applicable code from the IssueType value set, and may additional provide it's own codes in other coding elements in the type. A human readable description of the type of the issue SHOULD be placed in code.text.

annotation.shortDefinition: Additional diagnostic information about the issue
annotation.definition: Additional diagnostic information about the issue. Typically, this may be a description of how a value is erroneous, or a stck dump to help trace the issue.
annotation.comment: typically this field is used to provide troubleshooting information about the error.

annotation.shortDefinition: XPath of element(s) related to issue
annotation.definition: A simple XPath limited to element names, repetition indicators and the default child access that identifies one of the elements in the resource that caused this issue to be raised.
annotation.comment: The root of the XPath is the resource or bundle that generated OperationOutcome. Each XPath SHALL resolve to a single node. The XPath syntax is used whether the referenced instance is expressed in XML or JSON.
annotation.requirements: Allows systems to highlight or otherwise guide users to elements implicated in issues to allow them to be fixed more easily.

binding.name: IssueType
binding.definition: A coded expression of the type of issue

code.definition: Content invalid against the Specification or a Profile.
A structural issue in the content such as wrong namespace, or unable to parse the content completely, or invalid json syntax.
A required element is missing.
element value invalid.
A content validation rule failed - e.g. a schematron rule.
An authentication/authorization/permissions issueof some kind.
the client needs to initiate an authentication process.
The user or system was not able to be authenticated (either there is no process, or the proferred token is unacceptable).
User session expired; a login may be required.
The user does not have the rights to perform this action.

Some information was not or may not have been returned due to business rules, consent or privacy rules, or access permission constraints. This information may be accessible through alternate processes.
Processing issues. These are expected to be final e.g. there is no point resubmitting the same content unchanged.
The resource or profile is not supported.
An attempt was made to create a duplicate record.

The reference provided was not found. In a pure RESTful environment, this would be an HTTP 404 error, but this code may be used where the content is not found further into the application architecture.
Provided content is too long (typically, this is a denial of service protection type of error).
The code or system could not be understood, or it was not valid in the context of a particular ValueSet.
An extension was found that was not acceptable, or that could not be resolved, or a modifierExtension that was not recognised.
The operation was stopped to protect server resources. E.g. a request for a value set expansion on all of SNOMED CT.
The content/operation failed to pass some business rule, and so could not proceed.

content could not be accepted because of an edit conflict (i.e. version aware updates) (In a pure RESTful environment, this would be an HTTP 404 error, but this code may be used where the conflict is discovered further into the application architecture).
Not all data sources typically accessed could be reached, or responded in time, so the returned information may not be complete.
Transient processing issues. The system receiving the error may be able to resubmit the same content once an underlying issue is resolved.
A resource/record locking failure (usually in an underlying database).
The persistent store unavailable. E.g. the database is down for maintenance or similar.
An unexpected internal error.
An internal timeout occurred.
The system is not prepared to handle this request due to load management.
A message unrelated to the processing success of the completed operation (Examples of the latter include things like reminders of password expiry, system maintenance times, etc.).

binding.name: IssueSeverity
binding.definition: How the issue affects the success of the action

code.definition: The issue caused the action to fail, and no further checking could be performed.
The issue is sufficiently important to cause the action to fail.
The issue is not important enough to cause the action to fail, but may cause it to be performed suboptimally or in a way that is not as desired.
The issue has no relation to the degree of success of the action.

annotation.shortDefinition: A single issue associated with the action
annotation.definition: An error, warning or information message that results from a system action.

annotations.shortDefinition: A request to perform an action
annotations.definition: A request to perform an action.
A nested type in Order: When order should be fulfilled.

annotation.shortDefinition: Code specifies when request should be done. The code may simply be a priority code
annotation.definition: Code specifies when request should be done. The code may simply be a priority code.
annotation.comment: This is usually a local code agreed in the context of the ordering workflow.

annotation.definition: A formal schedule.

binding.name: RequestedTime
binding.definition: When a requested action should be performed (e.g. STAT, daily, evenings, etc.)

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifiers assigned to this order by the orderer or by the receiver
annotation.definition: Identifiers assigned to this order by the orderer or by the receiver.
When the order was made.
Patient this order is about.
annotation.comment: May be left blank if the request reference identifies the patient, or if the request is not associated with a patient.

annotation.definition: Who initiated the order.

annotation.shortDefinition: Who is intended to fulfill the order
annotation.definition: Who is intended to fulfill the order.
annotation.v2Mapping: Unclear: MSH-5 / IPC-7 / BPO-8 / RXO-32 / RXE-40 / RXD-30 / RXG-11 / RXG-27 / PRT-8 (PRT-4-participation in { 'AP', 'DP', 'PO', 'RT' })

annotation.shortDefinition: Text - why the order was made
annotation.definition: Text - why the order was made.
If required by policy.
annotation.comment: Reference will be constrained when suitable targets exist.
annotation.v2Mapping: if ordering provider, then ORC-12, OBR-16, etc.
annotation.todo: Verify RIM semantics.

annotation.definition: When order should be fulfilled.
What action is being ordered.

search.description: What action is being ordered

search.description: Patient this order is about

search.description: Who initiated the order

search.description: Patient this order is about

search.description: A formal schedule

search.description: Who is intended to fulfill the order

search.description: Code specifies when request should be done. The code may simply be a priority code

annotations.shortDefinition: A response to an order
annotations.definition: A response to an order.
annotations.comment: There might be more than one response to an order.

binding.name: OrderStatus
binding.definition: The status of the response to an order

code.definition: The order is known, but no processing has occurred at this time.
The order is undergoing initial processing to determine whether it will be accepted (usually this involves human review).
The order was rejected because of a workflow/business logic reason.
The order was unable to be processed because of a technical error (i.e. unexpected error).
The order has been accepted, and work is in progress.
Processing the order was halted at the initiators request.
The order has been cancelled and replaced by another.
Processing the order was stopped because of some workflow/business logic reason.
The order has been completed.

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifiers assigned to this order by the orderer or by the receiver
annotation.definition: Identifiers assigned to this order. The identifiers are usually assigned by the system responding to the order, but they may be provided or added to by other systems.

annotation.shortDefinition: The order that this is a response to
annotation.definition: A reference to the order that this is in response to.
The date and time at which this order response was made (created/posted).
The person, organization, or device credited with making the response.
A reference to an authority policy that is the reason for the response. Usually this is used when the order is rejected, to provide a reason for rejection.
annotation.comment: Reference will be constrained when suitable targets exist.
annotation.v2Mapping: Defined in FHIR as 'if required by policy'; unclear how this would map to V2 except ORC-19.9-action by.assigning authority or ORC-30-enterer authorization mode, neither of which exactly scales to a resource

annotation.shortDefinition: pending | review | rejected | error | accepted | cancelled | replaced | aborted | completed
annotation.definition: What this response says about the status of the original order.
Additional description about the response - e.g. a text description provided by a human user when making decisions about the order.

annotation.shortDefinition: Details of the outcome of performing the order
annotation.definition: Links to resources that provide details of the outcome of performing the order. E.g. Diagnostic Reports in a response that is made to an order that referenced a diagnostic order.
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR+OBX[n] / RXE / RXD / RXG / RXA / BPX / BTX

annotations.shortDefinition: A grouping of people or organizations with a common purpose
annotations.definition: A formally or informally recognized grouping of people or organizations formed for the purpose of achieving some form of collective action. Includes companies, institutions, corporations, departments, community groups, healthcare practice groups, etc.
A nested type in Organization: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose.

annotation.definition: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached.
annotation.requirements: Need to distinguish between multiple contact persons.

annotation.shortDefinition: A name associated with the contact
annotation.definition: A name associated with the contact.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track the person by name.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contact details (telephone, email, etc) for a contact
annotation.definition: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the party may be contacted.
annotation.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

annotation.shortDefinition: Visiting or postal addresses for the contact
annotation.definition: Visiting or postal addresses for the contact.
annotation.requirements: May need to keep track of a contact party's address for contacting, billing or reporting requirements.

binding.name: OrganizationType
binding.definition: Used to categorize the organization

binding.name: ContactPartyType
binding.definition: The purpose for which you would contact a contact party

annotation.shortDefinition: Identifies this organization across multiple systems
annotation.definition: Identifier for the organization that is used to identify the organization across multiple disparate systems.
annotation.requirements: Organizations are known by a variety of ids. Some institutions maintain several, and most collect identifiers for exchange with other organizations concerning the organization.
annotation.v2Mapping: XON.10 Organization Identifier / XON.3 ID Number

annotation.definition: A name associated with the organization.
annotation.requirements: Need to use the name as the label of the organization.
annotation.committeeNotes: If you need multiple names to cater for acronyms and "trading under" names, use an extension "alias" instead.

annotation.definition: The kind of organization that this is.
annotation.comment: Organizations can be corporations, wards, sections, clinical teams, government departments, etc. Note that code is generally a classifier of the type of organization; in many applications, codes are used to identity a particular organization (say, ward) as opposed to another of the same type - these are identifiers, not codes.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track the kind of organization that this is - different organization types have different uses.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact detail for the organization
annotation.definition: A contact detail for the organization.
annotation.comment: The use code home is not to be used. Note that these contacts are not the contact details of people who are employed by or represent the organization, but official contacts for the organization itself.
annotation.requirements: Human contact for the organization.

annotation.definition: An address for the organization.
annotation.comment: Organization may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods. The use code home is not to be used.
annotation.requirements: May need to keep track of the organization's addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements.
annotation.v2Mapping: No authoritative equivalent in V2.x; some V2.x segments such as OBX might provide a serialized instance value

annotation.shortDefinition: The organization of which this organization forms a part
annotation.definition: The organization of which this organization forms a part.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track the hierarchy of organizations within an organization.

annotation.shortDefinition: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose
annotation.definition: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose.
annotation.requirements: Need to keep track of assigned contact points within bigger organization.

annotation.shortDefinition: Location(s) the organization uses to provide services
annotation.definition: Location(s) the organization uses to provide services.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether the organization's record is still in active use
annotation.definition: Whether the organization's record is still in active use.
annotation.comment: Default is true.
annotation.requirements: Need a flag to indicate a record is no longer to be used and should generally be hidden for the user in the UI.
annotation.committeeNotes: Lloyd(?): This isn't data we record about an organization but is data about this organization's record. I would argue about including this metadata here. It also implies effects on functionality, like not showing up in queries anymore, which cannot be guaranteed. All in all, this belongs to record infrastructure, not data.

invariant.name: org-1
invariant.human: The organization SHALL at least have a name or an id, and possibly more than one

annotations.shortDefinition: Resource for non-supported content
annotations.definition: Other is a conformant for handling resource concepts not yet defined for FHIR or outside HL7's scope of interest.
annotations.requirements: Need some way to safely (without breaking interoperability) allow implementers to exchange content not supported by the initial set of declared resources.

binding.name: OtherResourceType
binding.description: HL7-maintained set of codes for "Other" resources
binding.definition: Codes for identifying types of resources not yet defined by FHIR

annotation.definition: Identifier assigned to the resource for business purposes, outside the context of FHIR.
Identifies the 'type' of resource - equivalent to the resource name for other resources.
annotation.comment: Because resource references will only be able to indicate 'Other', the type of reference will need to be specified in a Profile identified as part of the resource. Refer to the resource notes section for information on appropriate terminologies for this code.
annotation.requirements: Must be able to distinguish different types of "other" resources.

annotation.definition: Identifies the patient, practitioner, device or any other resource that is the "focus" of this resoruce.
annotation.comment: Optional as not all resources potential resources will have subjects. Resources associated with multiple subjects can handle this via extension.
annotation.requirements: Needed for partitioning the resource by Patient.

annotation.definition: Indicates who was responsible for creating the resource instance.
annotation.requirements: Needed for partitioning the resource.

annotation.definition: Identifies when the resource was first created.
annotation.requirements: Allows ordering resource instances by time.

annotations.shortDefinition: Information about an individual or animal receiving health care services
annotations.definition: Demographics and other administrative information about an individual or animal receiving care or other health-related services.
annotations.requirements: Tracking patient is the center of the healthcare process.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Patient: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient.

annotation.definition: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the contact person.
annotation.requirements: Used to determine which contact person is the most relevant to approach, depending on circumstances.

annotation.shortDefinition: A name associated with the contact person
annotation.definition: A name associated with the contact person.
annotation.requirements: Contact persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that contact person.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact detail for the person
annotation.definition: A contact detail for the person, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
annotation.comment: Contact may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.
annotation.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

annotation.definition: Address for the contact person.
annotation.requirements: Need to keep track where the contact person can be contacted per postal mail or visited.

annotation.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the contact person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
annotation.requirements: Needed to address the person correctly.

annotation.shortDefinition: Organization that is associated with the contact
annotation.definition: Organization on behalf of which the contact is acting or for which the contact is working.
annotation.requirements: For guardians or business related contacts, the organization is relevant.

annotation.shortDefinition: The period during which this contact person or organization is valid to be contacted relating to this patient
annotation.definition: The period during which this contact person or organization is valid to be contacted relating to this patient.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Patient: Languages which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health.

annotation.shortDefinition: The language which can be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
annotation.definition: The ISO-639-1 alpha 2 code in lower case for the language, optionally followed by a hyphen and the ISO-3166-1 alpha 2 code for the region in upper case. E.g. "en" for English, or "en-US" for American English versus "en-EN" for England English.
annotation.comment: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
annotation.requirements: Most systems in multilingual countries will want to convey language. Not all systems actually need the regional dialect.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether or not the Patient prefers this language (over other languages he masters up a certain level).
annotation.comment: This language is specifically identified for communicating healthcare information.
annotation.requirements: People that master multiple languages up to certain level may prefer one or more, i.e. feel more confident in communicating in a particular language making other languages sort of a fall back method.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Patient: This element has a value if the patient is an animal.

annotation.definition: Identifies the high level taxonomic categorization of the kind of animal.
annotation.comment: If the patient is non-human, at least a species SHALL be specified. Species SHALL be a widely recognised taxonomic classification. It may or may not be Linnaean taxonomy and may or may not be at the level of species. If the level is finer than species--such as a breed code--the code system used SHALL allow inference of the species. (The common example is that the word "Hereford" does not allow inference of the species Bos taurus, because there is a Hereford pig breed, but the SNOMED code for "Hereford Cattle Breed" does.).
annotation.requirements: Need to know what kind of animal.

annotation.definition: Identifies the detailed categorization of the kind of animal.
annotation.comment: Breed MAY be used to provide further taxonomic or non-taxonomic classification. It may involve local or proprietary designation--such as commercial strain--and/or additional information such as production type.
annotation.requirements: May need to know the specific kind within the species.

annotation.definition: Indicates the current state of the animal's reproductive organs.
annotation.requirements: Gender status can affect housing and animal behavior.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Patient: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual patient.

annotation.shortDefinition: The other patient resource that the link refers to
annotation.definition: The other patient resource that the link refers to.

annotation.shortDefinition: replace | refer | seealso - type of link
annotation.definition: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

binding.name: AnimalGenderStatus
binding.definition: The state of the animal's reproductive organs

binding.name: LinkType
binding.definition: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

code.definition: The patient resource containing this link must no longer be used. The link points forward to another patient resource that must be used in lieu of the patient resource that contains the link.

The patient resource containing this link is in use and valid but not considered the main source of information about a patient. The link points forward to another patient resource that should be consulted to retrieve additional patient information.

The patient resource containing this link is in use and valid, but points to another patient resource that is known to contain data about the same person. Data in this resource might overlap or contradict information found in the other patient resource. This link does not indicate any relative importance of the resources concerned, and both should be regarded as equally valid.

binding.name: AnimalBreed
binding.definition: The breed of an animal

binding.name: AnimalSpecies
binding.definition: The species of an animal

binding.name: ContactRelationship
binding.definition: The nature of the relationship between a patient and a contact person for that patient

annotation.definition: An identifier for this patient.
annotation.requirements: Patients are almost always assigned specific numerical identifiers.

annotation.shortDefinition: A name associated with the patient
annotation.definition: A name associated with the individual.
annotation.comment: A Patient may have multiple names with different uses or applicable periods. For animals, the name is a "HumanName" in the sense that is assigned and used by humans and has the same patterns.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track the patient by multiple names. Examples are your official name and a partner name.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact detail for the individual
annotation.definition: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the individual may be contacted.
annotation.comment: A Patient may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently and also to help with identification. The address may not go directly to the individual, but may reach another party that is able to proxy for the patient (i.e. home phone, or pet owner's phone).
annotation.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

annotation.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the patient is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
annotation.comment: The gender may not match the biological sex as determined by genetics, or the individual's preferred identification. Note that for both humans and particularly animals, there are other legitimate possibilities than M and F, though the vast majority of systems and contexts only support M and F. Systems providing decision support or enforcing business rules should ideally do this on the basis of Observations dealing with the specific gender aspect of interest (anatomical, chromosonal, social, etc.) However, because these observations are infrequently recorded, defaulting to the administrative gender is common practice. Where such defaulting occurs, rule enforcement should allow for the variation between administrative and biological, chromosonal and other gender aspects. For example, an alert about a hysterectomy on a male should be handled as a warning or overrideable error, not a "hard" error.
annotation.requirements: Needed for identification of the individual, in combination with (at least) name and birth date. Gender of individual drives many clinical processes.
annotation.committeeNotes: 'gender' is still the administrative gender, but this is reflected in its description rather than its name.

annotation.shortDefinition: The date of birth for the individual
annotation.definition: The date of birth for the individual.
annotation.comment: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real dob is unknown.
annotation.requirements: Age of the individual drives many clinical processes.
annotation.committeeNotes: renamed from dob, because the abbreviation is not obvious to non-English speakers.

annotation.shortDefinition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not
annotation.definition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not.
annotation.comment: If there's no value in the instance it means there is no statement on whether or not the individual is deceased. Most systems will interpret the absence of a value as a sign of the person being alive.
annotation.requirements: The fact that a patient is deceased influences the clinical process. Also, in human communication and relation management it is necessary to know whether the person is alive.
annotation.rimMapping: player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedInd, player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedTime

annotation.definition: Addresses for the individual.
annotation.comment: Patient may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods.
annotation.requirements: May need to keep track of patient addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements and also to help with identification.

annotation.definition: This field contains a patient's most recent marital (civil) status.
annotation.requirements: Most, if not all systems capture it.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether patient is part of a multiple birth
annotation.definition: Indicates whether the patient is part of a multiple or indicates the actual birth order.
annotation.requirements: For disambiguation of multiple-birth children, especially relevant where the care provider doesn't meet the patient, such as labs.

annotation.definition: Image of the patient.
annotation.requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of the patient. Fits with newer social media usage too.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient
annotation.definition: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient.
annotation.comment: Contact covers all kinds of contact parties: family members, business contacts, guardians, caregivers. Not applicable to register pedigree and family ties beyond use of having contact.
annotation.requirements: Need to track people you can contact about the patient.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this patient is an animal (non-human)
annotation.definition: This element has a value if the patient is an animal.
annotation.comment: The animal element is labeled "Is Modifier" since patients may be non-human. Systems SHALL either handle patient details appropriately (e.g. inform users patient is not human) or reject non-human patient records.
annotation.requirements: Many clinical systems are extended to care for animal patients as well as human.

annotation.shortDefinition: A list of Languages which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
annotation.definition: Languages which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health.
annotation.comment: If no language is specified, this *implies* that the default local language is spoken. If you need to convey proficiency for multiple modes than you need multiple Patient.Communication associations. For animals, language is not a relevant field, and should be absent from the instance. If the Patient does not speak the default local language, then the Interpreter Required Standard can be used to explicitly declare that an interpreter is required.
annotation.requirements: If a patient does not speak the local language, interpreters may be required, so languages spoken and proficiency is an important things to keep track of both for patient and other persons of interest.
annotation.committeeNotes: Rationale for putting this in the core is based on input from Canada. Other persons on call are from single language countries. Committee felt uncomfortable with leaving any of the 3 optional attributes modeCode, proficiencyLevelCode, or preferenceInd up to extensions. Instead we said that isModifier is "no" on modeCode and preferenceInd.

annotation.definition: Patient's nominated care provider.
annotation.todo: Need to rationalize this with circleOfCare from CarePlan.

annotation.shortDefinition: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record
annotation.definition: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record.
annotation.requirements: Need to know who recognizes this patient record, manages and updates it.

annotation.shortDefinition: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person
annotation.definition: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual patient.
annotation.comment: There is no assumption that linked patient records have mutual links.
annotation.requirements: There are multiple usecases: * Duplicate patient records due to the clerical errors associated with the difficulties of identifying humans consistently, and * Distribution of patient information across multiple servers.

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether this patient's record is in active use
annotation.definition: Whether this patient record is in active use.
annotation.comment: Default is true. If a record is inactive, and linked to an active record, then future patient/record updates should occur on the other patient.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to mark a patient record as not to be used because it was created in error.

annotations.definition: This resource provides the status of the payment for goods and services rendered, and the request and response resource references.

binding.name: PaymentStatus
binding.definition: The payment conveyance status codes

annotation.definition: The Response Business Identifier.
The version of the style of resource contents. This should be mapped to the allowable profiles for this and supporting resources.
The style (standard) and version of the original material which was converted into this resource.
annotation.requirements: Knowledge of the original version can inform the processing of this instance so that information which is processable by the originating system may be generated.

annotation.definition: The date when this resource was created.
The Insurer who is target of the request.
The practitioner who is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.
The organization which is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.
Reference of resource to reverse.
Reference of response to resource to reverse.

annotations.definition: This resource provides payment details and claim references supporting a bulk payment.

The note text.

The claim or financial resource.
The claim response resource.
The Organization which submitted the invoice or financial transaction.

annotation.definition: The Response Business Identifier.
Original request resource reference.
Transaction status: error, complete.
A description of the status of the adjudication.
The version of the style of resource contents. This should be mapped to the allowable profiles for this and supporting resources.

annotation.definition: The date when the enclosed suite of services were performed or completed.
The period of time for which payments have been gathered into this bulk payment for settlement.
The Insurer who produced this adjudicated response.
The practitioner who is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.

Suite of notes.

search.name: identifier
search.description: The business identifier of the Explanation of Benefit

annotations.shortDefinition: A generic person record
annotations.definition: Demographics and administrative information about a person independent of a specific health-related context.
annotations.comment: The Person resource does justice to Person registries that keep track of Persons regardless of their role. The Person resource is also a primary resource to point to for people acting in a particular role such as SubjectofCare, Practitioner, and Agent. Very few attributes are specific to any role and so Person is kept lean. Most attributes are expected to be tied to the role the Person plays rather than the Person himself. Examples of that are Guardian (SubjectofCare), ContactParty (SubjectOfCare, Practitioner), and multipleBirthInd (SubjectofCare).
annotations.requirements: Need to track persons potentially across multiple roles.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Person: Link to a resource that concerns the same actual person.

annotation.shortDefinition: The resource to which this actual person is associated
annotation.definition: The resource to which this actual person is associated.
Level of assurance that this link is actually associated with the target resource.

binding.name: IdentityAssuranceLevel
binding.definition: The level of confidence that this link represents the same actual person, based on NIST Authentication Levels

code.definition: Little or no confidence in the asserted identity's accuracy.
Some confidence in the asserted identity's accuracy.
High confidence in the asserted identity's accuracy.
Very high confidence in the asserted identity's accuracy.

annotation.shortDefinition: A Human identifier for this person
annotation.definition: Identifier for a person within a particular scope.
annotation.requirements: People are known by a variety of ids. Some institutions maintain several, and most collect identifiers for exchange with other organizations concerning the person. Examples are national person identifier and local identifier.
annotation.committeeNotes: Keeping Person.id cardinality as a matter of safety in the same manner as Person Activate.

annotation.shortDefinition: A name associated with the person
annotation.definition: A name associated with the person.
annotation.comment: Person may have multiple names with different uses or applicable periods.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to track the person by multiple names. Examples are your official name and a partner name.
annotation.committeeNotes: Committee does not fully grasp implications of HumanName datatype, so as a matter of safety decided to have cardinality 0..*. It is not clear to the committee whether or not all 80% name parts can be conveyed in one name instance.

annotation.shortDefinition: A contact detail for the person
annotation.definition: A contact detail for the person, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
annotation.comment: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.
annotation.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.
annotation.committeeNotes: renamed from contact, because that suggested "contact party" at first sight. "telecom" is a well-worn path, so without a really good working alternative we want to stick to it.

annotation.definition: Administrative Gender.
annotation.comment: The gender may not match the biological sex as determined by genetics, or the individual's preferred identification. Note that for both humans and particularly animals, there are other legitimate possibilities than M and F, though the vast majority of systems and contexts only support M and F.
annotation.requirements: Needed for identification of the person, in combination with (at least) name and birth date. Gender of person drives many clinical processes.
annotation.committeeNotes: 'gender' is still the administrative gender, but this is reflected in its description rather than its name.

annotation.shortDefinition: The birth date for the person
annotation.definition: The birth date for the person.
annotation.comment: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real dob is unknown.
annotation.requirements: Age of person drives many clinical processes. Next to the common use case of capturing someone birth date, also in some common cases time is registered.
annotation.committeeNotes: renamed from dob, because the abbreviation is not obvious to non-English speakers.

annotation.shortDefinition: One or more addresses for the person

annotation.comment: Person may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods.
annotation.requirements: May need to keep track of persons addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements and also to help with identification.

annotation.definition: An image that can be displayed as a thumbnail of the person to enhance the identification of the individual.

annotation.shortDefinition: The Organization that is the custodian of the person record
annotation.definition: The Organization that is the custodian of the person record.
annotation.requirements: Need to know who recognizes this person record, manages and updates it.

annotation.shortDefinition: This person's record is in active use
annotation.definition: Whether this person's record is in active use.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to mark a person record as not to be used because it was created in error.

annotation.shortDefinition: Link to a resource that concerns the same actual person
annotation.definition: Link to a resource that concerns the same actual person.

annotation.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.

annotation.requirements: Knowing which language a practitioner speaks can help in facilitating communication with patients.
annotation.committeeNotes: Note: cannot be named "language" because of technical reasons.

This procedure caused the related one to be performed.

binding.definition: A code that classifies a procedure for searching, sorting and display purposes

binding.definition: The outcome of a procedure - whether it resolveed the reasons why the procedure was performed

binding.definition: Specific follow up required for a procedure e.g. removal of sutures

binding.definition: The kind of change that happened to the device during the procedure

binding.definition: A code specifying the state of the procedure record

code.definition: The procedure is still occurring.
The procedure was terminated without completing successfully.
All actions involved in the procedure have taken place.
The statement was entered in error and Is not valid.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this procedure that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
annotation.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.

annotation.definition: The person on whom the procedure was performed.
A code specifying the state of the procedure record. Generally this will be in-progress or completed state.
A code that classifies the procedure for searching, sorting and display purposes.
The specific procedure that is performed. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure can't be coded.
Detailed and structured anatomical location information. Multiple locations are allowed - e.g. multiple punch biopsies of a lesion.
annotation.todo: Is this approach or target site?

annotation.definition: The reason why the procedure was performed. This may be due to a Condition, may be coded entity of some type, or may simply be present as text.
annotation.comment: e.g. endoscopy for dilatation and biopsy, combination diagnosis and therapuetic.

annotation.shortDefinition: The people who performed the procedure
annotation.definition: Limited to 'real' people rather than equipment.

The date(time)/period over which the procedure was performed. Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.
The encounter during which the procedure was performed.
The location where the procedure actually happened. e.g. a newborn at home, a tracheostomy at a restaurant.
annotation.comment: Ties a procedure to where the records are kept.

annotation.definition: What was the outcome of the procedure - did it resolve reasons why the procedure was performed?

annotation.shortDefinition: Any report that results from the procedure
annotation.definition: This could be a histology result. There could potentially be multiple reports - e.g. if this was a procedure that made multiple biopsies.

Any complications that occurred during the procedure, or in the immediate post-operative period. These are generally tracked separately from the notes, which typically will describe the procedure itself rather than any 'post procedure' issues.
annotation.rimMapping: Need specialization of OUT for this.
annotation.todo: Need harmonization proposal for new ActRelationshipType code.

annotation.definition: If the procedure required specific follow up - e.g. removal of sutures. The followup may be represented as a simple note, or potentially could be more complex in which case the CarePlan resource can be used.

annotation.shortDefinition: A procedure that is related to this one
annotation.definition: Procedures may be related to other items such as procedures or medications. For example treating wound dehiscence following a previous procedure.
Any other notes about the procedure - e.g. the operative notes.
A device change during the procedure.

annotations.shortDefinition: A request for a procedure to be performed

binding.name: ProcedureRequestPriority
binding.definition: The priority of the request

code.definition: The request has a normal priority.
The request should be done urgently.
The request is time-critical.
The request should be acted on as soon as possible.

binding.name: ProcedureRequestStatus
binding.definition: The status of the request

code.definition: The request has been proposed.
The request is in preliminary form, prior to being requested.
The request has been placed.
The receiving system has received the request but not yet decided whether it will be performed.
The receiving system has accepted the request, but work has not yet commenced.
The work to fulfill the request is happening.
The work has been complete, the report(s) released, and no further work is planned.
The request has been held by originating system/user request.
The receiving system has declined to fulfill the request.
The request was attempted, but due to some procedural error, it could not be completed.

annotation.definition: Identifiers assigned to this order by the order or by the receiver.
The patient who will receive the procedure.
The specific procedure that is ordered. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure can't be coded.
Indicates the site on the subject's body where the procedure should be performed ( i.e. the target site).
annotation.comment: Only used if not implicit in code found in ProcedureRequest.type.
annotation.requirements: Knowing where the procedure is made is important for tracking if multiple sites are possible.

annotation.definition: The reason why the procedure is proposed or ordered. This procedure request may be motivated by a Condition for instance.

The timing schedule for the proposed or ordered procedure. The Schedule data type allows many different expressions, for example. "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".
The encounter within which the procedure proposal or request was created.
E.g. surgeon, anaethetist, endoscopist.

annotation.shortDefinition: proposed | draft | requested | received | accepted | in-progress | completed | suspended | rejected | aborted
annotation.definition: The status of the order.
Any other notes associated with this proposal or order - e.g., provider instructions.
If a CodeableConcept is present, it indicates the pre-condition for performing the procedure.
The time when the request was made.
The healthcare professional responsible for proposing or ordering the procedure.
The clinical priority associated with this order.

annotations.shortDefinition: Who, What, When for a set of resources
annotations.definition: Provenance of a resource is a record that describes entities and processes involved in producing and delivering or otherwise influencing that resource. Provenance provides a critical foundation for assessing authenticity, enabling trust, and allowing reproducibility. Provenance assertions are a form of contextual metadata and can themselves become important records with their own provenance. Provenance statement indicates clinical significance in terms of confidence in authenticity, reliability, and trustworthiness, integrity, and stage in lifecycle (e.g., Document Completion - has the artifact been legally authenticated), all of which may impact Security, Privacy, and Trust policies.
annotations.comment: Some parties may be duplicated between the target resource and its provenance. For instance, the prescriber is usually (but not always) the author of the prescription resource. This resource is defined with close consideration for W3C Provenance.
annotations.rimMapping: ControlAct[isNormalAct() and subsumes(CACT, classCode) and moodCode=EVN]
annotations.committeeNotes: Sources of requirements: v2 EVN, Control Act, CDA, W3C provenance, ATNA.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Provenance: An agent takes a role in an activity such that the agent can be assigned some degree of responsibility for the activity taking place. An agent can be a person, an organization, software, or other entities that may be ascribed responsibility.

annotation.definition: The function of the agent with respect to the activity.
annotation.comment: e.g. author | performer | enterer | attester: +.
annotation.rimMapping: attester: .[self::participation]/typeCode='RESP' author: .[self::participation]/typeCode='AUT' cc: .[self::participation]/typeCode='IRCP' enterer: .[self::participation]/typeCode='ENT' informant: .[self::participation]/typeCode='INF' performer: .[self::participation]/typeCode='PRF' verifier: .[self::participation]/typeCode='VRF' source: .[self::outboundRelationship]/typeCode=''

annotation.definition: The type of participation of the agent.
annotation.comment: e.g. Person | Application | Patient | Device +.
annotation.requirements: If the type is "Resource" then the resource itself was the participant. If the type is a type of resource, then the entity identified by the resource is the participant.
annotation.rimMapping: person: ./role[isNormalRole() and classCode='REL']/player[isNormalEntity and classCode='PER' and determinerCode='INST'] agent: ./role[isNormalRole() and classCode='ASSIGNED' and player[isNormalEntity and classCode='PSN' and determinerCode='INST']] organization: ./role[isNormalRole() and classCode='ASSIGNED' and not(player)]/scoper[isNormalEntity and classCode='ORG' and determinerCode='INST'] software: ./role[isNormalRole() and classCode='ASSIGNED']/scoper[isNormalEntity and classCode='DEV' and determinerCode='INST' and hasDomain(code, 'Software')] document: ./target[isNormalAct and subsumes('DOC', classCode) and moodCode='EVN']

annotation.definition: Identity of participant as a Resource or uri.
Human-readable description of the participant.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Provenance: An entity used in this activity.

annotation.definition: How the entity was used during the activity.
The type of the entity. If the entity is a resource, then this is a resource type.
annotation.requirements: If the type is "resource" then the resource itself was the participant. If the type is a type of resource, then the entity identified by the resource is the participant.

annotation.definition: Identity of the Entity used. May be a logical or physical uri and maybe absolute or relative.
annotation.comment: identity may be a reference to a resource or to something else, depending on the type.

annotation.definition: Human-readable description of the entity.

annotation.shortDefinition: Entity is attributed to this agent
annotation.definition: The entity is attributed to an agent to express the agent's responsibility for that entity, possibly along with other agents. This description can be understood as shorthand for saying that the agent was responsible for the activity which generated the entity.

binding.name: ProvenanceAgentRole
binding.definition: The role that a provenance agent played with respect to the activity

binding.name: ProvenanceEntityRole
binding.definition: How an entity was used in an activity

code.definition: A transformation of an entity into another, an update of an entity resulting in a new one, or the construction of a new entity based on a preexisting entity.
A derivation for which the resulting entity is a revised version of some original.
The repeat of (some or all of) an entity, such as text or image, by someone who may or may not be its original author.
A primary source for a topic refers to something produced by some agent with direct experience and knowledge about the topic, at the time of the topic's study, without benefit from hindsight.

binding.name: ProvenanceAgentType
binding.definition: The type of a provenance agent

binding.name: ProvenanceEntityType
binding.definition: The type of an entity used in an activity

annotation.definition: The Reference(s) that were generated or updated by the activity described in this resource. A provenance can point to more than one target if multiple resources were created/updated by the same activity.
annotation.comment: Target references are usually version specific, but may not be, if a version has not been assigned or if the provenance information is part of the set of resources being maintained (i.e. a document). When using the RESTful API, the identity of the resource may not be known (especially not the version specific one); the client may either submit the resource first, and then the provenance, or it may submit both using a single transaction. See the notes on transaction for further discussion.
annotation.rimMapping: ./outboundRelationship[isNormalActRelationship() and typeCode=SUBJ]/target OR ./participation[isNormalParticipation() and typeCode=SBJ]/role OR ./participation[isNormalParticipation() and typeCode=SBJ]/role[isNormalRole()]/player

annotation.definition: The period during which the activity occurred.
annotation.comment: The period can be a little arbitrary; where possible, the time should correspond to human assessment of the activity time.

annotation.shortDefinition: When the activity was recorded / updated
annotation.definition: The instant of time at which the activity was recorded.
annotation.comment: This can be a little different from the time stamp on the resource if there is a delay between recording the event and updating the provenance and target resource.

annotation.definition: The reason that the activity was taking place.

annotation.shortDefinition: Where the activity occurred, if relevant
annotation.definition: Where the activity occurred, if relevant.
annotation.rimMapping: unique(./participation[isNormalParticipation() and typeCode=LOC]/role[isNormalRole() and subsumes(SDLOC, classCode)]/player[isNormalEntity and classCode="LOC" and determinerCode="INST"]

annotation.shortDefinition: Policy or plan the activity was defined by
annotation.definition: Policy or plan the activity was defined by. Typically, a single activity may have multiple applicable policy documents, such as patient consent, guarantor funding, etc.
annotation.comment: For example: Where an OAuth token authorizes, the unique identifier from the OAuth token is placed into the policy element Where a policy engine (e.g. XACML) holds policy logic, the unique policy identifier is placed into the policy element.
annotation.rimMapping: ./inboundRelationship[isNormalActRelationship() and typeCode="SUBJ"]/source[isNormalAct and subsumes(POLICY, classCode) and moodCode=EVN]/text[typeCode='ED'/tel

annotation.definition: An agent takes a role in an activity such that the agent can be assigned some degree of responsibility for the activity taking place. An agent can be a person, an organization, software, or other entities that may be ascribed responsibility.
annotation.comment: Several agents may be associated (i.e. has some responsibility for an activity) with an activity and vice-versa.

annotation.shortDefinition: An entity used in this activity
annotation.definition: An entity used in this activity.
A digital signature on the target Reference(s). The signer should match a Provenance.agent. The purpose of the signature is indicated.

annotations.shortDefinition: A structured set of questions
annotations.definition: A structured set of questions intended to guide the collection of answers. The questions are ordered and grouped into coherent subsets, corresponding to the structure of the grouping of the underlying questions.
annotations.requirements: To support structured, hierarchical registration of data gathered using digital forms and other questionnaires.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Questionnaire: Set of questions within this group. The order of questions within the group is relevant.

annotation.shortDefinition: To link questionnaire with questionnaire answers
annotation.definition: An identifier that is unique within the questionnaire allowing linkage to the equivalent group in a [[[QuestionnaireAnswers]]] resource.
annotation.comment: May be omitted if there is no expectation to link answers back to a questionnaire. This *can* be a meaningful id (e.g. a LOINC code) but is not intended to have any meaning. GUIDs or sequential numbers are appropriate here.
annotation.requirements: [[[QuestionnaireAnswers]]] does not require omitted groups to be included and may have some groups that repeat, so linkage based on position alone is not sufficient.

annotation.shortDefinition: Concept that represents this question on a questionnaire
annotation.definition: Identifies a how this question is known in a particular terminology such as LOINC.
annotation.requirements: Allows linking of questions (and their answers) to formal terminologies.

annotation.shortDefinition: Text of the question as it is shown to the user
annotation.definition: The actual question as shown to the user to prompt them for an answer.
annotation.comment: Common extensions are defined for more specialized types of display text.
annotation.requirements: When including text for the questionnaire, each question may contain its actual question display text.

annotation.definition: The expected format of the answer, e.g. the type of input (string, integer) or whether a (multiple) choice is expected.
annotation.comment: Additional constraints on the type of answer can be conveyed by extensions.
annotation.requirements: Defines the format in which the user is to be prompted for the answer.
annotation.rimMapping: N/A - MIF rather than RIM level

annotation.shortDefinition: Must question be answered in data results?
annotation.definition: If true, indicates that the question must be answered and have required groups within it also present. If false, the question and any contained groups may be skipped when answering the questionnaire.
If true, the question may have more than one answer.
annotation.comment: Whether the question itself will be displayed for each answer is a rendering choice typically based on whether there are nested groups.
annotation.requirements: Used for "check all that apply" types of questions or "list your top 3", etc.

annotation.definition: Reference to a valueset containing the possible options.
annotation.rimMapping: Not supported - MIF/templating layer to capture value set

annotation.definition: Nested group, containing nested question for this question. The order of groups within the question is relevant.
annotation.requirements: It is useful to have "sub-questions", questions which normally appear when certain answers are given and which collect additional details.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Questionnaire: A collection of related questions (or further groupings of questions).

annotation.shortDefinition: To link questionnaire with questionnaire answers
annotation.definition: An identifier that is unique within the questionnaire allowing linkage to the equivalent group in a QuestionnaireAnswers resource.
annotation.comment: May be omitted if there is no expectation to link answers back to a questionnaire. This *can* be a meaningful id (e.g. a LOINC code) but is not intended to have any meaning. GUIDs or sequential numbers are appropriate here.
annotation.requirements: [[[QuestionnaireAnswers]]] does not require omitted groups to be included and may have some groups that repeat, so linkage based on position alone is not sufficient.

annotation.shortDefinition: Name to be displayed for group
annotation.definition: The human-readable name for this section of the questionnaire.
annotation.comment: The title of the "root" group is the title for the questionnaire.
annotation.requirements: When including text for the questionnaire with the answers, sections may have a section header.

annotation.shortDefinition: Concept that represents this section on a questionnaire
annotation.definition: Identifies a how this group of questions is known in a particular terminology such as LOINC.
annotation.comment: The code(s) for the "root" group apply to the questionnaire as a whole.
annotation.requirements: Allows linking of groups of questions (and complete questionnaires) to formal terminologies.

annotation.definition: Additional text for the group, used for display purposes.
annotation.comment: Common extensions are defined for more specialized types of display text.
annotation.requirements: When including text for the questionnaire, each section may contain additional explanations are background text.

annotation.shortDefinition: Must group be included in data results?
annotation.definition: If true, indicates that the group must be present and have required questions within it answered. If false, the group may be skipped when answering the questionnaire.
Whether the group may occur multiple times in the instance, containing multiple sets of answers.
annotation.requirements: Groups may be used to create set of (related) questions that can be repeated to give multiple answers to such a set.

annotation.definition: A sub-group within a group. The ordering of groups within this group is relevant.
annotation.requirements: Reports can consist of complex nested groups.

annotation.definition: Set of questions within this group. The order of questions within the group is relevant.
annotation.requirements: Must register answers to questions.

binding.name: QuestionnaireGroupConcept
binding.definition: Codes for questionnaires and groupings of questionnaire questions

binding.name: QuestionConcept
binding.definition: Codes corresponding to individual questions

binding.name: QuestionnaireStatus
binding.definition: Lifecycle status of the questionnaire

code.definition: This Questionnaire is not ready for official use.
This Questionnaire is ready for use.
This Questionnaire should no longer be used to gather data.

binding.name: AnswerFormat
binding.definition: The expected format of an answer

code.definition: Answer is a yes/no answer.
Answer is a floating point number.
Answer is an integer.
Answer is a date.
Answer is a date and time.
Answer is a system timestamp.
Answer is a time independent of date.
Answer is a short (few words to short sentence) free-text entry.
Answer is a long (potentially multi-paragram) free-text entry.
Answer is a url (website, FTP site, etc.).
Answer is a choice from a list of options.
Answer is a choice from a list of options or a free-text entry.
Answer is binary content such as a image, PDF, etc.
Answer is a reference to another resource (practitioner, organization, etc.).
Answer is a combination of a numeric value and unit.

annotation.definition: This records identifiers associated with this question set that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
annotation.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.
annotation.committeeNotes: Is this 80%?

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of Questionnaire
annotation.definition: The version number assigned by the publisher for business reasons. It may remain the same when the resource is updated.
annotation.requirements: In some cases, separate resource instances might be created for each version (if an older version can be maintained once a new version exists).

annotation.definition: The lifecycle status of the questionnaire as a whole.
annotation.rimMapping: .statusCode (also whether there's a revisionControlAct - and possibly mood to distinguish "in-progress" from "published)

annotation.definition: The date that this questionnaire was last changed.
Organization or person responsible for developing and maintaining the questionnaire.
annotation.requirements: Conveys responsibility for the questions and their organization and also helps evaluate the questionnaire's "authority".

annotation.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
A collection of related questions (or further groupings of questions).
annotation.comment: The Questionnaire itself has one "root" group with the actual contents of the Questionnaire. Information on this root group applies to the questionnaire as a whole.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to logically group answers to grouped questions.

invariant.name: que-2
invariant.human: The link ids for groups and questions must be unique within the questionnaire

example.name: Lifelines
example.description: Real-world lifelines questionnaire (fictively taken from the patient)

example.name: BlueBook
example.description: Neonate record from New South Wales, Australia "My Personal Health Record" example

example.name: SDC
example.description: Set of several examples - medication, AHRQ and NCI forms

example.name: SDC-LOINC
example.description: SDC medication example with LOINC codes populated

search.name: title
search.description: All or part of the name of the questionnaire (title for the root group of the questionnaire)

search.name: status
search.description: The status of the questionnaire

search.name: code
search.description: A code that corresponds to the questionnaire or one of its groups

search.name: date
search.description: When the questionnaire was last changed

search.name: identifier
search.description: An identifier for the questionnaire

search.name: version
search.description: The business version of the questionnaire

search.name: publisher
search.description: The author of the questionnaire

annotations.shortDefinition: A structured set of questions and their answers
annotations.definition: A structured set of questions and their answers. The questions are ordered and grouped into coherent subsets, corresponding to the structure of the grouping of the underlying questions.
annotations.requirements: To support structured, hierarchical registration of data gathered using digital forms and other questionnaires.

annotations.definition: A nested type in QuestionnaireAnswers: The respondent's answer(s) to the question.

annotation.definition: The answer (or one of the answers) provided by the respondant to the question.
annotation.comment: More complex structures (Attachment, Resource and Quantity) will typically be limited to electronic forms that can expose an appropriate user interface to capture the components and enforce the constraints of a complex data type. Additional complex types can be introduced through extensions.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to retain a single-valued answer to a question.

annotations.definition: A nested type in QuestionnaireAnswers: Set of questions within this group. The order of questions within the group is relevant.

annotation.definition: Identifies the question from the Questionnaire that corresponds to this question in the QuestionnaireAnswers resource.
annotation.requirements: Groups can repeat in the answers, so a direct 1..1 correspondence may not exist - requiring correspondence by id.

annotation.shortDefinition: Text of the question as it is shown to the user
annotation.definition: The actual question as shown to the user to prompt them for an answer.
annotation.requirements: When including text for the questionnaire, each question may contain its actual question display text.

annotation.definition: The respondent's answer(s) to the question.
annotation.comment: We nest the value because we can't have a repeating structure that has variable type.
